name: Der Präsident. -
text: I declare the session suspended on Thursday 15 January 2015 to be resumed.

name: Der Präsident. -
text: The final draft agenda for this part-session, as set out in the Conference of Presidents at its meeting on Thursday 15 January 2015 in accordance with Rule 152 of the Rules of Procedure, has been distributed. The following amendments have been requested to this draft: the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats is asking for the debate on counter-terrorism measures to be concluded with a resolution to be voted on at the February I part-session.

name: Esteban González Pons
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, this Parliament produces all sorts of resolutions. It doesn't seem to make sense that, after what has happened in Paris, we don't have a resolution on terrorism. The world is waiting to hear this Parliament. Firstly to hear Europe's voice on terrorism, but secondly, and more importantly, to see that we are able to agree not only to speak together in Paris, but also on the substance of the matter. On an issue as important as terrorism, Parliament cannot speak, talk, talk... and not solve. Because not having a resolution against terrorism is a way of resolving, it is the worst possible resolution, which shows that to manifest ourselves we are together, but that on the substance of the issue we are not able to agree. Let's take a step forward. It's a demand.

name: Guy Verhofstadt (ALDE). -
text: Mr President, first of all, I am very happy that my eppied colleague wants to have a debate on the attacks in Paris and the measures to be taken, because I remember that during the meeting of the Conference of Presidents, the last time, the EPP was not yet convinced that it would have a debate today on this issue. I therefore welcome this change of position and my proposal is in fact to try to have a common position of Parliament before there is a meeting of the European Council on the 12th.

name: Birgit Sippel (S&D). -
text: Mr. President! In the wake of the Paris attacks, hundreds of thousands of French citizens demonstrated for democracy, for freedom, for the defence of freedom of expression and other values. Yesterday in committee, the Commission said that we do not need actionism and that it has made it clear that there is a lack of implementation of existing instruments. Yes, we need a response to terrorism, especially terrorism, which is emerging in our own midst!  The fighters no longer come from outside, they come from our own Member States, they are our citizens. That is why we think it is completely wrong to put anything together in a quick shot now, but we insist that we carefully examine the whole package of possible measures and then position ourselves together.

name: Der Präsident. -
text: The Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance is asking for a debate on a statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative on the escalation of the Ukraine conflict and the attacks in Mariupol to be put on the agenda for today, before the one-minute speeches. In addition, the sitting is therefore to be extended until 9 p.m.

name: Rebecca Harms
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which On behalf of my group, I have requested that a debate be held in this plenary session on developments in Mariupol and in eastern Ukraine, even without Mrs Mogherini: that is, the extension of the sitting by one hour. I am not doing this in order to re-discuss what we decided in the last strasbourg week, but I have decided to make this request because I believe that it is important – especially after these terrible developments in eastern Ukraine – to make it clear that we are pursuing all this and that we are taking this seriously and that the aim of our political work on Ukraine and Russia is to create peace and security, to create new and to re-create, and to end the misery and death in eastern Ukraine.  And I decided again this afternoon to stick to the fact that it is right to discuss this today, because I was shocked by news from some Member States, particularly Athens, from where the signal has come from that one wants to take a different account of Russia in this dispute in the future.  I believe that the European Parliament must make it clear to the Council of Foreign Ministers this week, before the extraordinary meeting of Foreign Ministers, that our position applies and that we want the Foreign Ministers and the summit to be united in solidarity. And I have always been in favour of solidarity with Greece, but I am also calling for solidarity from Greece with the east of the European Union and the continent.

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE). -
text: Mr President, we do not agree with our colleague's request. We have already had a debate on Monday in the Committee on Foreign Affairs, in the presence of the Ukrainian Ambassador to the European Union and all the political groups have expressed this position in a very clear way and there is nothing to add to that.  On the other hand, I agree with what our colleague has just said about the attitude of Athens, because we were all surprised to discover this unacceptable attitude. But I think it's enough to put it out here, this alliance with Putin that Tsipras wants to do is unacceptable.

name: Der Präsident. -
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Commission statement on counter-terrorism measures (2015/2530(RSP)).

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, honourable Members, allow me to express my thanks to you for giving me the chance to discuss this issue with you today, just some minutes before I fly to Riga for the informal Justice and Home Affairs Council. I will actually have to leave at 5 p.m. to catch my flight, and I would like to thank Vice-President Katainen for taking the floor if necessary, on behalf of the Commission, to conclude this debate. The brutal terrorist attacks in Paris were an attack on our fundamental rights. It has once again become clear that we face an increased and severe terrorist threat to Europe. We have seen that terrorism knows no borders. Terrorists’ travel, financing and access to weapons are, by definition, cross-border problems and they require a strong, united and coherent response from the entire Union. This is not a time for competition among the EU institutions to act and be seen to be acting – with the danger of announcing badly-thought-through ideas which cannot then be delivered, leaving citizens even more disillusioned with the Union. The Member States, as you know, remain primarily responsible for security, but Europe is part of the solution. There are a lot of relevant EU tools and measures already in place. The Commission is determined to take an approach that is comprehensive, result-oriented and realistically deliverable, with the focus on maximising the added value of existing EU measures and, where necessary, proposing new and complementary ones. The Commission can add value by looking at gaps in the effectiveness of existing operational law enforcement and cooperation tools. Security is essential for a functioning democratic society. It is a prerequisite for our citizens’ wellbeing and a prerequisite for citizens’ ability to exercise their own rights. Freedom and security are two sides of the same coin, and not conflicting goals. Developing such a response requires that we all work together. This Parliament is our strategic partner in developing an effective response that will respect our fundamental rights and values and be in line with the expectations of Europe’s citizens. That is why I am here to present and discuss our latest thinking and lines of action, with the aim of fighting terrorism and radicalisation, in the context of the preparation of the European Agenda on Security announced in our work programme. All the EU institutions will be examining further action on counter-terrorism in the context of the upcoming European Agenda on Security. Initial discussions on this are expected to take place at the informal Justice and Home Affairs Council in Riga and at the meeting of the European Council on 12 February. A new agenda for European security for the years 2015-2020 will be presented in the coming months, around May. This agenda should aim to ensure the highest level of protection for the fundamental rights of our citizens and those residing in or staying in or visiting the European Union. Upholding our democratic values and ensuring security are not only compatible: they are mutually reinforcing. It seems clear that there is a need to maximise the value of existing instruments and to deliver on pending proposals first, before developing further measures. Furthermore, we must make sure that the measures in place allow us to tackle the problems we face effectively. To maximise the value of existing EU measures we also need to make the best use of the Schengen Information System, under existing EU law, for checks on travel documents and on persons at the Union’s external borders and to assess any emerging need for improvement. The Commission is assisting and will further assist Member States in identifying common risk criteria for checks on persons. Europol, in particular, will play an important role in the implementation of the future agenda. We need to make sure that it receives all the requisite information from all Member States so that it can deliver its added value in terms of intelligence and threat assessments. The same goes for Eurojust. As long ago as 2005 it was decided that the Member States should provide counter-terrorism information to both agencies. On cybersecurity and the protection of critical infrastructures, we need to reassess whether additional action is needed. The Boston Marathon bombing highlighted the vulnerability of public events. We will work to protect such soft targets, and also critical infrastructure, more effectively. A number of initiatives and trials are ongoing, which will feed into our reflections for future proposals. With regard to delivering on pending proposals, that is where I believe this House can add value in responding to calls from citizens. One example is the EU Passenger Name Record (PNR) Directive. An EU PNR directive is necessary in order to enhance substantially the security of everyone living in Europe. We need to make sure that our law enforcement authorities have access to the data necessary for the prevention of terrorist acts and serious transnational crimes. No decision has been made, except that the Commission is committed to working with the co-legislators to achieve a legal instrument which is both effective and fully in line with fundamental rights. I am looking forward to seeing this, and I intend to help the European Parliament and the Council in moving forward quickly on this issue. I have read – we have all read – articles about what the position of the Commission might be. Let me be clear: the Commission has not come forward with a modified proposal or other initiative today. That was never planned. There has not even been a College of Commissioners discussion since the orientation debate on the EU security agenda. Everything that has been published allegedly reflecting a Commission official position or decision is therefore wrong. With regard to the data retention reform, and in particular the Law Enforcement Directive, I call on the co-legislators to work together towards quick adoption. This will be essential in providing a clear and predictable framework for the processing of personal data in Member States and the exchange of such data between law enforcement authorities. Furthermore, we need to optimise the sharing of information between law enforcement authorities. To that end, the adoption of the Europol and Eurojust legal frameworks and the pending proposal to improve cross-border law enforcement training will be crucial, but progress can already be achieved without waiting for this. We will very shortly organise a joint meeting with Europol and Eurojust to see how information sharing can be improved under the current legal framework. The Commission is seizing the opportunity, during the preparatory work before adoption of the agenda, to consider whether further measures are needed to address the evolving threat, including whether the existing EU legal framework needs reinforcement. We had our first discussion with my fellow Commissioners just last week. It is clear that the fight against terrorism will be a major focus of this agenda. Let me now put forward some preliminary reflections on the objectives that the European Agenda on Security should address, including how to continue to offer Member States comprehensive support in preventing and addressing radicalisation and other forms of extremism. The fight against arms trafficking is another building block. We need to review the implementation of the existing legislation and ensure a greater exchange of information both between Member States and with Europol, Eurojust and Interpol. At the same time, the fight against organised crime and the financing of terrorism needs to be stepped up. We must deprive terrorists of their sources of finance. The link with organised crime is striking. Ensuring the effective implementation of the fourth Anti-Money-Laundering Directive and the Funds Transfer Regulation agreed upon in December 2014 is crucial. The existing tools for the confiscation of criminal assets must be used. We must ensure the speedy execution of all confiscation orders. We also need to look carefully at reassessing the need for, and the added value of, possible EU solutions for data retention, respecting the principles set out by the Court of Justice last year. The Commission is monitoring and evaluating the situation in each Member State before discussing the way ahead with the co-legislators. We need to find sound solutions for the exchange of passenger record data with those third countries that are key to our security interests and to make sure that they are fully consistent with the solutions to be reached for EU PNR. Full implementation by Member States of existing legislative instruments on information exchange is therefore key. However, we also need to consider how to strengthen Europol’s intelligence analysis capabilities in relation to terrorism and radicalisation-related threats. We need to expand the use of existing EU policy-cycle tools to address serious and organised-crime-related threats as well as threats related to terrorism and radicalisation. On the external front, the EU is stepping up its assistance to neighbouring countries and regions. The particular focus is on law enforcement cooperation, information exchange, extending criminal law tools and anti-radicalisation efforts. Delivering rapidly and effectively on our response requires political will and the setting of clear priorities. The Commission has voiced its determination to take this up as a matter of priority. Working hand in hand with Parliament on developing a coherent response will be essential in defining and developing action to keep Europe both secure and open.

name: Monika Hohlmeier
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has The attacks in Paris, but also the attacks we have seen before, which took place in Brussels, in London, in Madrid, in various cities of the European Union and also outside the European Union, present us with enormous challenges. My wish for this European Parliament – and if it had been in the previous vote, incidentally – would have been for us to have agreed unanimously that we should also be allowed to discuss the issue of terrorism, that we should also have to discuss it in public and that a Community would have to show, just as those governments that are socialist, who are conservative, including Green interior ministers – have all set themselves a common agenda. Frankly, I would like to see a little more unity in this Parliament in order to show the public what we want and how we fight. That is why I would also like us to discuss openly and profoundly objectively the instruments that our law enforcement agencies need to combat the terrorists. Passenger data is one of them, and perhaps data retention is part of it, there are issues that are also controversial in our country, but it is precisely the discussion of prevention measures or what forms of de-radicalisation we can do, what we can do in our prisons. We need to talk to third countries. My request to all my fellow Members is this: let us really work together on this and not show that we are a house here that is once again arguing about trivialities.

name: Gianni Pittella
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, our thoughts today can only go to Paris, this city, this people who have been so deeply affected by that indelible crime. Paris was also the great mass demonstration for us. Paris reminds us of the murderous madness but also of Lassana Bathily, the Muslim boy, of Malian origin, who protected the hostages of the shop and who a seventh ago became French and therefore our Fellow European.  We do not want to forget that jolt of dignity and we believe that from there, we must start again, in a unified spirit, Mr Hohlmeier. We will not fail to support concrete measures, but we will deny our support for measures that undermine freedom, which is an indispensable achievement of the European Union. We call ourselves the European Union because we are founded on freedom. For the rest, you will all have our support for measures that want to combat terrorism effectively. Europe – as the Commissioner mentioned – already has some instruments at its disposal: let us make them work! We need to strengthen Schengen, in its components relating to the exchange of information and the strengthening of security and external borders, without touching on the basic principle of mobility. We have no foreclosure with regard to PNR provided that the conditions relating to the length of data detention and other conditions are clarified. No preconditions, but be careful to deceive the citizens: it is not only with PNR that the problem is solved. PNR can be one of the factors in a multifactorial strategy that we need to put in place, starting with the strengthening of judicial cooperation.  The joint action and work of intelligence, the strengthening of the foreign policy, a common policy towards the countries on the southern shore of the Mediterranean and, finally, a policy aimed at inclusion and integration. Many terrorists, especially young people, come from pockets of poverty, poverty, abandonment, marginalisation and marginalisation: these are the phenomena we must combat: more education, more education, more funding for education, more dialogue to combat fanaticism and terrorism and no exploitation. We must be serious, because we talk and deal with a serious issue: we cannot say, as we sometimes do, that immigration brings terrorism. In my country, not a single immigrant has been suspected or denounced as a terrorist. So let us stand together: we are taking the common front seriously to combat and overcome the evil plan of terrorism.

name: Timothy Kirkhope
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, the atrocities in Paris were shocking. As rapporteur for the EU PNR, it is clearly an important piece of the jigsaw in the EU’s coordinated approach to fighting not only terrorism, but also serious crime. The European Data Protection Supervisor (EDPS) has stated that this Parliament does not have to wait for a new data retention directive or data protection package. I intend to apply the highest data protection standards and the judgment of the European Court of Justice to my proposals. The EU Counter-Terrorism Coordinator says the use of PNR data reduces ethnic profiling. Europol says there are over 3 000 EU foreign fighters radicalised, military trained, returning to the EU and exploiting the gaps and deficiencies in law-enforcement information exchange across the EU. This directive would help to address that. At present there is no EU legal framework for citizens or the airlines and no clear legal or administrative redress in the use of data. My directive would provide these rights and clear legal boundaries. I ask the political groups and Members to work with me and cooperate with me. We can find a solution together to protect lives and to protect civil liberties.

name: Guy Verhofstadt
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, my message this afternoon in this debate is clear. We have to work together in this Parliament and we cannot waste time. Two weeks after the attacks on Charlie Hebdo we must take a leap forward, and we must conclude in the European Union a broad and ambitious package to tackle terrorism. We have to do this as Parliament together with the Commission and together with the Council because it is a common task and there is a common goal to be achieved. In fact, what we have to do is to repeat what happened after 9/11. After 9/11, in 2001, alongside other measures we decided on a package and created the European Arrest Warrant, which at that time represented a dramatic change in Europe because previously it had taken years to secure the extradition of a suspect. Sometimes it took 10 years to bring someone back from the UK to France whereas since we have had the European Arrest Warrant it takes just days to transfer a suspect or a criminal from one country to another. We need the same level of ambition now: not to do the same things, because the threats have changed, but to have a similar package to strengthen our security in Europe – and two things are at stake here. First of all, we need a common capacity to analyse the information and the risk, because that is lacking in Europe. In all major terrorist attacks over the past 10 years, Mr Kirkhope, the perpetrators have been known to the services of the different countries. The problem today is not so much that we do not collect the info; the problem is that we do not share the info between our services in Europe. That is the main problem. We have to create what we are calling ‘euro-intel’ – a system for sharing information and for common analysis of risks. I have heard a number of people today saying that this is not possible under the terms of Article 4 of the Treaty. Well, I can tell you that in the last parliamentary term we changed the Treaty twice: once to have 18 more Members of Parliament and the second time to introduce the European Stability Mechanism to save the banks. If it is possible to change the Treaty on the fast-track procedure to save the banks, it has to be possible to change the Treaty to increase the security of European citizens here in this European Union. Secondly, we must not make the error of the nationalists and the populists, namely to say that the problem is Schengen. The problem is not Schengen. The problem is that we are not sufficiently solid among ourselves to strengthen the outside borders of the Schengen area instead of reinstating internal borders. Finally, on passenger name records (PNR) I want to say just one thing, since Mr Kirkhope has spoken about this. We are in favour of a European PNR system but it has to go together with guarantees and with the protection of data and privacy. It is clear that Mr Pittella is right: this is about safety and freedom at the same time. And one last sentence about the targets in this debate: you cannot abuse the death of Charlie Hebdo as some are doing here in this Parliament, Ms Le Pen, Mr Farage. This is not about a war between civilisations and religions: it is about a war against criminals and terrorists, and that makes all the difference.

name: Cornelia Ernst
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which When I went home yesterday, I ran to my apartment at police cars and I don't know how many heavily armed soldiers pass by. I wondered: are we doing more security? Are we really preventing next attacks, attacks like those in Paris and elsewhere with tighter border controls or five years of passenger data retention? Do you really believe that we are creating more security? We are running after a phantom again, we are running after a fiction that really does us no good! We must fight terrorism where it arises. It originates, for example, in countries such as Iraq. Why? Because the Sunni population there has been humiliated and there is no reconciliation. Terrorism is promoted by Saudi Arabia, whose kings have been handed over by the West, even though they are funding terrorists around the world. The first demand must be: arms exports to such regions do not belong! With europe in mind, terrorism always arises where inclusion fails, and it fails in every Member State. For example, in Germany, where people watch young people run towards jihadists. We must understand that fire cannot be extinguished with fire. This won't do. We need an honest debate on anti-Islamism, anti-Semitism, xenophobia, exclusion in the midst of our society. Instead of more and more restrictions, we need drop-out projects, genuine dialogue and a rethink in EU society so that people's needs can once again play a role in our entire political life.

name: Jan Philipp Albrecht
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, yes, we need to strengthen security. I agree with all those who say we need to deliver whatever is necessary and proportionate to get a higher level of security. But what is proposed now, the proposed blanket mass surveillance of citizens, is exactly the opposite of that. It does not deliver that. Instead, you are delivering a symbolic measure at the cost of effective security and the civil liberties of EU citizens. Even before the Paris attacks it was possible to know who was on which plane. We already know that. We have advance passenger information: it is there, we can access it and we know who is on which plane. In the case of known suspects, we can follow them. So why do we not focus on the suspects? Why do we not focus on the risk? That is what you need to do in your directive, Mr Avramopoulos, because that would be a focused approach on security. We need to strengthen the capacity of police officers and security personnel – locally, regionally and at European level – to analyse this information. They need to be able to join the dots. That is exactly what has been missing in the past and what has led to the insecure situation we have today. But the problem is that we spend all our money on blanket surveillance measures like data retention and other issues. It is proposed to invest hundreds of millions of euros in the blanket retention of personal name records. This money is very much needed by the police everywhere in Europe, and needed for the coordination of European security and police authorities. Europol has just a small amount of money for the setting up of joint investigation teams. We need to invest the money there. That is what we need. So, Mr Avramopoulos, I am not convinced by your proposals, and I am not the only one. The Court of Justice has said very clearly that it is not legal and not in line with the fundamental right of data protection to put everybody under surveillance. You have to choose where you are shooting. You have to choose who you are going after. You have to create some determining criteria to indicate where there is risk or suspicion. Do not put everybody under surveillance because that would be no different to what China or Bahrain does.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD). -
text: Mr President, I would just like clarification on why blue cards are not being taken because this question was, of course, asked at the last Strasbourg part-session. If we do not have the opportunity to question speakers then what happens in this Chamber is merely a series of pre-prepared statements; it is not a debate.  This question was supposed to go back to the Bureau but there has been no explanation whatsoever. So I would like to know, please: is there a reason why we are not having a debate today and could it be communicated to us if there is?

name: Presidente. -
text: Mr Arnott, it is up to the President to admit or not to admit, as provided for in the Rules of Procedure, 'blue cards'.

name: Paul Nuttall
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, as I speak, we are in a building which is guarded by the Belgian army in full combat dress, and that tells us all we need to know about the terror threat we face from extremist Islam. We have already witnessed attacks in London, Madrid, Brussels and now Paris. And let us be honest here: it is not a case of ‘if’ there is another attack; it is a case of ‘when and where’. We can prepare all we want, but none of this will be successful if we do not have the cooperation of the Muslim communities themselves. Europe’s Muslims must do more to root out extremists that exist in their midst. They must take responsibility in order to cut out this cancer. May I suggest that they follow the lead of President al-Sisi of Egypt, who recently attended a Coptic Mass and called on Islamic scholars to renounce jihad. We must also deal with the thorny issue of Turkey. It is the same Turkey which turns a blind eye to extremist Muslims hopping over the border to fight in Syria for ISIS. It is the same Turkey which idly stood by and did almost nothing whilst the border town of Kobane was under attack. It is the same Turkey which has received nearly EUR 1 billion from this place in pre-accession funding, and it is the same Turkey that all of the British political parties, except my own, want in the European Union. Therefore, if we want to tackle terrorism in Europe, then firstly we need Europe’s Muslims on side; secondly we must hold Turkey to account; and thirdly we must control our own borders.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI). -
text: . Mr President, unfortunately the recent events in Paris and Belgium, the daily attacks by terrorist jihadists, in the form of armed robberies, kidnappings, rapes and murders, and the movement of 'designated' European citizens, which have ultimately proved to be extreme Muslim elements, to and from the European Union, demonstrate the wrong policies we are implementing with regard to terrorism. We have established a number of Treaties, laws, strategies and actions to combat it. But we cannot deal with it only through discussions. Let us take brave decisions, let us use all the mechanisms at Community level and, above all, let us put an end to foolish extroversion by, in particular, dealing with countries outside the European Union. We ostrich and fail to look the problems in the eye. Terrorism is an asymmetric threat and as such we must tackle it. Do the rapid reaction units we have set up, such as Europol, not have the necessary, at legislative and operational level? Items. They do not have the know-how, but much more the equipment and the information base. The messages we receive every day warn of the coming danger. Our enemies know our weaknesses. It's about time we admitted them, too.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE). -
text: Mr President, Commissioner, the events in Paris, those in Belgium, the attacks which are foiled - as I said yesterday - every day, but also the jihadist networks which are dismantled every day - even yesterday - in France: we have an urgent need to act. I agree with all of Monika Hohlmeier's requests, but, Commissioner, we had already made many proposals long before these events. However, there are steps that we can take immediately, without additional tools, and indeed, yesterday, Gilles de Kerchove reiterated and affirmed them: the improvement of the use of the Schengen information system, the exchange of information within Europol, but also the establishment of more systematic controls at the external borders of the European Union, as well as the acceleration - which is debated - of the adoption of the European PNR which will always be more effective than twenty-eight. I agree with Guy Verhofstadt's intervention on the need to act quickly, because we are really at war with barbaric criminals and terrorists. Commissioner, I listen to you, we come to your speeches, you make presentations all day long without ever determining a timetable, never. Today, there is an emergency, which is that of the safety of European citizens. You are asked, "When are you going to act, when are you going to put these measures in place, which do not require additional legislative tools?"

name: Birgit Sippel (S&D). -
text: Mr. President! Yesterday, the Commission said in the Committee on Home Affairs that, in the wake of the Paris attacks, we need action, not actionism. Right! Because one of the terrorists' aim is to spread fear so that we restrict democracy and freedoms, and this strategy must not work, even and especially after the Paris attacks. And that is precisely why the proposals currently circulating are worrying in their many ways: monitoring the Internet, collecting passenger data, tightening up the rules for the Schengen area, preventing encrypted communications, perhaps even new data retention and more. I would like to remind the Commission and the Council that, in its judgment on the abolition of the Data Retention Directive, the European Court of Justice has drawn up a fundamental rights check for all surveillance measures. In other words, they must all meet the comprehensive criteria laid down by the European Court of Justice. And in the case of passenger data, this means not only checking storage periods, access rights or effective controls, but also restricting it to the occasional use of data.  Do we have a problem getting data? It was not only in the case of the Paris attacks that the perpetrators were known to the national authorities! However, the Member States are making far too few use of existing instruments and, in particular, the exchange of information seems to be taking place far too little. We therefore need a comprehensive evaluation of existing measures before we always propose new instruments, and we should not forget that this will not eliminate the root causes of terrorism in our midst, such as discrimination and exclusion of young people. The bottom line is that instead of dismantling civil rights, we must defend the rule of law, safeguard freedom and fundamental rights right now. That is what we owe our citizens.

name: Karol Karski (ECR). -
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. According to the Jamestown Foundation (An American think tank), most counter-terrorism operations in Europe after the attacks in Early January in Paris targeted Chechens. According to the BBC, Russian citizens of Chechen origin with explosives have been arrested in France. In Germany, one of those arrested, according to Deutsche Welle, is a Turkish man suspected of directing what he described as "an organization of Islamic extremists from Turkey and Russian Chechnya and Dagestan", while two terrorists were killed and a third Chechen was captured after a police mansle in Belgium. Does the police profiling of Chechen expatriates from Russia show that the authorities of the Member States are taking into account the eastern inspirations of the current wave of terrorism? So how can Moscow gain more support for the far right, anti-immigration and anti-European parties in order to destabilise and undermine the unity of the European Union?

name: Sophia in 't Veld (ALDE). -
text: Mr President, many people in Europe are afraid, understandably, because the images of Paris – but also other images that we see every day – are scary and intimidating. But our response to their fear should not be just symbolism or fake security. We should do what it takes and not just play to the gallery. First of all, we already have an extensive toolkit. We have the tools but we need to evaluate whether we have all the tools that we need and whether we have the right tools or we need bigger or smaller tools. Maybe some tools are superfluous. We also need to assess whether all those measures being decided by Parliament, and also by the government leaders when they meet in Brussels, are subsequently implemented in the Member States. They make a lot of grand statements but I would like to know what the state of implementation of the measures is. I think we should have a scoreboard as in the internal market. On specific topics: regarding PNR, my group, as we signalled two weeks ago by letter, is open to discussion on an EU PNR, but there are two simple and clear conditions. One is that whatever proposal we discuss, it must meet the test of necessity and proportionality. That is a legal requirement, not a political one. Secondly, the Council needs to adopt the directive on data protection. It has been on their table for a year and a half. It is not that difficult. Parliament has voted; it will take them 30 seconds to pass it.  On encryption: I hear a lot of scary and worrying proposals about a ban on encryption or the obligation to hand over encryption keys. They are dangerous proposals. What is next? Will it become a criminal offence if you have a lock on the front door of your house? Because that too would be very useful in the fight against terrorism. We are on a slippery slope. Finally, I am glad to see that we are all united in our determination to fight people who want to destroy our democracy through violent means. But I would like the Council and the Commission to be equally determined when it comes to defending democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights against threats from the inside. I call on the Commission to put forward proposals – as my group has asked many times – for binding instruments for ensuring and enforcing fundamental rights and the rule of law. Binding instruments, Commissioner!

name: Barbara Spinelli (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to express my concern about the anti-terrorism measures that the Commission and the Council are discussing and the risks of emergency legislation which, in the name of values, opposes the rule of law and security. I am talking about the risks, Commissioner, of measures already announced by Member States, of monitoring websites, of obstacles to movement in the Schengen area, of the disproportionately long collection of passenger data (PNR) which this Parliament and the European Court of Justice have already rejected. Many of these measures existed before the terrible attacks in France. They didn't stop them. I am talking about the link established in many schools, in many public places between terrorists and Muslim communities. I am talking about the general tendency, which was already seen in the attack on the Twin Towers, to speak of a 'war against terrorism'. This is not a war.

name: Eva Joly (Verts/ALE). -
text: Mr President, Commissioner and dear colleagues, three words: sincerity, lucidity and proportionality.  Sincerity, first. Don't play with the fear of our fellow citizens and stop lying. No, a European NRL would not have prevented these tragedies. It is means that we need and not new legislation. Lucidity, then. Analyze malfunctions before promoting new measures. Proportionality, at last. As the Court of Justice has pointed out, a balance must be struck between the fight against terrorism and respect for our fundamental freedoms. Only suspicious persons and their relatives should be monitored. Widespread surveillance will not prevent terrorist acts, but will lead to fragile democracies that may be tempted by abuses. Let us not fight terrorists with methods prohibited by law. Let us not turn into involuntary auxiliaries of terrorist logic.  They kill, let's not let them destroy our values.

name: Laura Ferrara (EFDD). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the terrorist threat, which has been bullied by the events in Paris, must not lead us to make mistakes similar to those which occurred the day after 11 September, when the Patriot Act used measures that severely restricted freedom and fundamental rights. The protection of public security must not become the basis of campaigns of psychological terrorism, which guarantee ever more effective social control. We must build on our values, our principles and our rights, protect them and make them our strong point. That is why, in the long term, policies to prevent terrorism must be based on strengthening intercultural dialogue, education and social integration. In the immediate future, however, action must be taken where it is easier to radicalize terrorist networks, for example by controlling those anonymous communication systems for the Internet, the lair of the black market in arms and drugs.  Police cooperation and the exchange of information between Member States must be improved, as well as continuing to pursue the fight against all forms of financing of terrorist networks, so as to achieve their definitive dismantling.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, all your decisions have helped to disarm us, including morally, in the face of Islamist fundamentalism, for many years. I would like to touch on a subject that seems to me to have been completely ignored. To Italian journalists, the President of the Constituent Assembly of Libya, Ali Tarhouni, expressed great concern, and I quote: "Europe has seriously underestimated the possibility of militants infiltrating Lampedusa, Sicily or Malta. Risks are increasing at a dramatic rate." The reality is that the simple declaration of nationality, especially Syrian ones, the mere filing of a refugee file, obliges us today, in the light of the legislation, to accept and, moreover, to provide for populations of which we know absolutely nothing, on whom we have absolutely no information. We have even less information because we have severed relations with Syrian intelligence, which was a serious source of visibility on fundamentalists. The Italian Foreign Minister made the same statement and retracted his remarks under the pressure of the intellectual terrorism of well-thinking. We are abused and we are spoiled by reassuring words, we make angelism. The reality is that we have no means in this case to guard against these kinds of risks, except to find, in particular, our national borders.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE). -
text: Aħna ninsabu maħsuda b'dak li seħħ ftit aktar minn 24 siegħa beauty fil-lukanda Corinthia fil-Libja. Kellna attakk terroristi ieħor b'nies maqtula li spi大大aw vittmi innoikeenti. Dan l-attakk terroristik fil-Libja segwa l-attakki li saru fi Franza li jmorru oltre minn attakki orribbli fuq individwi. Dawn kienu attakki fuq il-valuri u l-libertajiet li l-Ewropa hija mibnija fuqhom. Aħna qed niffa大大jaw sfidi ta' sigurtà li huma mingħajr pre大edent. name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D). -
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, in recent days it seems to me that the debate has progressed a little on one thing: this fight against terrorism implies a balance between the need to ensure the security of the Union and its citizens, and to guarantee, on the other hand, respect for fundamental freedoms and rights. I believe that we have also made progress on the idea that the fight against terrorism is far from being reduced to a technical issue that is part of the security logic alone. Radicalisation is a multifaceted, evolutionary and multidimensional phenomenon, developing both within and outside the Union. The European response must, therefore, favour a cross-cutting, comprehensive, long-term approach and require a multiplicity of actors. Among the areas of action to be developed, I want to support the ideas already mentioned, such as improving the exchange of information between Member States and with EU agencies - Europol, Eurojust - and improving the implementation of the effectiveness of the Schengen information system, combating the financing of terrorism and the trade in illegal firearms, or optimising the full potential of the internet in terms of raising awareness of everything effectively. In this panel of actions, the social and cultural dimension of the fight against terrorism must not be cosmetic or declarative, but generate concrete actions on the ground. Let us not forget that radicalization often arises from disarray and lack of prospects. Finally, let us not fall into the trap that is set for us. The current debate deserves not to be treated with emotion and haste with, on the one hand, the emergency workers and, on the other, the homeopaths. If no one is defending the status quo, we must act with reflection, based in particular on an accurate assessment of the existing European tools and their implementation.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the We are discussing the fight against terrorism today, and we must answer one question: how much freedom do we want to give up for greater security? In all interventions in freedom, the less freedom is always guaranteed, never the greater security. A liberal society will always remain vulnerable. Perhaps a totalitarian society can be made totally safe, but a liberal one? We are discussing or have already introduced biometric passports, video surveillance, telephone surveillance, data retention, restricting cash transactions, lifting banking secrecy, banning the encryption of communications. The citizen is already glassy today, and if you ask me, much too glass. If I have to choose between freedom and security, I choose freedom.

name: Cecilia Wikström (ALDE). -
text: Thank you, Mr President, i.e. the european Parliament and Since the Paris attacks about three weeks ago, we are all once again in a state of deep sorrow. This calls on us to now act together: both to guarantee the security of citizens and to preserve open society with respect for fundamental rights and human privacy. Terrorists know no national borders, we know that. That is why it is now high time for us, through the EU's law enforcement authorities, to understand this, and to act just as effectively and preferably a little more effectively than terrorists and criminal networks can do. Since we know that the main problem is to exchange information between The Member States, this is what we need to address. We need to create a complete intelligence service and we need to strengthen cooperation between law enforcement agencies on threats and exchange information on people and networks planning to carry out horrific attacks. We owe this to our citizens, and nothing but this is accepted. Both openness and security – at the same time.

name: Judith Sargentini (Verts/ALE). -
text: Of course we are concerned that European Jihadis are fighting with the IS in Iraq and Syria. Let us not forget: the executioner of the IS is a Briton! We call him Jihadi John. It is understandable that we are concerned about attacks here in Europe, and I am doing the same. But we also have to be very concerned about what Jihadi John and his friends are doing in Syria and in Iraq. I do not understand that if we reject it, if we think: what should we do about this, in the meantime all our European heads of government do not know how quickly they have to travel to Saudi Arabia to pay their respects to the late king. Saudi Arabia! The country that helps finance terrorism, the country that has such barbaric practices as the IS, the country that does not shy away from giving people batons, chopping off hands and feet, handing out death sentences. Ladies and gentlemen, that must be the beginning of our anti-terrorism policy!

name: Kristina Winberg (EFDD). -
text: Thank you, Mr President, i.e. the european Parliament and It has been claimed from some quarters that terrorism and radicalisation are due to poverty and non-existent chances of finding jobs for young people. In that case, Greece, with a youth unemployment rate of over 50%, should surely be swarmed by IS fighters and Boko Haram supporters. Yet we have not seen a single suicide bomber in Athens, and no terrorist attacks in a very long time. So what does Greece have instead? Low immigration, a common national identity and the sense to express their displeasure by going to the polls and electing a new government. Study after study has shown that foreign terrorists generally have higher education and higher incomes than the average in the countries they come from. What is the lowest common denominator of terrorists with the anti-Semitism we saw in Paris? An intense hatred of the West and its new home countries and an extreme interpretation and confession to Islam. One may be able to access a few things through labour market policy programmes, exit programmes, integration measures, etc., but in the long run we have to realise that there are very many people with a significant capacity to harm us, both within and outside the EU, who simply do not see the world in the same way but want to maintain an Islamic caliphate with all their souls under strict Sharia law.

name: Diane Dodds (NI). -
text: Mr President, firstly allow me to express my personal sympathy and that of my constituents in Northern Ireland following the recent abhorrent attacks and loss of life. Today, we stand with communities in France and in northern Nigeria, and indeed with those from the Jewish community experiencing the awful rise of anti-Semitism. As a Member of this Parliament from Northern Ireland, I know all too well how the threat and the out-workings of terrorism can have devastating consequences, not only for the victims and their families, but also for a nation’s consciousness. In Northern Ireland we are privileged to have committed police and armed forces, and today as we assess anti-terrorism measures across Europe, Member States must ensure that their forces are given all the necessary resources to succeed in this fight against terror. The Charlie Hebdo rallies in Paris and across France show a resilience of character that says the bullet and bomb will not prevail. Such resilience of character was also evident in my community as the IRA waged a campaign of terror. We held similar rallies after the Enniskillen bomb, after the Omagh bomb and other atrocities and, while the IRA was defeated, sadly for many justice still evades them and those scarred by terrorist activities. Today’s debate is about stopping terrorism, but every day we in this House must focus on the rights and needs of victims of terrorism.

name: Agustín Díaz de Mera García Consuegra (PPE). -
text: Mr President, I begin with a quote from the spokesman for the Bagdadi (it is from before yesterday): "Any Muslim with the capacity to shed a drop of blood from the Crusaders, who does so. Did you see what a simple Muslim did with Canada and its parliament of slackers and what our brothers in France, Australia and Belgium did? May Allah have mercy on all of them. What comes next will be worse and more bitter." Before yesterday. This is the threat, it is an unequivocal, current, permanent and sustained threat in time and lethally fulfilled. And the answer? Are we here for the answer? I don't know. The answer has to come from prevention, detection, persecution and repression. It has to come hand in hand with all that catalogue of performances that have been shown here. Yesterday I made a dictionary, a dictionary of measures and objectives, in the field of freedoms and in the field of repression, prevention, research and prosecution. Relations with Turkey, Canada, Australia and the United States need to be improved. Our external borders must be improved, the trafficking of firearms and explosives must be neutralized. All this we can do, we have to do it with the force of reason and with the reason of force. We have the right to defend and the obligation to defend our citizens and we also have primary law, which gives guarantee and vitality to the legal rule we give ourselves. We're stronger but more vulnerable. Either we react soon, or soon, soon, we will attend, along with sterile debates, more minutes of silence and more solidarity demonstrations.

name: Jörg Leichtfried (S&D). -
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for his You said in your speech that security is a guarantee for democratic societies – that is right, and terrorists are attacking that security. But terrorists are also attacking other fundamental elements of democratic societies, namely freedom, the rule of law. In all the measures that need to be taken, it must be borne in mind time and again that this balance between security and the preservation of our freedom, the preservation of our rule of law, is an incredibly difficult one. If you now believe that we need more data – I am not sure that this is necessary – and if you believe that we need passenger data agreements, passenger data directives, then you must propose one, Commissioner, one that is in line with the decisions of the European Court of Justice, in accordance with fundamental rights. Then we can discuss it. I am still not sure that this is necessary. In recent events, it was not the case that there was not enough data, there were too few police officers who evaluated this data and too few police officers on the street. Perhaps we should discuss this once. 15, 20 years of austerity have in fact ruined our police, and they are no longer able to respond. We also need to discuss this. Perhaps they need more money and not more surveillance of those who are innocent anyway. Ladies and gentlemen, we really need to be careful about this. The Socialist Group is in favour of sensible actions to prevent terrorism, but it is not in favour of blind actionism, which is of no use and which is increasingly restricting our freedom and dismantling our rule of law. To those members who are now calling for border controls, i.e. border controls have not prevented these attacks, but they may have prevented this man from coming to Paris, who saved these six people. We should also think about this, whether that would have made sense.

name: Helga Stevens (ECR). -
text: In southern Europe, only marginal security checks are carried out on incoming refugees with papers. But undocumented refugees are screened differently. Some EU citizens also pose a security risk. I am thinking, for example, of returning combatants.  There is therefore a need for more frequent, targeted but not systematic checks at Europe's external borders. I have the impression that, for example, the external border with Turkey is in practice far too porous. In order to address this, common risk indicators need to be developed as a first step. For me, these are absolutely priorities that are not yet sufficiently addressed.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have to tell you the truth: unfortunately, I have heard a little bit from our Commissioner. I would also have liked to have heard a little self-criticism because, I believe that, if what is happening is happening, it is partly the fault of the European institutions as well. I would like, for example, to hear something about what Europe has done in past years with regard to Libya, Iraq, or even what it has done recently with regard to Syria or what it has not done, for example, with regard to countries such as Saudi Arabia, which is certainly not one of the most tolerant countries in the world. It is a failure of Europe, a failure of integration policies: we cannot think that integration consists in allowing someone to come here to Europe and say or do what they want. When there are people in Europe who say that they want to apply Sharia law, these people simply need to be expelled. It is also a failure of immigration policies: it is news yesterday that Isis, from Libya, says that it wants to infiltrate terrorists who will then arrive, perhaps with boats, through illegal immigration, into Europe. We therefore need stricter border controls and, above all, for those illegal immigrants who are there to be repatriated.

name: Michał Boni (PPE). -
text: Mr President, Europe needs security which means it needs stronger counterterrorism actions and the new policy. It is important to avoid losing time at the political stage so the idea of a pact on counterterrorism among key political groups in Parliament is very much expected. I want to emphasise some points. One: we should start common work with the Commission on the renewal of the European internal security strategy. We need clear pillars for this strategy, a holistic approach and a fast track. Two: it is important that work starts again on PNR as a common framework for 28 Member States, taking fully into account personal data protection, responding to the problem of retention indicated by the Court, based on real evidence of how this solution could be effective and ensure that those data which are really needed are processed. Three: we need fast work on the NIS Directive. It is important for strengthening cooperation among Member States. The key point is to have useful cooperation among all the institutions which can contribute in the area of anti-terrorism actions (also responsible for the security of our external borders). Four: we need proper legislation, adjusted to the terrorism challenges but which on the other hand protects differentiation in cultural, ethnic and religious views. Also with respect to privacy and encryptions by default in devices. This is the key goal – to finalise work on the whole privacy package. Five: the last point, we need a good balance between freedom and security. Freedom and security are the two sides of the same face of the European citizen.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D). -
text: Mr President, like the Commissioner, I will be going to Riga at 5 p.m. to have the honour of representing Parliament in the negotiations. Listening to some of the contrasting views, it might be thought that this will be a very difficult task. In fact, I would suggest it is not as difficult as colleagues would think. The chair of my political group and other colleagues have actually said that if, notwithstanding the views of Mr Albrecht, they believe that PNR is something which can be justified by the Commissioner, that PNR is not objectionable in principle, in terms of proportionality and necessity, and that we have the requisite safeguards – with, as Ms Hohlmeier said, actual solidarity, and the civil liberties that my colleague Ms Sippel talked about – then together we can achieve this. However, I would say to the Commissioner, on behalf of the Parliament and of my own group, that we have to build trust. The way to do this is to point out that PNR is not the only component of this strategy and road map against terrorism. This is about radicalisation and about Europol getting all the necessary leads against terrorism, as the Commissioner said. Fighting terrorism is about the causes of terrorism, and it is about a whole range of things – as many speakers have said today – because, if it is not about these things, then we cannot unite here in Parliament against terrorism, which is such a complex issue. We should unite but we should not fool our public by pretending this is not a complex issue. We should work together with the Commission and the Council, in a sophisticated and compassionate way, to achieve our objectives while safeguarding civil liberties and ensuring that component is taken seriously in the Council meetings. I hope my colleagues will help us and help, with the Council and the Commission, in these discussions.

name: Anders Primdahl Vistisen (ECR). -
text: Mr President! When you hear both the debate that was held at the LIBE Committee this week and the debate that some of your colleagues are having in this Chamber, you get the impression that you are sitting in a cheese bell in this House, completely ignoring the very sensible arrangements that the governments of the Member States want - the very sensible arrangements that a large proportion of the citizens of Europe want. You run yourself up to some principles that sound good and which must also be taken into account - that is, the fact that you do not register too much, the consideration of how to register - but you do it in such a fundamentalist way that you keep obstructing the protection of 10 and proper anti-terrorism protection in Europe.  If it continues in this way, then It is clearly my impression that governments should simply continue bypassing this Parliament. The main point must be to protect European citizens, not to protect the vanity of some members of this Parliament who want to block the PNR for any reason.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI). -
text: Mr. President! Whenever there is a threat of terrorism on our continent, or unfortunately it has now unfortunately found concrete expression, the same pattern of reaction on your part is always to be observed: they call for the erosion of fundamental civil rights and they call for the implementation of even more surveillance technologies. I wonder how many more phones do you want to monitor, how much more Internet traffic do you want to monitor, how much more biometric data do you want to suck up? They must finally have their foreheads and the courage to say that the danger comes from a very clear direction, and that is Islamism. We must also set the right political response patterns here. It must be made clear that immigration from the Islamic sphere should be stopped as much as possible in the future, because immigration from the Islamic sphere means that it is used as a vehicle for political Islamism. In the area of asylum, it must be made clear that asylum care must take place on the continent of those who seek protection and help, as the German Minister of the Interior, Mr de Maiziére, has also called for. And we must also make it clear to everyone who has come to us that our continent is one based on Christian and Western roots, and that everyone who has problems with it should go back to their continent of origin.  Ladies and gentlemen, I call for a zero-tolerance policy against all political extremism and religious fundamentalism, and I call for you to finally look this issue boldly and honestly in the eye and take the right action, rather than just talking about it.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to say that, in the light of what the Commissioner has also said – namely the risk that making so many statements that are not followed up by action will increase public mistrust – it is almost difficult to speak on this issue. The eyes will be on the Riga meeting, just as they will also focus on the informal meeting of heads of state and government.  I believe that we need concrete action. I do not want to repeat the measures to which my colleagues have already referred. I very much appreciated what Mrs Hohlmeier said. I think what we need, all of us here, is to leave our ideologies at home, to stop being either "goodists" or "alarmists." We must get close to our citizens, who are currently receiving a flood of information, even dissonant and conflicting information, which is increasing the alarm. Because, for example, in my country a foreign minister first says that there is the possibility of infiltration through immigration, then he denies it; but then comes – as Marine Le Pen also mentioned – the alarm from Libya. We know that Libya, the territory from which that tide of desperate people starts, is increasingly in the hands of Isis and we cannot tolerate our citizens – and I am speaking to you in particular on behalf of my fellow citizens who are the Italians – feeling in the trenches, feeling at the forefront and seeing that we continue to get lost in chatter, we continue to filter reality through more or less ideological visions while they absolutely need us to speed up the concrete measures that exist. and above all that we overcome that lack of trust that exists between States and, sometimes, between different bodies of law enforcement, that we also overcome those jealousies and envies that are blocking a system already in place, to which we must give breath and strength because I believe that security is one of the main rights of a citizen and certainly one of the main duties. I even believe that this is the raison d'er of a state, one of the main reasons why states exist. I therefore rely on you, Commissioner, to give real concrete form to words.

name: Geoffrey Van Orden (ECR). -
text: Mr President, I wonder what scale of atrocity it would take before all Members of this Parliament understand that strong security measures, exercised with proper oversight by our democratically-elected governments – possibly assisted in limited areas by the European Union – are necessary to combat a serious terrorist threat. I must say that I am astonished by some of the views that have been expressed today. In relation to the terrible terrorist attacks in Paris, one of our colleagues remarked that the perpetrators were known. So what would he have done? I suspect he would be the last person that would see the logical conclusion from what he has just said, and that is that all these suspects should be locked up. That would be the conclusion from what he has just said.  In these times of heightened terrorist threat our intelligence and security services need the ability to penetrate the black hole that parts of the Internet have become and to identify the patterns of behaviour that might enable terrorists to be identified. We need PNR, but it is just one of many measures that need to be taken.  Let us also, by the way, avoid exploiting yet another crisis in order just to give the EU more powers and competence. It is about being effective in our Member States.

name: Marcel de Graaff (NI). -
text: Western Europe is suffering from terror, attacks, murders, rapes. Jihadists and arms dealers travel freely in the European Union. Turkey, Saudi Arabia and Quatar pay imams to preach hate. In European madrassas, children are being trained to war against the infidels, against European values, against us, against you and me. Our citizens are fed up. They take to the streets en masse in Milan, in Dresden and in Paris. And what is the European Commission doing? It advocates more immigration from Muslim countries, more immigration from backward cultures, more Turkey. Enough is enough! Schengen must stop, immigration must stop, Islamisation must stop. Jihadists out, hate preachers out, terrorists out! I demand that the European Commission immediately stop immigration and restore internal borders.

name: Axel Voss (PPE). -
text: Mr. President! Europe needs a new anti-terrorist strategy and also an improved strategy for internal security, because the current state of affairs cannot reassure those threats, and the Commission and you, Mr Arramopoulos, are on the right track. We should also show the victims and bereaved people and our citizens that we are capable of responding to this, and we should also react decisively to it, otherwise we have already lost. Some of us – and this really excites me in this debate – simply do not want to take note of some of the realities. Our freedoms are reason enough for the terrorists to kill us. And if you want to see everyone on the tombstones now. But your data was safe, then it doesn't reassure anyone! Of course, we need a balance between security and freedom here in this area. But this also requires the political will to get this, and perhaps we should also take note of the fact that the experts have been telling us for four years that we are getting special insights from passenger data that cannot be gained from other data. The rapporteur has made enormous efforts over these years and has come to look after you, and perhaps we should just start taking political responsibility.  If we are always talking about actionism here – I would be glad if you were to take action at all, instead of always being against everything – we have been puzzled about it for four years and better coordination is just such a point. In the NSA report of March last year, we proposed that intelligence should also be coordinated accordingly. It was rejected by you! Perhaps we can take this one step further. Thank you very much.

name: Gerolf Annemans (NI). -
text: As a Fleming and therefore for the time being as a national of the Belgian kingdom, I would like to apologise to all the victims of Islamist terrorism. Belgium has been specifically threatened by IS in a Youtube video today with car bombs and beheadings, along with France. Belgium is called "the little sister" of France, bad enough. Koulibaly's weapons, from the Kouachi brothers, were bought here two kilometres away, in the district of the Brussels south station. Several terrorist cells have been on belgian territory in recent days. There is a link between this terrorism and the way in which immigration has gone here in Belgium, the immigration policy of the socialist parties, for decades, of Belgium. And from their political allies, who are opening up the borders of this country. For years, handing over Belgian papers without setting conditions and imposing restrictions has given birth to a monster. I repeat: I apologise in their place to all the victims of terrorism.

name: Presidente. -
text: (Addressing Mr Buonanno, who asked to be allowed to speak on a point of order) Mr Buonanno, please show respect for the House. Tell me which rule of the Rules of Procedure you are referring to.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I refer to Rule 186 of the Rules of Procedure: the point of order. In the absence of Mrs Mogherini, I would like to highlight this very important issue, because we are at war with Islamic terrorism. I'm dressed as a soldier to remind you, because you sleep on your feet. This issue must be addressed in Strasbourg, holding a special sitting for a whole day. I would therefore ask for a point of order with Mrs Mogherini present. I ask you, Mr President, why you are not talking about much more difficult issues than the days and about such important issues. ... this is the Europe of 'standing sleep'.

name: Presidente. -
text: I fully understood the point of order, Mr McClearly, and this is a matter that must be raised by the groups at the meetings of the Presidency.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI). -
text: Mr President, excuse me, always talk about hot air, that's the serious thing. Mr President, there is no point in being president and then being ... (The President withdrew the speaker)

name: Teresa Jiménez-Becerril Barrio (PPE). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the day after tomorrow marks a new anniversary of the murder of my brother and his wife at the hands of the terrorist organisation ETA. A few weeks ago three terrorists sowed terror in Paris killing twelve innocents and terrorizing millions of Europeans. My brother was killed by nationalist fanatics; journalists, religious fanatics. I tell everyone that there is no land or god worth the life of an innocent person. That is why today I speak not only as a victim of terrorism, but as a European citizen and defending those who have the right to live without fear. We need a coherent and continuous, non-intermittent terrorist policy that acts only under the emotional wave, but when we remove the sticker we return to the hypocritical indifference. And yes, of course I am a part of the PNR, and to have it already, because the urgency, gentlemen, is not at odds with the responsibility of protecting our citizens. It is enough to face terrorism ideologically, because those who kill us care nothing if we are right-wing, left-wing, green, GUE, socialist or popular. If they, the dead, could speak, I'm sure they'd ask us to come together and stand up for the most important of all rights, which is the right to life. Because without the right to life we cannot exercise any of the others, nor the most important, which is freedom and for which all the victims of terrorism have died.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I hope that the Commissioner has very clear ideas. Because at the beginning I was optimistic, when I felt the intention to find a union between us, between the political forces, a union of this Europe, since terrorism is inspired, draws its life and food, precisely through our divisions. On the one hand, we hear talk of the possibility of closing borders, of abandoning Schengen, and then returning to a feudal state. On the other hand, there is talk of drive Islamists out of Europe, but they are already in Europe. Three people were enough. They are called "lone wolves", to create what happened: three people. So let us agree, even if we have the necessary differences on the measures! Again, the European PNR. But pnr some want it, others less so, others say no to PNR among European countries. But neither does the Data Protection Supervisor. So it's important to have one voice, one voice to fight a difficult battle. I have heard of tolerance – that is absolutely right – but not reciprocity. The Islamists also want to be able to build mosques but they destroy our churches. So, reciprocity and respect.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D). -
text: Mr President, why do we keep talking about foreign fighters and not recognise that the main threat is indeed home-grown, coming from EU nationals such as those who carried out attacks in Madrid, in London, in Brussels and lately in Paris. Why do Member States, instead of waving PNR as a magic bullet, not adequately finance national information and security services and those at EU level, namely Europol, Eurojust, Frontex, in order to equip them with expertise in Arabic and other language skills, as well as in human intelligence to monitor social media, to draw up shared lists of terrorism suspects, spend resources on targeted instead of mass surveillance, on protecting critical infrastructure and on fighting effectively cybercrime and financing of terrorism?  Why do Member States and the EU tolerate the proliferation of competing services and crisis centres, even at EU level as well as at national level, which compete with each other instead of cooperating and sharing information? Why do they not invest in a single crisis and information centre at EU level to serve all the EU institutions and communicate with Member States? And of course, instead of the austerity that fosters social disintegration, why do they not finance programmes to prevent radicalisation and de-radicalise the young people from our communities who are being drawn into these horrendous activities?

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR). -
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking In the face of a phenomenon such as terrorism, it is necessary to act in a coherent and rapid manner. Ms Hohlmeier called for consistency, but I have the impression that unity was broken very quickly. If we take seriously the voices of the left, the greens, it is very clear that 'we do not want new instruments to fight terrorism', and more intelligently and softly the Socialists say this, Mr Verhofstadt was also moving in the same direction. But what worries me even more is the tortoise pace of Commissioner Avramopoulos – the announcement that in May we will only have a programme to fight terrorism, that then the programme agenda will definitely be shaped, that is, an extremely slow pace. Nor can the formula be repeated all the time: 'we want an effective fight and we want respect for fundamental rights'. Concrete instruments need to be shown, and I hope that the Commissioner will speed up the calendar in the last word, secondly, he will say this much more specifically than at the beginning.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE). -
text: Mr President, yes to security to protect the integrity of European citizenship and to security that guarantees fundamental rights, with measures in line with our democratic standards. The first anti-challenge tool we face is intelligence. We need coordination of objectives and information at European level and efficient use of all technical and human resources. And nothing less intelligent than taking advantage of the journey to subtract, marginalize competent institutions in the field and willing to add. Nothing worse than file freedoms. Ideas do not delinquen, delinquery radicality, which makes them instruments of hatred against the other. And let's not forget that betting on peace includes eliminating the social fracture in which extremism has its best breeding ground.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL). -
text: Prevention and the firm fight against terrorism can never be a pretext for imposing security measures, limiting citizens' freedoms, rights and guarantees, as we have already seen with the Patriot Act. We will also not accept judicial cooperation measures in criminal matters that call into question constitutionally and democratically enshrined principles by the peoples of each country. Measures to combat terrorist financing must be adopted, coming from offshore, from the sale of energy resources and also measures to combat arms trafficking and, to say: terrorism is always terrorism, in any corner of the world. The European Union and other forces cannot support and fund organisations that are linked to al-Quaeda and the Islamic State and then want to fight them when they are at our homes and terrorism happens in Paris, as it is practiced in the occupied territories of Palestine or through the drones that the United States uses to fight defenseless populations. It's terrorism everywhere.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Avramopoulos, on the one hand, we have this demand for security; on the other hand, we have civil rights and freedoms. When these two things are balanced, there is a risk that, in the name of the danger of terrorism, civil gains will be called into question, the achievement of which has taken so many years. So let us look historically at what has happened every time such a danger has been put in the way: let us be careful not to question important civil liberties. Mr Albrecht is right to say that the instruments already exist and should be better used. For example, in the field of security, there is little cooperation between the secret services of the individual Member States. We try to exchange information and act better from this point of view, instead of summoning a monster and risking taking steps backwards. I cannot understand the meaning of what Mrs Le Pen said when she said that she was restoring borders and, I do not know, redoing the colonialist policy of a hundred years ago. Let us try to understand that the world has changed and that there can be no turning back on certain achievements, just as Schengen cannot be called into question.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI). -
text: Everyone with a heart is shocked that terrorism causes innocent people to die.
