But anyone who uses their heart and mind at the same time also understands that it is very possible to take advantage of people's natural fear of terrorism to introduce measures that increasingly take away people's freedom and rights and give control over citizens to a small, opaque, uncontrollable group with enormous power – we obviously do not want that.  Let us not forget that in the spirit of the war on terror or the war on terrorism, the Western world has introduced total control over internet communications, eavesdropping. In this spirit, prisoners are still being tortured at Guantánamo without a judge's decision and without charge. In this spirit, two unjust and unjustified wars were launched, resulting in the deaths of hundreds of thousands of civilians. All these measures have not prevented it, but made it even more dangerous... (The President has withdrawn the floor from the Member.)

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE). -
text: Mr President, the global nature of recent terrorist violence demands that we redouble our efforts to provide a genuine area of security, and that we integrate the internal and external aspects of the fight against terrorism. Many of the instruments have already been put in place, and in such cases we need only to consolidate or better apply rules, or to exercise trust among Member States. A European security policy would probably have more respect for the rule of law and fundamental rights principles than the current patchwork of individual Member State solutions. Fighting for more security should never jeopardise the other objectives of freedom and justice. This is what must always differentiate us from the people we try to protect ourselves from. However, all security policy measures must go hand in hand with introspection as to the causes of radicalisation and with an effort to develop more social cohesion and inclusiveness in our societies.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D). -
text: Mr President, I would like to join those who in this debate have reminded us that the enemy is not Islam, but the criminal fanaticism of those who are willing to kill and die killing and those who remember that the bloodiest terrorist attack of recent years was not perpetrated by a Muslim: his name was Anders Breivik and he was a far-right racist full of hatred against Islam and against religious and identity pluralism. I also join those who recall that the battle, which must ensure a balance between freedom and security, cannot be fought by betraying the DNA of the European Union, which is respect for fundamental rights and fundamentally the privacy of Europeans and those who also remind us that the battle includes the struggle for values, social exclusion and marginality , in which psychotic fanaticism nests. And finally, of course, I also add to those who remember the importance of legislating against hate speech, because in Spanish criminal law we have managed to distinguish freedom of expression from the enlating of terrorism, the glorification of terrorism, the apology of terrorism and the humiliation of victims.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR). -
text: There is no doubt that Islamic bigotry and radicalism is the biggest challenge facing Western civilization right now. Undoubtedly, this religion is seen as politics, and its inspirations draw and follow a single political goal – to take over the whole world on behalf of their point of view. We have two choices, either to resist or to lose this fight. But this struggle is not fought by declarations, dear Mr President and colleagues. This struggle can only be fought with a strong state, with borders, with intelligence, with national security. What we can and should do as the European Parliament is to use our political instruments. And one policy instrument, Commissioner, is to impose sanctions on a country that supports terrorism, such as Turkey; a country using European funds; a country organising trafficking in human beings; a country that funds, organizes and treats ISIS or ISIL fighters, or whatever you want to call them; neighbouring countries such as Bulgaria and Greece by transferring dozens of illegal migrants. That's what we can do and that's what we need to do and these sanctions should be asked of you.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE). -
text: Mr President, we are not in ordinary times. The internal and external threat is real and that is why the political will must be expressed quickly. Europe must demonstrate its ability to act within the natural framework of its rule of law.  Of course, we need to improve intelligence sharing, strengthen siS and Europol, and implement an intelligent European NPP. Similarly, it is necessary to decide to systematically control the air, sea and land borders of Schengen to show that Schengen is effective. Similarly, Eurojust will have to be strengthened and why not? To have a European prosecutor.  Finally, in the long term, we will have to have a real strategy for our prisons, which are all too often, in many Member States, a school for crime and terrorism.  We will also have to have a responsible foreign policy, I am thinking in particular of Turkey. We need to rethink - why not? Temporary visa policy.  Finally, we will have to make progress on the Europe of defence. Let's do all this together, so we'll show that we're finally up to the challenge.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, honourable Members, first of all allow me to express my thanks to all of you for your contributions to this very interesting and important debate. In the face of the monstrous attacks this month, and in responding to the ongoing threat of terrorist attacks, Europe must remain strong and united in its response. Do not have any doubt that the Commission will do its part to support the response at EU level, and we will work hand in hand with Parliament and, obviously, with Member States in our common goal of keeping Europe open and secure.  On EU PNR, since many Members of this Parliament referred to that, I want to clarify once again that our position remains unchanged. The Commission is committed to working together with the co-legislators to achieve a legal instrument which is both effective and fully in line with fundamental rights. We are very carefully assessing all options regarding how the Commission can best help the European Union legislators to reach a quick and effective result on the EU PNR proposal. Allow me to thank the rapporteur, Mr Kirkhope, for the work he is currently doing. We will be next to him.  On the implementation of existing measures: this is indeed a priority for us. The Commission is expecting responses by 15 March from all Member States. On Schengen now: yes, I agree with Mr Verhofstadt. Schengen is not a problem, it is part of the solution, and I explained in my opening remarks how we need to make the maximum use of the existing possibilities, and the best use of this tool. I would like to thank you again for this very timely debate. I have received one important message out of this which is that we should be united; work together here, but also with all the institutions. The Commission is committed to working with you for the benefit of all citizens, to defend their rights and their security, to work with you in trust and in unity.

name: Presidente. -
text: The debate is closed, the vote will take place at the next part-session. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. – I am disappointed to hear references in today's debate to the European Arrest Warrant, a pernicious piece of legislation which allows UK citizens to be extradited without the case ever being heard by a British court to weigh up whether the evidence is sufficient to warrant extradition. Even more disturbingly, the British Conservative Party chose to opt back into this legislation when it had the opportunity to do so and stifled the Westminster Parliament in the process. We need strong national security and borders to counter terrorism; let us by all means share best practice with our European neighbours but security must be sovereign.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. – The terrorist attacks in Paris have been a painful reminder to the whole of Europe that we have lived too long, believing in deceptive security, and have ignored the signals that have already been a form of extreme violence and destruction today. Already in 2003. The European Security Strategy has identified major security challenges such as terrorism, regional conflicts , organised crime, but the roots of today's terrorism stem from decades of societal change, both in our society and in the inability to find lasting solutions to peace and stability, especially in the conflicting Arab countries. If, more than a decade ago, we talked about the threat of terrorism from third countries, then today we are facing an even more complex problem when terrorist attacks are carried out by our citizens born and raised in the EU. I believe that the issue of security must be looked at in a complex way and in a review of actions in the areas of migration policy, external border protection and organised crime. I hope that the Member States and europe as a whole take the security threats seriously, and that there will be a political will to make difficult decisions, but unavoidable for security.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. Your statement in order to fight terrorism at European level seems to be just a new artifice with "measures" in order to look good after the tragic events that have affected France. Perhaps the Commission could also accompany its measures with a "stop-jihadism" website such as the one recently created by the French government, which is absurd in the face of this threat? Unfortunately, she almost managed to get close to it, since in her statement, the European Union's possibilities for "fighting hate speech" were mentioned. It is obvious that this will solve the security problems at European level... This sad observation of powerlessness in the face of terrorism is only the result of years of lax policies on the part of the European Union and most of the governments of the Member States, including my own, France, which prefer to hide their faces. Only a proactive policy will make the situation clearly resolved. Good intentions will not suffice, we must now stop the accession of new countries to the European Union, notably Turkey or the Balkan countries, or suspend the Schengen agreements immediately. Finally, there is an urgent need to establish, as is practiced in the United States, a screening of passenger data records (PNR).

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The Paris attacks proved once again that Europe is the target of organized terrorist groups. Young people from our countries go abroad, to troubled regions, where they are trained in combat by extremist movements, and then they come back to strike Europe in the heart. The answer to terrorism is the unity and solidarity of Europeans and not withdrawal or individualism as some advocate. The solution lies in Europe. We need to set up a European NRL. Socialists need to understand that our citizens need to feel safe. We need to rethink Schengen in light of recent events. We have an obligation to improve surveillance at the Union's borders. To do this, we need to increase Frontex's financial resources. Cooperation between police forces and cooperation between Member States are the directions to follow. But above all, we must educate our young people about European values so that, from an early age, they are not tempted by speeches advocating hatred and destruction.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. We cannot hide this: the threat of terrorism in Europe is serious and the Community institutions can only respond firmly. However, I believe that, after the events in Paris, the term that must accompany THE EU's action must be: 'balance'. Balance between the need to implement immediate action and the obligation to think about long-term solutions; the balance between data collection, the use of intelligence tools and the right to privacy, but above all the balance between security and freedom, the two pillars on which our democracy is based. Let us therefore speed up the debate on the directive on the exchange of PNR data, but also ensure that European citizens are guaranteed the protection of their personal information. We must step up our control over the movement of foreign fighters, but without restricting European freedoms, starting with the closure of the borders opened by Schengen. We cannot accept that the terrorist threat should enclose the European model of society and the values associated with it. Finally, it is crucial for the Eu ropean Union to have a common security policy, involving a total sharing of information between the 28 Member States, which is crucial if we are to be able to start talking about real European intelligence.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. – It offers me no doubt that we must combat terrorism that threatens innocent citizens and seeks to undermine our values and our societies. But in doing so, we must reject simplistic readings and demagogic political discourses. It is not true that terrorism can be associated with emigration. Some of the terrorists, as we have seen now in Paris, but have seen in the past in Spain and Ireland, are European citizens. It is not true that we need new instruments and new laws, undermining the privacy of Europeans. What we have to do is take advantage of the tools we already have, optimising judicial and police cooperation (including the sharing of information produced by the secret services), being effective in combating arms trafficking and implementing the new Schengen Evaluation System without delay. We need to identify the problems and solve them. To call for more security measures and diminish freedoms is to cede victory to terrorists. It is reprehensible and we cannot fail to condemn the forms of politics that exploit fear and the feeling of insecurity.

name: Tanja Fajon (S&D)
text: Writing. – The events in Paris have shocked Europe and the world. People are scared, they expect action. We must ensure security, but not at the cost of the security of our freedoms. Our societies must remain open, free. The response to the threats of terrorism in Europe must not be fear or disproportionate security measures, and the answer must be to strengthen values such as freedom, democracy, solidarity. We Europeans must fight all forms of extremism shoulder to shoulder. European governments must not lose their judgment. We must not introduce mass surveillance of air passenger name records (EU PNR) without proper analysis. We would like to know what the data retention conditions will be, who will use it and in what cases. We do not have prejudice, but we need a guarantee on data protection and the privacy of Europeans. EU Member States make too little use of existing instruments. We need to make more use of these, such as the Schengen Information System, rather than introducing new ones. We need to strengthen cooperation between The European judicial authorities, the exchange of information, we need intelligence services that work together. The Socialists and Democrats will not agree to change the Schengen rules and restrict freedom of movement. Nor will we allow restrictions on freedom online. In Europe, we must ensure respect for fundamental rights and the rule of law, and focus the debate on education, the deradicalisation of young people in Europe and the peaceful coexistence of different cultures and religions.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: in writing. – The tragic events of Paris, Verviers and, more recently, those of the Corinthia Hotel have once again put us before the need to find an answer to prevent and combat terrorism, radicalism and the new challenge of homegrown terrorists. These combats and the strengthening of security are not merely confined to the borders of the Member States. These are cross-border problems that require joint solutions based on mutual trust. We cannot, however, misstate our objectives by legislating to hot on the basis of emotion. We must assess the content and effectiveness of the instruments we already have and promote their full implementation before considering their amendment. These heinous acts attack human lives, but also against the founding principles of the Union: respect for life, the defence of freedom, but also solidarity for all those who, for economic and political reasons, seek refuge on our borders. I conclude by reminding you that today we are celebrating European data protection day, world privacy day. It is our obligation to ensure that the loss of rights, such as privacy, is not seen as inevitable. The collection and sharing of information necessary for the prevention and repression of terrorism must be qualitative and not quantitative!

name: Eugen Freund (S&D)
text: Writing. – The most important thing in the fight against extremism and terrorism is to identify the causes of this and to act on them. We have seen terrorist attacks in Europe on several occasions and in many countries, which we have managed to get a grip on. The Italians will remember the brigate rosse's struggle against the political establishment in their country, the Germans of the Red Army faction, who also found many victims beyond the actual target persons, then economic, banking and industrial captains. In Spain, ETA has struck, in Northern Ireland there have been decades of conflict, which have been sold to us as a religious war, but which in reality had social dimensions. And that is exactly where we need to start again now. The perpetrators are not primarily radical Islamists, but people excluded from society who have found no recognition, no social integration, in the country in which they grew up. Appropriate training and jobs that are satisfying thereafter take the wind out of the sails of extremism. And then the European Union must also do more diplomatically to reduce the hotspots on the fringes of Europe – all these measures form the basis for better integration – and that is what we must work towards.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: In writing. Considering the recent and abominable terrorist attacks in Paris, other terrorist actions in Europe, the numerous attempts to carry out terrorist attacks in Europe foiled by the security and intelligence agencies of the Member States of the European Union, it may be time for the EU institutions to analyse the possibility of setting up a European Union counter-terrorism intelligence service. I know that there is always a reluctance on the part of some countries of the Union to follow such a project, but Europe is under attack and we must respond appropriately, in order to protect our citizens, our institutions, our values, our freedom, the freedom to think, to speak, to act, to write, as we see fit. The first step towards achieving such a project should be the creation of a special intelligence department that integrates the intelligence services of Member States, the United States, and other partners, so that our security institutions act at the appropriate time, to counter possible terrorist attacks in Europe. A body to better share relevant information with the European Union and with the intelligence of other states and security bodies. I invite you to analyse and work on these proposals, in the interest of our citizens.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. The Terrorist Attack in Paris shook the whole of Europe, to which interior ministers reacted immediately, holding an extraordinary meeting in the days after the attack. I see it as important that the most important things to do have been identified: the treatment of foreign fighters, the fight against radicalisation, the strengthening of cooperation and exchange of information between the competent Member State and international authorities. I also believe that security at the external borders should be strengthened, while respecting the maintenance of smooth border traffic, fundamental freedoms and safety standards. At the same time, these steps should not jeopardise one of the most important elements of the ACQUIS, freedom of movement, the functioning of the Schengen system. We need joint action, we need a coherent response to terrorism. They must not be allowed to increr hatred, to increranate fear, to create division in our society. This includes countering radicalisation. There is concern and therefore the increasing use of the Internet to increment hatred and violence – the partnership of the largest internet service providers is essential. Addressing the causes of youth radicalisation is challenging. The events in Paris have also confirmed the urgent need for Europe to provide police training to respond rapidly to these challenges, which cannot be combined with Europol, the Police Office in The Hague. I am currently working as parliament's responsible for the report on the functioning of CEPOL to ensure that this important institution is regulated on a sound basis in the future.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The tragic events of three weeks ago in Paris and the attempted attacks in Belgium show that citizens of the European Union cannot feel safe in their countries. That is why we must now take action to ensure an effective fight against terrorism. At present, we do not have rules at EU level that allow the use of passenger data. Such a directive can help in the fight against terrorist organisations, provided that it ensures the highest standards of protection of personal data. EU citizens have the right to know who, for what purpose and for how long their data will be stored. Of course, finding the right balance between the security of our citizens and the freedom of the individual will not be easy, but I am convinced that it is possible. I am very pleased that this report has ended up in the hands of my Fellow European Conservatives and Reformists, Mr Kirkhope. I think that together we are able to restore our citizens to a sense of security.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. Whether they are the victims of the Paris attacks, the martyred Eastern Christians or the beheaded hostages, whether They are French, English, American or Japanese, it is to all humanity that radical Islam has declared war. It is a lasting threat, extremely violent, highly organised and which today takes on multiple faces, especially those of young men and women, born and raised in Europe, and capable of killing other Europeans. Thus, there is an urgent need to act in a methodical and relentless manner to eradicate Islamist terrorism within the Union itself, but also in the world. Every Member State must make the fight against terrorism a priority. We need to strengthen our intelligence cooperation, set up a European NRL, reform the Schengen area to improve border controls and put in place a European plan to combat gun trafficking. We must also fight against the apologies of jihad on the Internet and urgently evaluate our tools for preventing radicalisation. Finally, we must engage in joint, strong and coordinated external action, particularly at the military level, to combat the Islamic State and Al Qaeda.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE)
text: in writing. – The underlying point now is that we cannot wait any longer to put in place adequate counter-terrorism measures. The EPP Group has always stressed the need for a Passenger Name Record (PNR) system and has emphasised that need in its strategy for counter-terrorism, as presented on 28 January 2015. Credit card and telecoms companies are already obliged by law to keep their data for up to six months. Why should it be different when it comes to PNR data? Up to this point, the EU has focused on securing data protection and privacy, leaving security aside. The deteriorating security situation and the radicalisation around us are clear proof that privacy and security have to complement one another. Preventing radicalisation and terrorist attacks should be the core aim. There should be close cooperation with social network companies to restrict access to terrorist material online and remove any terrorist propaganda. One effect of such action would be to help curb hate speech, and that needs to be addressed in laws across Europe. Cutting off the means of propaganda alone is not enough: tracking down and disabling the financing of terrorism is another important pillar. We need a terrorist finance tracking system. To back up the establishment of an EU black list of European jihadists and terrorism suspects, we need to put in place an EU smart border system and to cooperate closely with third countries.

name: Gabrielius Landsbergis (PPE)
text: Writing. – This year has begun with particularly serious shocks to the international community: terrorist attacks in Paris, the ongoing war in Ukraine, brutal, not unlike the attacks on civilians in Mariupol, which are known as terrorist acts. The world order and the distribution of powers are constantly being tested by new challenges. Western democratic values are still not acceptable to aggressors, on what basis they would base their attacks – religiously, nationally or any other – these are crimes against humanity that cannot continue. I agree that the Council, the Commission, the Member States need to exchange information, conduct consultations on counter-terrorism measures with interested parties. However, I would like to point out that anti-terrorist measures must be taken today not only after the attacks in Paris, but also after the attacks in Mariupol. Terrorism is more close than ever , inside and at the borders of the EU, and it is more painful than ever to admit that there is a constant war with an unpredictable aggressor in Ukraine today, and the People of Ukraine have been fighting hard for their country every day since November 2013. So, summing up, with deep compassion not only I say "Je Suis Charlie", but also "Je Suis Mariuopol", "Je Suis Valnovakha".

name: Светослав Христов Малинов (PPE)
text: in writing. – At a time when we are talking about cross-border crime, radicalisation, international terrorist networks, security cannot be limited to the national state. European countries must therefore come together towards optimal implementation of the community's available cooperation instruments in this field and, where appropriate, introduce new ones. The rights and freedoms of citizens are the foundation of the European Union. However, when the right to life is threatened, all other rights and freedoms become quite illusory. I don't think we have much room for discussion right now. Today, we see that mistakes have been made in the past in the right direction of providing more security for our citizens. I am strongly for a common named register of passenger registration data; a proposal which, in the previous term of the European Parliament, was rejected by the votes of the Left and liberals. There needs to be cooperation with ISPs, especially when it comes to frankly radical sites that are members of terrorist organisations. Last but not least, along with immediate measures, let us not forget that the best way to counter extremism is to promote democratic values through civic education. Only this will ensure that we do not allow people prone to violence and terrorism to grow inside the European Union.

name: Luigi Morgano (S&D)
text: in writing. The tragic events in Paris have shown not only how fragile our democracies are, but how, in the face of the real threat of Islamic terrorism, Europe and the Member States must equip themselves with more effective intelligence tools. The solution to combating terrorism is not to close borders, to suspend Schengen, as some populist leaders have mentioned in recent weeks. On the contrary, we need to strengthen the Schengen information system, cooperation between police forces and strengthen Europol and Eurojust. It is necessary to establish measures that, under the control of the judicial authority, make it possible to monitor those European 'fighters' returning from death training camps; we must be able to obscure the 'captivating' jihadist sites that with alarming ease recruit many, too many young people, not just those belonging to pockets of social distress and marginalisation. Commitment on the cultural, educational and social aspects is therefore essential. The adoption of the Passenger Name Record (PNR) Directive for passenger registration on flights in the Schengen area may also be a necessary measure, but it is imperative to strike the right balance between security and adequate respect for privacy. Only a unified response at EU level can be truly effective in combating terrorism.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: Writing. – The unequivocal condemnation of the criminal attacks in Paris must be accompanied by the basic criterion for the search for the objectives and objectives of these actions, i.e. who benefits from them. The EU institutions and the political forces of the capital in the European Parliament hide that the so-called "jihadists" are the creation of the US, the EU and their allies, who equipped, strengthened, organised and used them as a strike force in their imperialist interventions and planning in the wider Region of the South-Eastern Mediterranean. Now, as in similar cases in the past, they are methodically exploiting the jihadists, as the convenient pretext, to promote even greater intensity of repression and its mechanisms, the main objective of which is to strike the labour-popular movement and its action. The JRC is fundamentally opposed to this whole web of repression and, of course, to new measures to strengthen it, such as the generalised file and the monitoring of everything, the plans to create an EU secret service, the strengthening of secret services and repressive mechanisms, the restriction and abolition of basic popular freedoms and democratic rights. The JRC condemns the adoption of measures for an even more savage hunt for migrants and refugees through the 'smart border' mechanisms of Schengen, the Dublin II and III Regulations.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. Needless to say, our citizens expect their governments and the European Union to guarantee their security. They expect concrete and effective responses against fundamentalist terrorism, which will defeat imminent actions but at the same time go to the root of the problem. The murderers who sowed terror in Paris, like the suspects arrested in Belgium and Germany, are all people born and raised in Europe, who have attended our schools. We cannot, therefore, ignore taking measures that act where there is poverty, ghettoisation, ignorance and lack of rights. On the other hand, the exchange of information between our intelligence services and our magistrates is essential to prevent further attacks, as well as a stronger common foreign policy. We can, of course, discuss pnr reform, but this must certainly be done without questioning fundamental principles such as personal freedom and privacy. It is also natural to strengthen controls at the external borders of the Schengen area which, contrary to what populists and xenophobic people say, is not the problem but the solution, if used in a spirit of cooperation between the Member States.

name: Емил Радев (PPE)
text: in writing. – Following the terrorist attacks in France, a number of proposals have been discussed to improve cooperation at European and international level in the fight against terrorism. The truth is that this will not be the only attack of this kind in Europe and all Member States, including Bulgaria, must be ready to prevent many others. Bulgaria's proximity to the conflict in Syria, as well as the fact that hundreds of Europeans are passing through Bulgarian territory to join Islamic State, is reason enough for the Bulgarian services to work even harder to prevent terrorist attacks. They must actively participate in the European counter-terrorism cooperation networks and continue to carry out enhanced controls along the Bulgarian-Turkish border. At the same time, other Member States need to provide more information about people suspected of crossing from Bulgaria to Turkey on their way to Syria so that the Bulgarian services can have a complete picture of the passenger flow across our southern border. I believe that the French citizen arrested on suspicion of terrorism is a positive example of European cooperation. The fight against terrorism is a continuous process that requires constant effort and it is our duty to win it for the sake of European and Bulgarian security.

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D)
text: In writing. The attacks in France have led to a real public outburst in Europe in defence of our common values. In the face of terrorist activities on our continent, our response can only be European, cross-cutting and integrated, to ensure the right to security of people in full respect of fundamental freedoms. The fight against radicalization, with its multiple and complex causes, will require more education, more social inclusion. We must also move forward on other key areas: improving the exchange of information between Member States, thanks to the possibilities of the Schengen information system. The adoption of the European NRL, which will help improve the monitoring of European jihadi candidates, by offering more guarantees for the protection of fundamental rights. The proper application of the Schengen rules, thanks to more effective controls at the external borders. The development of an alternative message and awareness of terrorist propaganda, while targeting more hate speech circulating on the Internet. But also the development of a real common foreign policy for Europe. At all times, we must remain united and united, defending both our freedoms and our security, which together contribute in an essential way to the proper functioning of our democracy.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. – In the current situation of heightened security risks, it is certainly right to look consistently at finding ways to increase the security of EU citizens. In the context of Schengen cooperation, I believe that the effective use of all the cooperation instruments currently available to all Member States in the area of justice and home affairs should be ensured. The solution is certainly not to dismantle the Schengen area, but rather to use all the instruments that are part of Schengen cooperation. In this context, I therefore welcome the position of the PPE, which strongly supports the maintenance of the fundamental principles of Schengen.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. The brutal attacks carried out by terrorists have a shocking effect. In addition to the need to respond adequately to these attacks and to be genuinely effective , i.e. not just sham measures, it is important to remember that national police and national security services prevent many of these despicable acts. We, as elected representatives, must also draw attention to this. In addition, such acts also draw our attention to the importance of Police Training and Cooperation in Europe. It is clear that in the future the role of organisations such as CEPOL, which encourage cross-border cooperation in order to combat crime and maintain public security, law and order, should be strengthened in the future.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. – The terrorist attacks that took place some time ago in France have further heightened the fear of Europeans from attacks. The European Union uses a number of different mechanisms to fight terrorism. The question raised here, however, is whether these instruments are appropriate. At times, they seem to be somewhat outdated and thus no longer match the modern approaches used by terrorists. However, not all means are allowed to protect democracy and the citizens of Europe, especially those that interfere with human freedom in an excessive way. It is precisely because of the dilemma of what is proportionate and what excessive action is needed, we need clear commitments and rules to be adopted by the European Parliament. It is dangerous if we start to introduce measures that can no longer be controlled and are illegal. This is because we are destroying our own values, not terrorism. In the long term, we must be aware of the causes of the rise of terrorism, starting with dialogue, analysis of the situation and proper planning. In any case, the fight to prevent terrorism must also involve the planning of immigration policy, social inclusion and adequate information that can ensure preventive action. However, the whole thing must also be managed with a legal basis that prevents and limits abuses of the security and counter-terrorism protection system.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. – We all agree that terrorists do not know about national borders, and lately we have had an attack on fundamental human rights. A swift and united response from the European Union is expected. To achieve this requires solidarity between all European Union bodies and between Member States. We must respond fully, in a targeted and enforceable way, and we can only achieve this by building mutual trust.  Existing measures and laws should be implemented, but some new ones should also be introduced, of course constantly taking into account both freedom and security. This is not simple, but we must specifically opt for a passenger register on aircraft (PNR). Controversial though it is, we need it, but it's just one of the tools at your disposal. There is also a need for good cooperation with Europol, Eurojust and cooperation and coordination of intelligence services. Securing the external border of the Schengen zone needs to be stepped up and all activities coordinated with a clear timeframe. So far it has been shown to lack risk assessment, but so far it has been acted a posteriori which is not the best method.  Causes should be detected, intercultural dialogue should be established, but integration policy at the level of local communities should be improved. We all have cause for concern and we are all responsible, and we are obliged to find solutions so that our citizens do not live in fear and that Belgian soldiers do not keep us safe in this parliament building.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. Withdrawal of nationality is as populist as it is stupid. This is nothing more than a disempowerment, quite the opposite of the response to terrorism and intolerance! Last but not least, the withdrawal of nationality is as stupid as sending your child back to the orphanage at 16 because his behavior does not suit us... Belgium and the European police are thwarting a lot of attacks. They do not communicate much on this subject so as not to cause panic, but at the same time it is reassuring. In France, the senior head of the anti-terrorism unit was very clear: we do not need more data, we already have too much. We need more police. This is also my view: if we lose individual freedoms to security, we will lose both. And the abandonment of these individual freedoms in favour of so-called greater security is a victory for terrorists. What is needed, therefore, is not to reduce the number of police officers (under Sarkozy, the number of police have decreased five times in five years of five years) and to increase the exchange of information between The European police forces.

name: Indrek Tarand (Verts/ALE)
text: In writing. After the terrorist attacks in Paris, the European Union must show solidarity with France. These regrettable events remind us of the importance of intervention and prevention measures that ensure the safety of our citizens. The CSDP is an important part of these measures, and therefore cannot be overlooked. The current political climate underlines the need to develop the CSDP in order to reach its potential. The PSDC's under-equipment problem could be partly relieved by the two Mistral-class helicopter carriers whose sale to Russia has been suspended. Recent events clearly show that it would be irresponsible to provide these boats to a country that is supporting terrorist attacks against the citizens of its neighbouring country.

name: László Tőkés (PPE)
text: Writing. – Listening to Commissioner Dimitris Avramopoulos's unilateral proposal on counter-terrorism measures, I am seriously missed because he treats the whole complex issue as a matter of mere technical, professional and security policy, and accordingly his proposals for action do not extend beyond the scope of personal data protection and better exchange of information, adequate infrastructure or impeccable passenger records. However, confined to direct prevention and punishment of crime, he did not say a word about the social background and moral dimension of terrorism. By condemning the Paris attacks unconditionally and showing full sympathy for the victims, we must also see the role that our liberal social system and our misguided immigration policy play in the current situation, and that not only terrorists, but also our entire legislature and legal system, are seriously responsible for what has happened. The right to free expression must not constitute a free desecrating of the faith and human dignity of others. Freedom of movement must not mean unhindered freedom of movement of terrorists. On the other hand, freedom of conscience and religion are European values that cannot be in violation of the exercise of other freedoms. Consequently, there is a need for a legal settlement in Europe that not only penalises terrorist vigilantism, but also prevents desecration and blasphemy, in other words, the abuse of freedoms. It could also be an effective antidote and preventative tool for acts of terrorism against victims of their faith.

name: Traian Ungureanu (PPE)
text: in writing. – Maybe it is not surprising that the first thing one could hear after the attacks in Paris was a warning against our anti-Islamic response. This is already a media and political ritual. Each massacre is followed by appeals to calm, addressed to people who are portrayed as potential fanatics. The more innocent citizens pay with their lives, the more sophisticated excuses are produced for murder. This is simply a denial of reality. We should name names and know where the threat comes from. Reality cannot be supressed and eventually it will catch up with us. What I propose to the European Parliament is to defend European values by speaking the truth before it is too late. The massacre in Paris was followed by two huge rallies – one in Paris, the other in Grozny, the capital of Chechnya, where 500 000 people expressed their support for Islamism and rejected Western freedom of expression. The rally was described as spontaneous, but under Ramzan Kadyrov, the Chechen authorities are nothing more than a Putin puppet regime. The rally was organised with obvious Soviet-style choreography. It should remind the EU that Putin’s regime is using every form of overt and covert operation to undermine European values and unity.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The prevention and firm fight that must be fought against terrorism is not confused and cannot be a pretext for new waves of security measures, limiting citizens' freedoms, rights and guarantees. We believe that any ideas which are expressed at national or European Union level of moving towards exception laws which, like the infamous US Patriot Act, could result in the deprecation of fundamental rights should be rejected. We consider it essential to take serious combat mechanisms against terrorist financing, through offshore and less transparent practices involving states and financial institutions, as well as the adoption of mechanisms to combat the trafficking of arms, energy resources and raw materials that can revert to the benefit of terrorist organisations. The fight against terrorism implies the rejection of policies of interference, invasion, occupation and war which, as in the examples of Iraq, Syria or Libya, only lead to the emergence of terrorist groups. We also reiterate our conviction that the fight against terrorism cannot be seen as a fight between civilisations or between religions, nor give way to racist and xenophobic stigmatisations.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: in writing. – Mr President, it must be noted that we cannot address anti-terrorism measures without a broader European strategy for the security and stability of the region. In order to achieve our long-term goals, the instruments adopted must provide for both preventive measures and fast-reaction procedures. In particular, areas such as the monitoring of national counter-terrorism policies, the sharing of best practices among Member States and the reinforcement of our information exchange and of cooperation on criminal justice should be improved. We should also address the threat at its roots by preventing social exclusion and the growth of extremism, and by fighting relevant types of crime: corruption, drug, human and weapons trafficking and cybercrime. High-security issues such as terrorism transcend the distinction between internal and external security. Realising that means we must also improve the stability of our geopolitical surroundings through collaboration with a variety of state and non-state actors. Especially, we need to reinforce our cooperation with third-party states that might be incubators or logistics and transit bases for violent extremists. Moreover, our conflict-prevention tools must not neglect the promotion of human rights and democracy, external assistance in relation to governance, the rule of law, policing and law enforcement, and well-tailored aid.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. – Europe is still in shock after the terrorist attacks in Paris. I would like these events to serve as a sobering for a European security policy that is not effective. The security situation in the EU is further deteriorating due to Russian aggression in Ukraine and the uncertainty brought about by the victory of the extreme Syrians in Greece. The EU must respond to the deteriorated security situation immediately - comprehensively! 1. First of all, MS must strengthen its own security systems, ensure cooperation with other Members (such as the exchange of relevant intelligence); 2. At EU level, we need to strengthen common institutions (such as Eurojust and Europol) and activities (for example, control of external borders). We also need to round up the legal framework, including the PNR Directive. 3. Above all, we need a political counter-terrorism pact! We are relieving the situation for terrorists because they know that we are divided at this point. That's why I'm appealed for unity!

name: La Présidente. -
text: The agenda calls for debate on the council and Commission's statements on the European Fund for Strategic Investments (2015/2522 (RSP)).

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council. - Madam President, honourable Members, thank you for inviting the Council to participate in this very important debate on the EU fund for strategic investments. This issue has been a priority for all three EU institutions, which in itself is a very good starting point for further discussions. I am grateful for this opportunity to share my views on it. The Parliament has been instrumental in bringing the issue of investment to the forefront of the European agenda. Hence, I am particularly pleased to stand here today as we start working on the first concrete deliverable of the investment plan. The EU fund for strategic investments is a top priority for the Latvian Presidency and for the Council. It is essential that we strengthen economic growth and reduce unemployment in the EU. The investment package is designed to deliver on this dual goal, and it is of the utmost importance that the co-legislators work closely together and as quickly as possible. I find it useful to recall that President Juncker and the European Council have set an ambitious deadline. We count on Parliament’s support in achieving it. The current investment situation requires resolute and swift action. We want to see the first projects in place this year. The Council has already started examining the proposal in an ad hoc working party which is meeting very frequently. Two meetings took place last week and the next one is scheduled for tomorrow. We aim to produce a general approach by March to allow sufficient time to agree with Parliament well before the summer deadline. The Ecofin Council will keep a close eye on progress with this proposal, which will feature prominently on our agenda. In fact, the first intensive exchange of views on the proposal at ministerial level took place yesterday. I am confident that Parliament is willing to match our ambitions and I look forward to constructive cooperation. This is going to test our mutual commitment to boost Europe’s economic recovery. While the importance of the EU fund for strategic investments cannot be overestimated, it is only one part of the Commission’s investment plan – the so-called liquidity pillar, designed to mobilise finance for investment. The second pillar of the Commission’s plan, the project pipeline and the setting up of a European investment advisory hub, is also part of the current legislative proposal. By helping to identify well structured, reliable and viable projects, we ensure that the private sector participates and that the money is channelled to the real economy. So we must pay due attention to these measures accompanying the setting-up of the fund, as they will be key to the successful delivery of strategic projects across Europe. However, it is perhaps the third pillar – improving the investment environment – that will ultimately be the most important in terms of fostering private investments. This is a much broader issue that needs to be tackled at many different levels. From an EU perspective, it is a question of completing the single market. A number of measures have already been announced by the Commission, for instance under the banner of the capital market union. The Council stands ready to work together with Parliament and the Commission on all initiatives designed to enhance the single market and to improve the EU’s competitiveness. At the same time, action is also needed at national level to remove any barriers to investments and unlock the growth potential throughout the EU. We therefore look forward to the Commission’s proposals and initiatives in these areas. The investment plan is fully in line with the priorities of the Latvian Presidency in the field of economic policy and competitiveness. As you know, the plan is not designed to solve every single problem in the euro area or the European Union – from macroeconomic shocks to deflation, energy security and local authorities’ debt problems – but it is a step in the right direction and, most importantly, it has been designed in the most flexible way so that it can grow. Structural reforms, fiscal responsibility and investment are the three keys to restoring growth and creating jobs. In other words, investment is only one ingredient in the mix. We should not forget the others: structural reforms and fiscal prudence. To tackle the challenges ahead, we – Parliament, the Council and the Commission – must work together quickly and efficiently to ensure that the legislative package delivers the needed boost in the economy.

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. - Madam President, it is always a pleasure to be in the European Parliament to talk about big issues, as we are doing today. I would also like to thank the Latvian Presidency for the excellent job it is doing in putting the investment plan very high on the agenda. Less than two months after announcing its ambitious strategy to boost jobs and growth, the Commission has presented a draft law to set up the European fund for strategic investments (EFSI). We are delivering quite fast. This fund goes to the heart of the EU investment offensive: the drive to get funds flowing back into the parts of our economy where they are needed most and to stimulate job creation. We have also proposed creating a transparent pipeline for projects and setting up a European investment advisory hub to make sure public and private promoters get the technical assistance they need to develop viable projects that can benefit from this funding.  In line with the objectives of our plan, each of these measures will remove uncertainty in order to mobilise much-needed private investment. For Member States we are providing certainty by clarifying how the new entity will be governed, how Member States’ contributions will be treated under the Stability and Growth Pact (SGP) and how projects can best be developed to have a tangible impact on growth and jobs. For private entities we are providing certainty with a legal text explaining the legal form and governance of the European Fund for Strategic Investments, with enhanced technical assistance, and by establishing transparency in relation to the project pipeline. We are moving fast and I am counting on you for very strong political support so that we can have the European Fund for Strategic Investments up and running in the first half of this year. The timetable is very ambitious. Council negotiations kicked off on 19 January 2015 in an ad hoc working group established for the investment plan for Europe. It is important that work in Parliament should start as soon as possible too. We count on the co-legislators to agree on the text by June so that the EFSI can be operational by mid-2015. Since we are moving very fast it is important to take the time to explain very clearly what we are doing. I want to look in particular at SGP treatment, governance and some other details. Regarding SGP treatment, the Commission will treat favourably Member States’ contributions to EFSI investment under the SGP. The EFSI will be open to contributions from Member States directly or through national promotional banks. Member States can also contribute at the level of different projects. Contributions in the form of capital and guarantees to the EFSI will not be counted when assessing the fiscal adjustment. Co-financing with EFSI projects or investment platforms will be eligible under the revamped investment clause. Regarding governance, we foresee a two-tier governance structure. This governance structure has been specifically designed to allow the fund to remove more uncertainty for investors taking on project tranches that present a higher risk than those covered by normal EIB instruments. This is a key point because, to add value, the EFSI must be able to support projects with a higher risk profile in order to get investment flowing in the countries and sectors of our economy where it is needed most. In practice, a Steering Board will define the EFSI investment guidelines. These guidelines will set out the risk profile of the fund and the criteria for the selection of projects. The Steering Board will consist of representatives from the EFSI partners, i.e. the Commission and the EIB, and, in the future, any third-party entity that might participate in the EFSI capital, subject to the agreement of its partners. As long as the only contributors to the EFSI are the European Union and the EIB, all decisions in the Steering Board shall be taken by consensus. An investment committee made up of six independent experts will take the decisions on project selection. Projects will be selected on the basis of merit and the investment guidelines laid down by the steering committee. Investors tell us that this independent selection of projects based on merit is critical if we want private sector financing to come in. The investment guidelines defining the criteria for project selection will be adopted by the EFSI Steering Board once the EFSI regulation has been adopted, but the basic criteria are already clear now. Projects under this initiative will need firstly to be economically viable with the support of the initiative, secondly to be sufficiently mature to be appraised on a global or local basis, and thirdly to be of European added value and/or consistent with EU policy priorities such as the Europe 2020 strategy for smart, inclusive and sustainable growth, the 2030 Climate and Energy Package and other long-term EU strategic priorities. The proposal states that the EFSI should target projects with a higher risk-return profile than existing EIB and Union instruments in order to ensure additionality with existing operations. The EFSI should be used only where financing is not available from other sources on reasonable terms. The EFSI will be fully accountable to Parliament. The monitoring is structured around two key principles of which the first is reporting. The EIB will report semi-annually to the Commission and annually to Parliament and the Council on EIB financing and investment operations under the regulation. The reports will be made public. The Commission will also report to Parliament on the application of the regulation. On accountability, Parliament will have the right to organise, at any time, hearings with the managing director of the EFSI on the performance of the fund. The managing director will also have a legal obligation to reply swiftly, orally or in writing, to questions from Parliament. In addition, Parliament can request reporting by the Commission. The proposal presented today must be complemented by a series of measures to remove barriers to investment and to create a true single market. To me this is the most important part of the investment plan. It is the way to change Europe structurally and permanently in the right direction and to open up new investment opportunities. On this, a set of actions is outlined in the Commission’s 2015 work programme. The Commission will come forward with further proposals on the energy union, the digital single market, the capital market union and an internal market strategy for goods and services in the course of this year. We look forward to working with you on this matter. Finally, I want to signal that, while there are a lot of technical details in the plans presented today – and we rightly need to discuss those and get them right – it is important never to lose sight of the big picture and of what it is all for. The crisis of confidence is holding back the investment flows that are the lifeblood of the European economy. Taken as a whole, these new measures should restore investor confidence and get investment flowing into the regions and sectors of our economy where job creation is needed most. The urgency is very real at political level because the needs are very great on the ground. I look forward to working hand in hand with this House so that we adopt these proposals as soon as possible and have a meaningful impact on Europe’s investment.

name: Manfred Weber
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Mr Vice-President, representatives of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. Thank you for the presentation of Jyrki Katainen. The Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats welcomes the European Commission's proposal for the Growth Pact, for the investment package at European level. I also believe that the framework conditions are set in the right way: not debt-financed investments, but money raised in the private market to create jobs in Europe. That is the right way to go. That is why I would like to thank you for the speed with which we have worked on and also for the good proposals. My fellow Members will discuss the details from the PPE-DE's point of view later. I would like to combine this proposal today with a second development which will characterise the economic situation in the European Union and will also mark the next debates politically, namely what we saw on Sunday with the Greek elections. First of all, I would like to point out that, in our view, the relaunch of Europe initiated by the new Greek Prime Minister will certainly not be achieved by him, but is made through proposals such as those presented today by Jyrki Katainen, namely the investment package. The ILO, the International Labour Organisation, today published figures that this investment fund can create more than 2.1 million new jobs in the European Union. A huge boost for the European Union is expected from experts who stand out in this area. I mentioned Greece because I believe that much of what we want to do is in danger for investment, for economic power in Europe, for this vote and for the formation of a government last Sunday. For example, if the new Greek Prime Minister, Tsipras, now announces that he wants a bail-out, in other words, that debts should not be repaid, then I ask you: how are we to get private investors to join the fund when, at the same time, European politicians say: we are not paying back our debts? What does this have to do with solidarity? What does it have to do with solidarity if, with a bail-out, that is, with a debt cut in Greece, countries such as Cyprus would have to pay EUR 100 million, countries such as Italy would have to pay EUR 10 billion, countries such as Spain would have to pay EUR 6.6 billion and Ireland would have to pay EUR 347 million? A bail-out means that all other European states would have to pay for the Greek debt. Is it in solidarity that Spain, Italy and Cyprus are liable for Greek debts? Does this lead to stability? I do not believe that this will lead to stability; I believe that it will lead to instability in Europe. The election promises made, with more than 11 billion euros of new spending in Greece, do not lead to investors gaining confidence in that country. We have the hope, and even the request, that the successes – that Greece today has a balanced budget, that Greece has growth today, also a difficult situation, but growth – that these successes will not be risked now. I do not want to talk about radical left forces gathering in the government with right-wing forces, of making common cause with right-wing populists. I would also like to remind our Socialist friends that not a single woman has been hired as a minister in the new government; only men are active in the new government. What this has to do with gender balance is something that surprises me a lot. I am referring to this in this discussion on the investment fund, because such political developments are the far greater danger to the question of whether we are getting economic development. Anyone who looks at developments in Europe today will find that we have growth of 3.6% in Ireland, 2.6% in Latvia, we created a million new jobs in Spain last year – in all the countries where we have PPE-DE governments, where there is sensible governance and where investments are being made in the future, we have growth and positive development prospects. We in the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats will continue along this path. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr Weber, of course you welcome the 315 billion investment package, which I do not think is a great surprise! You say it is not a debt-financed investment. I find this astonishing, because that is exactly what it is: we go in with public funds, we pump up the 60 billion through loans and thus motivate private investment. This is certainly debt-financed. Secondly, if it is right that your dream of two million new jobs should be created by EUR 315 billion, why do we not double or triple them, then we have solved unemployment!

name: Manfred Weber (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. It is wonderful that the honourable Member is able to describe the problems. It would be good, however, if the populists in this House were to contribute to solutions. The proposal that is on the table is a proposal that will not increase the debt level in Europe. We will finance these investments from the normal budget and we will invite private investors. For someone who thinks economically, this is the best way to attract private investors to invest in the European economy. That is why Jyrki Katainen's proposal is the right one.

name: Maria João Rodrigues
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, we will certainly have the opportunity to draw implications from what has happened recently in Greece but one thing for sure is that we need a joint programme with Greece, run by the European institutions – the Commission, the Council, Parliament – based on fiscal responsibility but certainly restoring real progress and a real prospect for growth and jobs in Greece. This is the right answer to be provided. But for that we need investment, and that is why our debate today is relevant and we have a full sense of urgency. That is why I need to say to you, Commissioner, on behalf of our group, that we are really worried by the very slow build-up of the European Fund for Strategic Investment. We are, in fact, very worried that Member States are not so far making capital pledges for the Fund and we know very well that this stronger capital base for the Fund is fundamental to enable the Fund to increase its lending capacity; so this is a critical point, and this is not going well. We know very well that the EU budget guarantee and the EU contribution is not enough, and we are also worried in particular that Minister Schäuble recently dismissed Germanyʼs intention to make a national contribution, so this is a bad signal. I would say that we need to overcome this obstacle. Europe needs a massive investment project adapted to the needs of the real economy and that is why we need to make sure that all Member States, including those which are in excessive deficit procedure, can contribute. I hope you can deliver by the next euro area summit.

name: Syed Kamall
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, the ECR welcomes the fact that the Commission wants to narrow the investment gap in Europe. But I often speak to investors who have money to invest, but are scared off by red tape and see other parts of the world as far more attractive. So I think we need to recognise that this Fund will not be a silver bullet. In fact probably the most important part of the proposal is not the Fund itself but a so-called third pillar. What we need to do is cut red tape and bring down those barriers to investment.  Let me give you one example. I currently lend to entrepreneurs around the world via a successful American peer-to-peer lending platform. This platform tells me that they want to come to Europe but they are worried that EU legislation would not allow their business to succeed. So the true test of success here is not how many roads are built or how many pipelines are laid, but it is how many entrepreneurs will get financing and create sustainable jobs. And once they start their businesses, we need to make sure that EU legislation does not shut them down. Since the beginning of the year, digital businesses now have to pay VAT in the country of the customer rather than the country of sale. Now we know that this law was aimed at the big businesses such as Amazon which sell via low tax countries, but this one-size-fits-all legislation is also shutting down microenterprises selling digital products such as eBooks, online designs, or online knitting patterns for example. They cannot afford to check on customers in 28 Member States. There is no VAT threshold and if they refuse to sell to customers in other EU countries they are now being told that they may be breaking EU anti-discrimination laws. So they are damned if they do and they are damned if they don’t. So what do they do? They close down.  So by all means let us speak in this House about helping SMEs, by all means let us talk about a digital single market, by all means let us talk about these investment programmes, but, if we are at all serious, let us rip away the red tape that is harming businesses today, here and now. Until we do that, no amount of investment will close the gap. The songwriter Bob Dylan once asked, ‘How roads must a man walk down?’ but let me ask how many investors have to leave the EU before we remove the barriers? How many microbusinesses have to close down before we solve the VAT MOSS problem? How many people have to be unemployed before we open the markets? I fear, as Bob Dylan would say today, ‘The answer, my friend, is blowing in the wind. The answer is blowing in the wind’.

name: Pavel Telička
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, first of all let me assure Vice-President Katainen and the Minister that my group does consider the investment plan to be a big issue, as they have said themselves. In fact I would even say, Vice-President Katainen, Madam Minister, that you are partly or already on the road for one reason: I think that you are raising expectations in the correct way because the three pillars on which the plan is based are exactly the pillars that businesses are expecting. It is a question of regaining confidence. It is a question of confidence that the EU institutions are able to address the real issues with real instruments in a proper way. We are raising expectations. We are not halfway but we are on the way and I think it makes it even more important to deliver. Vice-President Katainen has mentioned that he considers the pillar on the internal market to be even more important. I would tend to agree. I think that this is really the case. You will remember, Mr Katainen, the interaction we had in our group on one issue on which we partly disagree. I was looking for a conditionality in terms of structural reforms. You explained that you found it perhaps burdensome, that it has to be simple. I would say that maybe there are ways to make it simple, not only in concrete projects but in general vis-à-vis that specific Member State. But let us leave that to one side. I understand this has not been taken on board.  I would make a different point alongside what you have just said. If the EU is coming with an investment plan, I would expect the Commission to try at least to impose on the individual Member States their own national investment plans. You are now getting a certain amount of input. Different projects are being proposed. I have seen some of the lists. Some are more encouraging, some are less so. I have confidence that people who know what economic viability is will make the right choice. But I would be much more confident if, in the framework of these submissions, we were to see concrete issues addressed by the national administrations in terms of completing their own bit of the internal market. Enforcing the legislation: the Commission knows very well where and on what issues individual Member States are failing. Better regulation, administrative burden. As Mr Kamall is a true liberal I can agree with him that cutting red tape is an important issue. I have been in business for the last nine years and when I speak to business people they name it number one. Once again, I can imagine that, in the framework of the national investment plan or whatever this document will be called, you can demand concrete steps be taken. Two remarks to finish with. First, I would have expected somewhat more from the Latvian Presidency in terms of what we were presented with today. I would have expected you to say not only that there were meetings – there was a meeting on Monday – but what happened at the meetings. What is the commitment of the Member States? What is the message? What do you want to leave with us here in Parliament? Otherwise we know it is important and we know that meetings are taking place. Second, I wish you the best of luck. We will provide the support but we want to see the delivery, also on the two pillars vis-à-vis the Member States.

name: Δημήτριος Παπαδημούλης
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr Weber, I understand your bitterness because your friend, Mr Samaras, lost the elections in Greece. But this is democracy and I advise you to leave the alarmism and distortion of the positions of the Greek Government. Greek citizens voted against a catastrophic austerity, which brought a huge recession, huge unemployment, huge poverty and unfair burden-sharing because your rich friends in Greece, under the responsibility of your political friends, do not pay taxes.  And the end of one-sided austerity is hope for the whole of Europe. And we say here in the European Parliament that it is time, as Mr Draghi said: 'I will do 'whatever it takes' to protect the euro', and that the Commission and the Council do 'whatever it takes' to bring investment and growth in the place of disastrous austerity, strengthening and with public resources the inadequate Juncker package and with input from the Member States and the Council and with investment allocation criteria, so that investment goes to countries suffering from greater disinvestment, from higher unemployment, from greater poverty. What happened in Greece on Sunday – and fortunately the Commission and the Council, unlike Mr Weber – opens a window of hope for the Peoples of Europe.  (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a blue card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr Weber has just said that Greece has experienced the solidarity of the eurozone. Do you agree with me that this solidarity has not reached the Greek people, that the Greek people have suffered from the consequences of the euro rescue policy, that unemployment has risen to alarmingly high levels, that youth unemployment has been the same, that the solidarity of the euro area has been applied solely to the creditors and, in particular, to the banks and financial institutions?

name: Δημήτριος Παπαδημούλης (GUE/NGL)
text: "blue card" answer. Mr Lucke, Mr Weber's friends, New Democracy and PASOK have been punished for what you describe. But the solution, Mr Lucke, is not the return of Greece to the drachma, as you propose, because then the German taxpayers will also lose their money. The solution is a shift of both Greece and the entire eurozone to growth with justice and with major reforms against the client state, against tax evasion, against corruption that for forty years New Democracy and PASOK built in Greece.

name: Bas Eickhout
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. I would like to talk again about the investment plan and perhaps keep the discussion on Greece until later. First of all, I would like to thank the Commission very much for the investment plan. Now there is finally room for investment after years of continued focus on austerity and further cuts. However, if we look at the investment plan now, we do have three fundamental objections and problems with the current proposals and we would like a response from the Commission, from Commissioner Katainen on that. First of all, too little democratic control. However, the plans state that this investment plan should also contribute to the EU's overall objectives. But that's far too unclear. If we now look at where the money is being taken from, namely part of the European budget, does that mean that an investment plan with a new steering board will be put in place? But the big question is: what exactly are these plans going to look like? As far as we are concerned, it is crucial that the European Parliament is fully involved in the co-legislation, that we can decide on the rules of expenditure. Secondly, too little regard for the public interest. If you look at the list that the various Member States have submitted, it goes in all directions, but millions are certainly going to coal-fired power stations, millions to nuclear power stations. The Antwerp ring is being taken off again, while we know how much that is a problem in Belgium, in Flanders. I see my Flemish colleague agreeing. So, how are we going to make sure that this kind of spending is really there for the public interest and not just private spending? Thirdly, briefly, it is too little to get the European economy going. Not enough thought has been given to new revenues, such as lost revenue from tax avoidance. Why is that kind of new revenue not used for this package?

name: Steven Woolfe
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, I recognise that Mr Katainen is one of the Commissioners who seems to have an understanding and sense of the real dire economic situation that Europe and the eurozone are in. I welcome that. After the crash of 2008, the eurozone is the only region in the world that is not growing. The impacts on its people are severe – unemployment, suicides, austerity impacting everybody – and we see that only more significantly in Greece. Mr Katainen, well-meaning people are coming to try and find solutions, but the solution you are seeking with the Strategic Investment Fund is not the correct solution. In a desperate desire to match the growth and success of the United States, academics across Europe came up with a false solution: that of the euro. They worked hard on it. They pontificated on it. They held seminars on the euro. If only you could recognise that it is the euro that is causing the problem, and that relieving yourself of the euro would mean that you would not have to try and spend EUR 20 billion to create EUR 315 billion.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI). -
text: Madam President, why do European monopolies welcome the Juncker investment package and quantitative easing, Draghi? But because it serves only their own interests in the context of the expansionary management of the capitalist economy. These are two forms of government subsidies with billions to boost private investment, which people will again pay as debt with new unpopular measures. The union's diverse defenders, who are flocking to support this mix, hide their basic condition: further reduction of what they call labour costs, reforms of wage and insurance systems to boost private investment, i.e. 'haircut' of popular incomes, transfer of taxation from employers to workers, generalisation of flexible working. These will be voted on in the next period as the European Semester. It is a development for monopolies and not for the people, who must not fall into the trap, but must be organised, fight back on the basis of their own interests, their own needs.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE). -
text: Madam President, Commissioner, Madam President of the Council, we can only support, of course, the Commission's proposals, because we need an important stimulus to get out of this European crisis.  The Commission understands that there is an urgent need for this situation and is now making a proposal for this Fund.  In the Commissioner's proposals, I note that it is important that Parliament has a place in monitoring the management of this Fund.
