We agree with the priorities that are expressed on this future Fund, we also agree on the establishment of a governance mode, a process of project selection, which is meant to be transparent, and it is necessary if we want to bring in investors.  However, we will have to seduce investors and do everything to reduce bureaucracy, to make investors want to come to Europe. A good signal would be to do everything possible to keep our technological progress, which would otherwise be extremely dangerous, because it would jeopardise European industry and our chance for growth.  So, in that case, what I fear is that we are getting to the Horizon 2020 program, which we so desperately need, that we negotiated hard here in Parliament a few months ago.  I conclude, Madam President, by telling the Council that the responsibility of the Member States is great, because we know that they are the ones who are dragging their feet to participate in this Fund on their own budget.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D). -
text: Madam President, Madam Minister, Commissioner, first of all thank you for your presentation. I wanted to tell you that I do not agree with those who denounce a trick of Mr Juncker's prestidigitator that would take 315 billion out of his hat, but I still think that if we called a spade a spade, we would gain clarity and credibility, because this plan is the recognition of the indispensable public investment in Europe. , this guarantee on the UNION budget is the basis of a Community loan that does not say its name. It is a pity, because it is this fund based on public action that will restore confidence to private investors. The Commission is therefore making a first step towards what we socialists and democrats have been calling for since the beginning of the crisis, namely the intervention of public investment. Unfortunately, it is not 300 billion over three years that Europe needs, but 300 billion euros of additional investment each year, and to achieve this, Member States will have to mobilise and seize this new instrument through projects, of course, but above all by contributing to this Fund. And to encourage them to do so, the Commission has presented a new interpretation of the flexibility of the Stability Pact. In the Council, Madam Minister, to keep the promise, which had hithert remained a dead letter, of boosting investment, growth and employment. However, there are still many governance issues related to our objectives. First, the viability of the projects presented by the Commission as a central criterion for the selection of projects, and for most of them, is an excellent thing. However, Article 5 (i) of the Regulation refers to education and training projects that are eligible for this Fund. How are we going to calculate that sustainability? How will very long-term investment projects, which are the seeds of a sustainable and socially inclusive model, be evaluated? How will the employment objective be taken into account when choosing projects? For if the Council and the Commission swear by the independence of the EIB in the selection of projects, how will the experts on the investment committee take macroeconomic issues into account? I will stop there, Madam President. Just a few enumerations such as youth employment, energy transition, etc. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, regulation))

name: Michael Theurer (ALDE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mrs Thomas, you have said that you are calling for billions of dollars in annual programmes to be implemented through public investment, but you are not saying how you intend to finance this, nor are you saying that, for example.B quantitative easing in the United Kingdom or the United States, is associated with structural reforms. How do you explain the fact that a liberal economic policy in these countries is supported by monetary policy, but you are calling for programmes that cannot be financed?

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: "blue card" answer. Madam President, it seems to me that, in this respect, I completely agree with the Commission. What we are doing is public investment by using the Union budget as collateral for a Community loan and, as I said, in addition, with the Commission's new interpretation of the Stability Pact, again we are encouraging Member States to invest. That is what we were talking about and I would like to say, since I have this little time, that the European Union needs all the Member States to benefit from these projects, from this Investment Fund.  I ask the Commission how much of the EFSI's activities it will be prepared to set aside for regions in difficulty.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR). -
text: Madam President! The European Union has a central philosophy: it responds to social and economic challenges with visionary plans and financial funds. I would remind you of the Lisbon Strategy: in 2000, the Union set itself a new strategic objective, namely to become the most competitive and dynamic economy in the world. The euro should speed up this process. Today we are facing a strategic shambles. The eurozone is not competitive internationally. There is no growth, but there is mass unemployment. Investment activity is paralysed. And what is the Commission doing? It presents a new plan: A new European Fund for Strategic Investments. Anyone who analyses this plan will come across a wealth of assumptions and estimates. Anyone who has studied projections knows that if an assumption changes, the calculations are no longer correct. A saying by Bert Brecht comes to mind, and everyone has to hear: "Yes, just make a plan, be only a great light. And make a second plan. They both don't go.'

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL). -
text: Madam President, Mr Vice-President, as you know, the sixth cohesion report finds that the cohesion objectives have been falling since 2008.  I therefore want to draw attention to the fact that if the billions of planned investments flow mainly into the richest regions, then it is all the effects of cohesion policy that are likely to be further annihilated, and the disparities between regions even more aggravated. We must therefore ensure that all categories of regions benefit from this plan. This is not a wish I make, I think it is an obligation that the European Commission has to do.  The Commission will also have to ensure that this plan ultimately only comes to finance what markets and industries are already able to finance and, as you said, we need risks, a shock of audacity, we actually need a New Deal for Europe. I am thinking, for example, of investments in the sea economy, in the cultural industry and, above all, in those troubled neighbourhoods where you have talented young people who have a lot of projects, especially in digital, that are asking to be hatched and that need to be supported. I end with a point on governance, it is quite clear that Parliament will have to be involved, because these choices are political choices.

name: Monika Vana (Verts/ALE). -
text: Madam President! The International Labour Organisation's study published today speaks of the job potential of the investment plan of 2.1 million by 2018. However, only under two conditions, namely that massive investments are made in the labour market at the same time, especially in those regions with very high unemployment at present, and that accompanying measures are put in place in the field of education, in the field of education in general. It is now the case that Vice-President Katainen made it clear in the Committee on Budgets that the aim of the investment plan is to attract private investors and increase competitiveness. Now, at least, he has mentioned the basic principles of Europe 2020, which include clear climate protection targets, employment targets, equality targets and poverty reduction targets. However, the fact remains that these criteria have not yet been formulated or binding on the investment plan. My question is therefore: how do you intend to ensure that these qualitative criteria are actually set out by the steering board as guidelines?

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this investment plan is destined to be another failure of the European Union, which continues to prove incapable of dealing with the economic crisis. I ask you how you can think of basing the plan almost exclusively on private investment, when it is clear that the lack of confidence and the further deterioration of the growth prospects will never convince them to put the money.  This crisis can only be achieved through massive public intervention, which must create the basis for private individuals to invest heavily. Thinking the reverse is pure utopia and mystification. European countries must be left free from budgetary constraints in order to invest. The United States emerged from recession thanks to an expansionary fiscal policy, churning out the 3% deficit/GDP for years. Their luck has been not having Maastricht or fiscal compact, absurd rules that kill growth and development.  Finally, this plan takes resources away from the European budget, with the risk of increasing the more than 20 billion outstanding invoices. Perhaps it would be appropriate to start from here in order to relaunch European growth.

name: Esteban González Pons (PPE). -
text: Madam President, Mr Katainen, from Spain we have supported this European investment fund and asked you to apply the principle of additionality (i.e. that this fund does not replace any of the investments that the European Investment Bank already has committed) and also to serve to finance the most risky investments, those that would not find financing otherwise. We share with you that the objectives of this fund are to have a direct impact on the economy and to create jobs and, therefore, high-quality investments, highly technological investments and investments that can also be profitable in the medium term must be selected. They must expedite the formalities and must hurry with the approval of at least the first projects, because we cannot disappoint any expectations. And governments must be forced to comply in this, as in everything. Governments must meet their commitments. A change of government does not mean a change of state and states maintain their commitments, whatever government of their color. No partner in the European Union has the right to become a risk to others, but no partner has the right to have advantages because they do not become a risk to others. Ladies and gentlemen, if non-compliance with commitments becomes an advantage, we will all fail to do so, not just Greece. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support I would like to ask the Member if we have understood that you are expressing serious concerns about this fund. I mean, that this new fund would in some way distract either national deductibles or other resources from existing and important investments of a Community nature. That's what I want to be clear about.

name: Esteban González Pons (PPE)
text: "blue card" response. – I said that this fund should take into account a principle of additionality, where means that the money spent on the new investment fund does not in any way replace the investment commitments already made by the European Investment Bank and which give rise to projects that are under way, which are creating jobs and which are helping many regions of Europe.

name: Kathleen Van Brempt (S&D). -
text: Many things have already been said about Greece. I do not think we should be having the debate here now, but we can learn something from it. First of all, you have to respect democracy, that's obvious. Secondly, that there is increasing popular support to say that a different European policy is needed. We will then be able to discuss for a long time what that means. But I think that other European policy is not only necessary, but we are also deploying it. As far as we are concerned, this may be more ambitious, but the fact that this investment plan is in place is very important. It is crucial that we be able to work with this.  In debates about the future, we often talk about structural reform. I hear that a lot. We, the S&D Group, are in favour of structural reforms, but of course you can discuss what structural reforms. Well, I have one on which we may be able to reach a consensus quite quickly - and perhaps the most important structural reform for the future, the transformation of our economy into a sustainable green economy. Radically making these choices, because we will also have the debate on climate and the road to Paris. Let us find a great consensus on this and let us embed it in these regulations around our investment plan. I think that's incredibly important.  An analysis has already been made - and I am also looking at my colleague Mr Bas - of all the proposals that are in place, and that is quite a lot, and it shows that more than 600 billion of the questions are related to good initiatives for a low-carbon economy. 25% of the proposals concern coal, nuclear energy, etc., but we already have proposals for 600 billion, which is actually double what lies ahead, which can be fully deployed on that sustainable economy. The role we are going to play in Parliament is to anchor that, to ensure that we not only invest, but that we invest meaningfully, sustainably and forward-lookingly.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE). -
text: Madam President, the other day we were a little surprised at his appearance in the Committee on the Economy, when he told us that there was currently no commitment on the part of any Member State to participate with money in the Juncker Fund. It left us a little worried, frankly, and confirms the fears we had at the start of the debate, which is that this plan is starting to go absolutely empty. The second thing I want to tell you and transfer to you is that if you are going to move funds from the general budget of the European Union, especially the Connecting Europe Facility of Horizon 2020, you will do a cost-benefit study of what it means to move those funds, because, in some cases, that can be extremely damaging. The third thing: in the legislative proposal there must be conditionality on the projects in order for them to have a social and environmental return, and we are very concerned, I have to tell you, for some of the projects submitted by the Member States, that they would involve a genuine social and ecological attack and that they are in no way in line with the policies of the European Union , not even the policies of the European Investment Bank. So I think that is where the Commission must also intervene.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE). -
text: The proposal for the European Fund for Strategic Investments is bold, innovative, will create jobs, help businesses and promote entrepreneurship. It translates into an ambitious investment plan, which will provide positive side effects to extend and strengthen the internal market. It will remove obstacles to deepening this market. It will promote interconnection and interconnections of networks, in particular in energy and digital. It will help to strengthen our competitiveness and, for example, to increase our energy independence. For the success of this Fund we need legitimacy and transparency. Projects should seek the participation and inclusion of all member states concerned and the European Parliament should be involved in this plan as much as possible. The Juncker plan, as it is known, must also have a component of internal solidarity, a component of territorial cohesion.

name: Udo Bullmann (S&D). -
text: Madam President! Unfortunately, mr Kamall no longer has the pleasure of taking part in our lively debate. But I would like to shout to him: If he already quotes Bob Dylan, then please decide on the right line of the song. My suggestion would be: The times they are a-changin. That is the motto of the day.  I believe that we can first see some commonground. It is clear that there is no longer any significant force in this House, that there is no significant force in political Europe that does not concretly, that we have a huge investment gap and that we urgently need to do something about it in order to return growth and promote employment. That is something, we agree on this point! Now, technically, the question is how we do it. Mr Vice-President of the Commission, Mr Katainen, there are a few issues that we need to resolve. Thank God in codecision, that is what we are here for. The first question is that public-private partnership has many advantages, that the private sector takes the risk, and if it succeeds, more capital can be mobilised. But how do we get the money now, if it works, into the right fields, into the fields where the most social added value is generated? How do we do that? That is why two others follow from this question: who has the trousers on, who is in charge of the governance of this new instrument? If the European Parliament gives money, if we have ownership, then we will not hand over responsibility to the cloakroom. We will continue to take responsibility for the form we need to talk about in codecision. The second is, of course, it must be possible to develop the great diversity of projects that is now on the verge of being profitable. For this we need a good policy mix of instruments, and this is where we need to refine. We are available. In codecision, we will find ways of doing this. I am confident.

name: Wim van de Camp (PPE). -
text: As a member of the EPP Group, as a member of the Committee on Transport and as a Dutchman, I welcome the Juncker Commission's plan. I often disagree with Mr Eickhout, but it is time for us in Europe to think in terms of challenges, and not just in terms of threats. We have thought for a very long time in terms of threats and now it is time for the challenges. But I tell you, Mr President, the path of ideals is paved with foot-and-clamps. One of these clamps is that the transport sector is allowed to deliver almost half of the money through the connecting European facility. But we like to do that, and we do so in Dutch, because we assume that we as multiplier get a lot of money back and also for classical infrastructure. I understand that the Internet and the Energy Union need a lot of money, but we also want traditional infrastructure. It will be another challenge to convince the private market of the Juncker plan - take a look at interest rates. And I have a question for the Council: how much money has the President of the Council already raised from the Member States to support the Juncker plan?

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D). -
text: Madam President, Commissioner Katainen, austerity in Europe has not worked and that is why we are calling for urgent and profound changes, and in this sense the commission's plan is going in the right direction because it is betting on that investment that we have been calling for, as a pillar to consolidate growth and generate jobs. Investment is the most powerful tool available to Europe to reform and modernize our economy. This means that it is not only quantity that is important, because also the quality of the projects and the added value that we will contribute is essential. That is why we need a structured investment plan around the Europe we want to build. We need a much broader future strategy, an agenda in which sustainable development is our real goal. And that is why I would like to stress once again that there must be coherence between political objectives and financial means at European level, because we will not be able to carry out any ambitious strategy either with the current European budget or with the current investment plan, as designed. But, as I was saying at first, we're going in the right direction. We need this plan, we need it to work and we need it to work now, because we have to revive the European economy. And to do this you have to meet many criteria. First, the criterion of additionality, very important. We cannot be tempted to finance what was already in the portfolio, because otherwise there will be no real European added value. Second, that the projects financed have a socio-economic value and impact. Third, let us go where our intervention is really necessary, where there are market failures or where we are in suboptimate investment situations. Fourthly, take, for example, country-risk into account when assessing projects. There are many things we need to talk about and this Parliament is ready to work with the Commission and the Council side by side to make this plan work. But first I would like to call on the Council and all countries to participate in this plan, because this plan alone is insufficient and we need more capital to improve investment.

name: Ingeborg Gräßle (PPE). -
text: Madam President! Commissioner! There are many unanswered questions surrounding the whole Juncker package, and it would be nice if there were some answers, Commissioner. The European Parliament can give EUR 8 billion, and then we are out. In terms of household terms, we make a trust fund, pooled money. This means that there is no accountability; we will never have a complete overview of what is actually going on, of the risks, of what this money actually does. But one thing is clear: we are getting rid of this EUR 8 billion from the field of research. That is why I would like to say that haste is actually harmful. There are questions, such as .B how past experience in the field of financial instruments has been taken into account. As a budgetary controller, I can tell you that, so far in the period 2007-2013, only 40 per cent of the money for financial instruments has actually reached the final beneficiary who is to use it. Only forty percent! I wonder how we can actually believe that the world is changing now because this package exists. I have more questions and would like to have some answers. I would also like to say to you: is it enough to give money? Greece has the weakest use of resources in rural areas. There are regions that are financed, there are regions that cannot manage projects at all, that is to say, technical assistance is at least as much needed, and the question that has already been raised is: what we are offering investors is an important question. The DAX in Germany has reached +59 percent in the last 3 years. I do not want us to make investments that will have to pay users dearly afterwards.

name: Lambert van Nistelrooij (PPE). -
text: I fully support the Juncker plan, for investment and for making strides forward in a real economy. But still I have a few comments. First of all, I think it's too much stand alone plan. We have 460 billion real money in our structural funds and investment funds and the relationship between those funds and the plan is completely unclear. I also think that much more needs to be done. We have gained experience with risk sharing facilities, with Jeremy programs etc. So much more can be done with the existing financial reservations in our budgets. Secondly, I am pleased with that additionality. Because we have to be very careful that the debt that is already decentralised in all kinds of projects is not being taken over by the EIB and does not generate any additional real investment. The criteria are actually very vague. My question to the Council and also to you is: let's say that it ends up in the old Member States and not into new Member States. Is that acceptable? 80 to 90 % ends up in a number of Member States and not in others. Are you talking about that? And may I add to the cross-border projects? Because that is where Europe is needed. Do projects like that get a priority? Can I get a response from the Council?

name: Othmar Karas (PPE). -
text: Mr Vice-President, I would like to thank the Madam President! Ladies and gentlemen! We have too high unemployment in Europe, too high public debt, outdated structures, too little investment, too little competitiveness and too little growth and employment. The plan presented today is just one initiative, an additional initiative. Today's plan, and I am pleased about this, is breaking new ground on the part of Europe. But it is not a substitute for all the existing measures that we have adopted, but an additional initiative for competitiveness, growth and employment.  The Fund is a real initiative for a European Investment Plan. The idea behind it is important. We need projects that are sustainable, otherwise we will not get private investors. Ladies and gentlemen, this Parliament feels partly responsible, and we will make this visible in our reports and in our work in the various committees, particularly in the Committee on Budgets, Economic and Monetary Affairs. To do this, we need dialogue. We do not accept that we are the governance control of the EIB. Instead, we will be involved in shaping it, and I say to them once again: the Member States must double the fund with money and guarantees so that it becomes a common concern.

name: Christian Ehler (PPE). -
text: Frau Präsidentin! Herr Katainen, wir stehen zu der grundsätzlichen Aussage von Manfred Weber, dass wir das unterstützen wollen. Das ist das richtige Projekt, jetzt muss es aber noch die richtige Konstruktion werden. Deshalb zwei Fragen:  What is the added value of the EFSI compared to the financial instruments which already exist, such as InoFin (Innovative Financing of Social Housing Refurbishment in Enlarged Europe), Horizon 2020 and the financial instruments under COSME (the Programme for the Competitiveness of Enterprises and Small and Medium-sized Enterprises)? Are they meant to complement one another? How can we create added value rather than merely relabelling or redirecting funds? The second question is: what kind of risk profile will the EFSI be looking for when funding projects? Or, to put it differently, how can a high leverage effect be ensured? That is important. We have existing instruments already in place. My last comment concerns the need to get it right in terms of projects. We would have liked a little more ambition, rather than taking support away from investment in research. There should be a certain burden sharing. That would have been the easiest way because you would not need to confront the Member States: it is easy to take that out of European money.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE). -
text: Madam Chairman, an important lesson for the new investment policy, based on the experience of cohesion policy, which is also investment and development, is that all forces should be channelled into preparing quality projects and strengthening human resources. So what is missing in the European Union are projects, but also human resources, and that is what the European Commission needs to focus on.  Likewise, Member States that are beneficiaries of cohesion policy have to invest an awful lot of resources to co-finance these projects, and I hope that the new investment policy will not substitute cohesion policy projects, but will be added, and that these countries will be helped in fiscal consolidation not to eliminate investments, but to strengthen investment potential.

name: Inés Ayala Sender (S&D). -
text: Madam President, I would like to ask Mr Katainen that the Commission, the Council and Parliament agreed on an instrument of the Connecting Europe Facility for transport, which was a success and which was in the right destination for infrastructure, services and job creation. Of those 30 billion, now 2 700 the Juncker Plan takes them away from us and passes them to the Juncker Instrument. I would like to ask you whether 100% of those 2.7 billion that are being passed to the Juncker Plan will go to transport projects and also with European added value and with European control of the Commission and Parliament. Because what has happened to us with the obligation for the Beaver project, which was one of the EI's luminaire projects, because it does not give us much thought that the money that is going to manage the EED right now has the same added value, the same security and technical assistance and, of course, the same control by the European institutions , the Commission and this Parliament.

name: Vicky Ford (ECR). -
text: Madam President, we need investment. We need private sector investment and investors, entrepreneurs and small businesses need to know that we are on their side. My email box is full of horror stories of small business which have shut and stopped trading in the fasting growing sector of our economy: digital entrepreneurs. Our new VAT rules are meant to be for big companies trying to avoid taxes but, for small companies, they are too complicated, too expensive and do not work in the digital age. They do not work for microbusinesses. They need an exemption. I say to the Council, the ball is in your court. Please do not just talk about changing this. Do not just think about changing it. That will not be taken seriously. Council, please, give microbusinesses an exemption. Just do it.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE). -
text: Madam Chairman, this Commission will be remembered for whether it succeeded with this very idea. Did this fund, did this plan work?  In this context, our mandate, which we are here and in this Parliament, will be very much marked by this success or failure. That is why I want to express my support for this plan right from the beginning, convinced that there is no alternative to it, because I accept the criticism and I think we should talk about criticism, but let's also offer alternatives. No one offered an alternative.  That is why I support this plan, I expect it will recognize a number of projects and above all make synergies. Synergy with the Member States that must participate in this project, but also with regions and cities, with private capital, with all that is available. Only in this way, through this synergy can we expect that this plan and that this fund will succeed.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL). -
text: This European Fund for Strategic Investments responds to an overriding need to combat the economic anaemia in Europe. The reality of unemployment, the lack of growth prospects and the risks of deflation are there to justify this need.  The means, unfortunately, do not correspond to the needs at all. The Fund is scarce and very dependent on what may be the answer of private investors. This model has failed in the past and will continue to fail because it is based on the construction of public-private partnerships in which the public bears the expense and the private with profit. We have seen this in health, communication infrastructure and even education.  Failure, because the problem is not only in the lack of funding, there is also a problem of lack of investor confidence, fuelled by austerity policies that continue to promote the concentration of wealth and depress aggregate consumption. Europe needs a publicly funded public investment project that contributes to the social and economic cohesion of the European area.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to join in the concern expressed by Mr De Clercq. Gräßle, who has left the Chamber, because the funding in question was taken from research funds and is then perhaps allocated to infrastructure projects, where organised crime may be moving, where the interests of the large multinationals are moving, which, in fact, the grand coalition of the European Parliament has a great interest in protecting, also in view of the recent events in Luxembourg. The Juncker Plan may also come for this: to find a common ground and find above all, perhaps, an alibi for the Socialists who are perhaps abandoning the fight against austerity. This plan perhaps gives them an alibi, because in the election campaign so many voters were deceived by the policies that some socialist parties promised, precisely, to fight against austerity. Therefore, I think that this is a very risky plan and we are in danger of going to cover up what is in fact the will of the European citizens.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI). -
text: The Juncker Plan is seen by many here as a miracle weapon. The figure is impressive: EUR 315 billion, of which EUR 21 billion comes from the EU, and we expect the private sector to do so 15 times that. It's not a miracle weapon, it's more of a miracle. What could be tempting for the private sector? The fact that these are high-risk investments and that the state has to take responsibility behind it must be taken with public money. We in Hungary have very negative experiences of this type of PPP cooperation. If economic development is not an end in itself, then the main objective must be to create jobs. SMEs account for 66.8% of jobs in the EU. This means that the main task would be to help, invest and position small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE). -
text: Let me start by saying that I fully support the idea of this investment fund. I also support the efforts of the European Central Bank, because it all leads to more jobs, working people, and that is a guarantor for satisfied Europeans, a guarantor of peace in Europe.  On this matter, I would like us to follow the timeline, but at the same time I would ask both the Commission and the Council to work very intensively with the Member States, so that what my colleague Van Nistelrooij has already pointed out to us is not to us, in order to find that, at the end of this investment programme, money has gone only to developed countries.  The problem is that many countries are also behind in development because they have not had these innovative approaches and approaches to mobilise private capital for development before. So be ware, just as we have to adopt all the regulation in the European Parliament and all the European institutions by the summer, countries must also conquer this philosophy.

name: Neena Gill (S&D). -
text: Madam President, I think the package put on the table by Vice-President Katainen is an important step. However, my group has been asking for this for years – saying we need more investment – because it is quite clear that just the austerity measures on their own have not kick-started growth. Therefore I welcome this legislative proposal for a strategic fund that is in front of us, but the onus is on all of us to make it work and ensure that we have implementation forthwith. To get it right we need to do a lot of work. The main points that I think some of the other colleagues have raised are that the selection of the right projects is essential and that they do add EU added value and are not just projects that would have been funded in any case. And Member States have to inject some more money into the fund, in a flexible way, in their national budgets. The question I would like to ask Vice-President Katainen is: who will decide on these projects? You said that Parliament will have a role in hearings but will we have a meaningful role in terms of the actual projects decided?

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. - Madam President, honourable Members, thank you very much for this lively debate and thank you for your ideas. I just want to underline the basic nature of the investment plan. First of all I want to recall what I have said before. This investment plan alone will not change everything. We need structural reforms, we need confidence-building fiscal policy, we need the right monetary policy and then we need Europe-wide action in order to encourage the private sector in particular to invest in Europe. That is why the investment plan is not a one-off stimulus measure. Instead, it is a structural European answer which has three angles. The first one is the risk fund, in order to encourage the private sector to invest in riskier countries, riskier regions, riskier projects, and especially in small and medium-sized companies. The second angle is a transparent project pipeline for which we would like to collect economically viable, reliable, well-structured projects so that private money can easily find projects from various parts of Europe. This has been wished for by institutional investors and private sector investors. They say that our everyday job is to invest in Europe, but unfortunately there are not enough viable and reliable well-structured projects. That is why they asked us to build a transparent project pipeline and we are going to do it. We want to help not only the private sector but also the public sector to structure those projects. We are enhancing technical assistance in order to make sure that the whole of Europe, all parts of Europe, can benefit from new opportunities. The third part, which in my mind is the most important part of the plan, is the single market part because it is a European structural reform which can create new markets, new opportunities for small but also for bigger companies in Europe, and there the sky is the limit for new job creation. That is why we all need to put our focus on the single market, and not to forget it – even though money is always more attractive – but the single market part is more powerful. We can get much more out of it than the other parts of the plan can bring. For those of us who are interested in helping SMEs and are interested in increased public resources for SME lending, I would encourage you to look at what the Spanish Government has done. It is a very good example to all of us. I would encourage every country to do the same. It is using structural funds as a financial instrument, providing more liquidity, more loans, to SMEs. This is the best way to use structural funds if you want to provide more loans to small and medium-sized enterprises. This is an untouched opportunity in most of our Member States. I wish you could help the Commission to pass this message to your own respective Member States. We should not forget that the original EIB will also continue to work. It will lend EUR 60 to 70 billion a year whereas the new risk fund, which is concentrating on riskier projects and SME lending to a greater extent than the EIB, will provide some EUR 60 billion liquidity without any Member State contributions, but in three years’ time. The reason why the new fund is smaller is that it is focusing on high-risk projects and nobody knows how much demand there is for this kind of money. I want us to work closely with each other. When we are taking money out of the European budget it means that we are using the same amount or a bigger amount of money but in a different way. For instance I expect research will receive more when we use the leverage effect of the new fund. We have to work very closely with each other; we have to work very fast together in order to open new opportunities for our companies and for our citizens to get jobs, because job creation and new jobs is the only reason why we have established the new fund and new investment plan.

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council. - Mr President, honourable Members, thank you for this debate which demonstrates the importance we attach to kick-starting investment in Europe after years of stagnation. It bears witness to the common determination of all three EU institutions to deliver promptly to European citizens on the ambitious investment plan, a plan that should promote sustainable growth and job creation. During this debate I took note of five blocks of questions on themes we discussed today. First of all we touched upon so-called red tape and the role of structural reforms, then we came to questions on sources of finance for investment and jobs in Member States, and to relations between public and private investment. Then, and very importantly, we heard the call for attention to be paid to the question of jobs: stimulating new jobs and fighting unemployment. Of course we talked about investments for the benefit not of private investors, but for our citizens’ jobs and the welfare. There were also questions about the use of the finance and the role of smart investments and sustainable projects and – importantly – horizontal questions about democratic legitimacy, the role of Parliament and the responsibility of Member States. So, coming to these five blocks of questions, I would like to recognise, in particular, the importance of what Mr Weber, Ms Rodrigues and Mr Kamall said. It is for this reason that we look forward to the Commission’s proposal and to initiatives under the third pillar of the investment plan. As I mentioned in my opening remarks, we believe that the third pillar may ultimately be the most important in terms of fostering private investment. We believe that, by proposing the three-pillar approach, the Commission has made the right choice because raising the level of investments is a rewarding exercise in the long term but a very complex one in the short term. The Presidency is ready to act not only on the proposal to establish the fund but also in the area of removing barriers and bottlenecks in the internal market, most notably in the fields of energy union, the digital economy and, indeed, the capital markets union. A lot can also be done at national level. With regard to the possible contributions of Member States to the fund, the details will need to be worked out in the legislative proposal, which we have just started to examine, but it is essential to ensure that, at whatever level Member States intervene, new investments can be mobilised. It is true that Member States or their national promotional banks will be able to contribute to the fund. But let me stress that this is just one of the ways in which Member States can support investment with the EFSI. They will also be able to contribute directly at project level or throughout investment platforms. As it stands, the Commission and the European Investment Bank have estimated that the level of funding envisaged will have to mobilise up to EUR 315 billion of new investments. Most of this will come from the private sector, where there is plenty of liquidity. This is real money and it needs to be used as soon as possible. That is without any additional contributions from Member States: when the additional contributions come, the amount will increase. When we talk about the added value of the fund, I would stress that the role of the new fund is to mobilise new investment, and additionality is a very important criterion which will ensure that the fund ‘crowds in’, rather than crowding out, private investment. We have only just started our examination of the proposal and, like the Parliament, we in the Council need some time to come to a position. However, it is already clear that the additionality of this instrument will be essential. The goal will be to support projects which are not currently being funded, for example because they are perceived as too risky. The fund should bear some of the risk, so as to make the projects more attractive to private investors. With regard to your comment, Mr Bullmann, you have raised a number of very valid points to which we will have to find answers during our internal and interinstitutional discussions. We agree that the money should come to where it is most needed, and we will have to work towards ensuring more certainty in the criteria. Of course the fund needs to address unemployment, inequality and growing poverty. That is the main goal. It is clear that an ambitious investment plan will help support demand in the short term and improve Europe’s growth potential in the longer term. It is an essential condition that it should underpin higher levels of employment. A significant increase in investment activity will bring a higher level of employment to the EU as a whole. The Commission proposal also envisages stepping up support for SME financing through the European Investment Fund. SMEs make a vital contribution to employment in Europe, and this part of the plan should not be underestimated as it will provide a significant boost to SME activity throughout the EU. With regard to the content of the debate in the Council – we had a question on that – I would draw your attention to the fact that yesterday’s Ecofin debate was public. However, since interest has been shown, I will provide a short insight into yesterday’s discussion. The Ministers showed their resolve to make this plan a success. They agreed on the necessity of ensuring that those projects which deliver the most significant contribution will succeed – those projects which create jobs and which enhance knowledge and technology transfer throughout the EU, be it in the developed regions or those which are still catching up. The principle of additionality was emphasised as one of the key criteria, and there are many questions that need to be clarified in order to get this right. Of course discussions will continue and the Council will work very hard and will deliver the best possible results. With regard to the role of the European Parliament, we very much look forward to starting negotiations with Parliament on the proposal to establish the fund, with a view to reaching an agreement as soon as possible in order to enable the flow of real money to our economies. But, in order for the private money to flow, some key principles are important, such as depoliticising the decision-making process at fund level and ensuring full independence in the selection of projects. In the Council we are also under heavy time constraints in examining the proposal. However, as the Presidency, we believe we can deliver on the ambitious deadline set by the European Council without compromising on the quality of the legislation. As long as we work constructively together, we can achieve this ambitious goal. Citizens expect us to deliver promptly. There is no time to spare when it comes to boosting investment in Europe. Let us work together constructively to make sure that the investment plan works. Let us put the economic crisis behind us. Let us jointly put in place the conditions for creating jobs and improving the welfare of European citizens. Let us make this work – honestly.

name: Der Präsident. -
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. – In his speech on Wednesday, Vice-President Katainen has not contributed anything to the Commission's legislative proposal on the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EIEF) whose text we have already known since the last plenary session. It should be noted in relation to this draft regulation that a clear legislative proposal has not been presented, but a financial gibberish that obscures the very important political and social dimension of the Investment Plan for Europe achieved through the constant work of the Parliamentary Group of European Socialists and Democrats. It is for this Parliament to correct and improve this draft, giving it minimal intelligibility and internal coherence. It is also important to ensure that the European Investment Bank exercises its role as a lender rationally, assuming a certain level of risk and not multiplying the imposition of commissions on beneficiaries or the exaggeration of EIE FEIE administration costs. Finally, it is striking, if not worrying, that Mr Katainen has come to his arraignments both before the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs and the plenary session of the European Parliament empty-handed with regard to possible national contributions to the EIG.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. There is still considerable uncertainty about the economic recovery in the Union and the risk of deflation is present. As such, the EFSI is a tool that can and should contribute to recovery in a context where private investors remain hidden and public investment is constrained by socially dramatic austerity in some countries and economically non-supporting for the Union. The public guarantee that is the basis of the recovery plan must be, this is the least of the things, a lever for improving the well-being of European citizens. Moreover, the principle of flexibility, which is gradually making its way, would like to see public investment through the EFSI excluded from the calculation of deficits for the States concerned. This is obviously essential for reviving social projects and promoting employment. But the socio-economic situation of the Union needs to go one step further. Flexibility must also apply to other strategic public investments that will create jobs and redeploy socio-economic. These include investment by local and regional authorities, which are constrained by the new accounting standards, even though they contribute significantly to economic activity without significantly impacting the debt.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. – Europe needs investment to revive activity and employment. Years of misguided austerity policies have led us to unbearable unemployment rates, especially youth unemployment, and lacerating increases in inequality and poverty, particularly in southern countries. A 180-degree turn is imposed. The new European Fund for Strategic Investments is heading in the right direction and, together with the flexibility introduced in the interpretation of fiscal rules, should be a starting point for abandoning austerity policy and clearly betting on growth, employment and welfare recovery. However, the lack of capital commitments to the Fund by Member States is worrying, which may discourage the attraction of private investment. We need greater commitment to strengthen the Fund's capacity to boost job creation and to undertake strategic investments that will enable Europe to overcome its deficits, such as the current fragmentation of the energy market, which must merit priority attention.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. – I welcome the Commission's proposal for a European Fund for Strategic Investments, which aims to lift Europe out of recession. I believe that Europe urgently needs an investment plan, because we cannot continue to blame economic hardship and cover up the crisis: cutting the budget, tightening social guarantees and saving at the expense of the people. According to the Commission, the European Fund for Strategic Investments will support strategic investments of European interest in infrastructure, in particular broadband Internet and energy supply networks, as well as transport infrastructure, in particular in industrial centres. It will also focus on education, research and innovation and renewable energy and energy efficiency. There are plans to focus more on small and medium-sized enterprises. However, I wonder whether the Commission has provided for a social return on this investment plan for Europe. How much is it expected to create new jobs or improve the quality of existing jobs? In other words, what will be the specific impact of the investment plan on people? Furthermore, in order to implement the European Fund for Strategic Investments as effectively as possible, I would like to call on the Member States to ensure that investment creates jobs other than any socially safe, increases employment and that a certain social impact assessment is carried out.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. The Commission is working on the participation in the Investment Plan of the Member States, as well as of the National Investment Banks. On both fronts we expect positive signals. The synergy of efforts at a time when public resources are not abounding can prove decisive. The area which can certainly make a difference to the resources at its disposal is that of private funds. We must be able to correct the anomaly where that today, with a greater availability of wealth, there is still no increase in investment in the so-called 'real economy'. In order to reverse this trend and stimulate private participation in the plan that decrees its success, the theme of project selection is fundamental. I would like to draw attention to two aspects that I consider to be central. There is a need for selection to take place on the strategic nature of the projects, which is the only way to reassure private investors and involve them in the effort. Another essential point will be to consider the added value of the employment impact that the projects chosen will be able to guarantee, given the current unemployment figures in Europe. We must do our utmost to ensure that the discussion phase is prolific and fast. I am sure that Parliament will not fail to make its contribution.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. - The term 'Last Chance Commission' is unfortunately the political reality of the situation the European Union is in today. The European Fund for Strategic Investments is one of the pillars on which the new European Commission bases its operational plan for the recovery of the European economy, increasing employment and consequently, saving the Union as we know it.  I support this idea for one basic reason, there are no other achievable ideas on the table. There are those who wonder why cohesion policy? How is the hedge fund different from it? Truth be told, their goal is the same, but the mechanisms are different. One of the most important differences is the mechanism that allows Member States to co-finance projects without increasing the deficit.  Without it, this fund would be doomed to failure even before it starts operating. State investments alone will not be enough to reverse negative trends and therefore the private component is of great importance. In conclusion, I hope that in five years we will applaud President Juncker for the success of the European Fund for Strategic Investments.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. Not content with having announced with great fanfare the launch of a major plan for strategic European investments and mitigating the effects of the LuxLeaks scandal, Jean-Claude Juncker has just admitted his inability to raise the necessary funds to implement his magic plan to stimulate investment and growth. As we predicted, the Commission strongly encourages states to abound in fresh money by proposing to extract their possible contribution to the EFSI (European Fund for Strategic Investments) from the calculation of their deficit under the Stability Pact. Far from loosening the budgetary stranglehold against the Member States, the Commission's strategy will give the Juncker plan a competitive advantage over the European Structural Funds and State/Region project contracts. The risk is that Member States' money, which is supposed to finance national public policies, will be diverted to the EFSI in the interest of budgetary adjustment. In this case, the European Commission is wielding the carrot and the stick to force states to transfer public funds at European level. This manoeuvre testifies to the extreme political tension that prevails in the European authorities.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. – The economic crisis has affected most economic sectors and the consequences have meant an increase in unemployment, a decrease in productivity and the profitability of certain sectors. The post-crisis "hangover" effect has led to a drastic decrease in investment at EU level, which has contributed to a decrease in confidence and created relative uncertainty about the European economic climate. We need financial instruments that stimulate private investment and guarantee their implementation. The intervention of private capital in public investment will mean more efficient and responsible expenditure. The outcome of the Greek elections has created new fears and immediately affected financial markets, and the effects are then passed on to Member States' economies. I am convinced that the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) will have the role of minimising these fears and strengthening investor confidence in the EU's economic potential. By attracting private capital to the economy and guaranteeing investment, the new investment strategy brings multiple benefits: it guarantees investment, makes it easier to access credit, contributes to the development of SMEs by creating jobs and generates long-term investments. At the same time, I believe that any possible additional contribution of more than 8 billion from the EU budget should be excluded from the discussion.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. I would like to give my full support to the investment plan proposed by the European Commission. The plan will eventually mobilise EUR 315 billion to finance strategic growth projects in transport, digital, energy, innovation, research and education. It will also support investment and development for European SMEs and mid-cap companies. This is an unprecedented opportunity to create jobs and adapt our economies to the challenges of the 21st century. As such, I believe that one sector needs to be the focus of attention: the agri-food sector. As global demand for food continues to grow, our European industries must strengthen their presence in a globalised and ultra-competitive market. This plan should be an opportunity to support innovation and trade in this sector, for the benefit of all operators throughout the agri-food chain, from production to distribution.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. – Dear Colleagues, I am pleased that Jean-Claude Juncker's promises made at the start of the new mandate are already gaining character with the presentation of the legislative proposal to establish the European Fund for Strategic Investments, which provides for an additional EUR 315 billion in private and public investment across the European Union. Here I would like to remind you that the European Union is still moving at two speeds, and even by three already, as many of the poorer regions in the European Union, instead of catching up, are significantly behind others. The standard of living and the economy of new member states such as Bulgaria are still far from the level of western member states, and the EU's cohesion policy does not yield a visible result. I would like to reiterate that it is the uneven distribution of economic growth in the EU that has led to an increase in internal migration and depopulation of entire regions. We need more strengthened and more concentrated action precisely towards the poorest regions, and for this I hope that the new proposals of the European Commission and the additional measures envisaged to support the European economy will be proportionally allocated according to the needs of the regions and the people. If this €315 billion is invested mainly in the old Member States, I would not be surprised if, in a year or two, even more mass migration follows in this direction.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. – The European Investment Fund proposed by the Juncker Commission is in danger of being yet another failed, uncertain and totally inadequate project to stimulate the growth and employment that Europe needs. The proposed mechanism is based on the multiplier effect that the initial financing of around EUR 16 billion would produce through private investment, in order to reach the figure of EUR 315 billion. I note two aspects that denote the inconsistency of the EFSI mechanism. The first relates to the great difficulty in which private individuals themselves find themselves, who, in conditions of lack of confidence and market difficulties, will hardly be stimulated to invest. The second concerns the type of projects to be carried out which, if not carefully screened and selected on the basis of strategic objectives, positive employment and environmental effects and maximum transparency, will prove to be the age-old infrastructure projects of major works that feed organized crime and the interests of large groups and multinationals. Finally, it should be noted with grave concern that some of the funding envisaged is being reallocated from existing resources for the Horizon 2020 research programme.

name: Jonás Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. – In his speech today, Vice-President Katainen has not made any news of the Commission's legislative proposal on the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EIEF) whose still text we have already known since the last plenary session. It should be noted in relation to this draft regulation that a clear legislative proposal has not been presented, but a financial gibberish that obscures the very important political and social dimension of the Investment Plan for Europe achieved through the constant work of the Parliamentary Group of European Socialists and Democrats. It is for this Parliament to correct and improve this draft, giving it minimal intelligibility and internal coherence. It is also important to ensure that the European Investment Bank exercises its role as a lender rationally, assuming a certain level of risk and not multiplying the imposition of commissions on beneficiaries or the exaggeration of EIE FEIE administration costs. Finally, it is striking, if not worrying, that Mr Katainen has come to his arraignments both before the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs and the plenary session of the European Parliament empty-handed with regard to possible national contributions to the EIG.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. In recent weeks, Europe has shown a willingness to change the strict austerity policies that have characterised the last legislatures. We acknowledge, Mr Juncker, a response to the demands of fairness, development and greater flexibility that the S&D Group and some countries, in the front row of Matteo Renzi's government in Italy, have placed on it. We are now approaching with a concrete legislative proposal, the proposal for a new European Investment Fund, which, together with the ecb's announced programme of buying government bonds, may be the precondition for a new growth season for the real economy. On the basis of these new instruments, the European institutions and the Member States will now have to show an extraordinary political commitment to stimulating growth and increasing employment. We need an ambitious agenda on so many priorities left aside for too long: a real European industrial policy, the Energy Union, the digital internal market, support for the social economy. The debate on the new Regulation of the European Investment Fund will demonstrate Parliament's commitment to the start of the new regulatory framework soon; We hope that the Commission will also show a sign of dynamism.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Schwa The European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) will be the main channel for mobilising funding of at least €315 billion. I am very pleased that all institutions agree to be ready to implement this plan to actively boost economic growth in the EU, which is necessary in the current situation of the pro-crisis crisis. The Fund will support investments in various forms of implementation of innovation and new technologies in our economy. The ambitious plan proposed by The Head of the European Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker, has every chance of becoming a flywheel for the EU economy, while strengthening our internal market. However, it is important to ensure the transparency of the projects financed, clear rules for grant awarding. The European Parliament must undoubtedly be actively involved in this process. The European Fund for Strategic Investments can become a key factor in the fight against current very high unemployment, especially among young Europeans. I hope that it will also provide an impe impely the further sustainable development of the Community economy. In the current situation of political turmoil, an increasing lack of faith in the EU's added value, citizens expect effective action as soon as possible to improve their quality of life. We have no time to lose.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. – In his speech on Wednesday, Vice-President Katainen has not contributed anything to the Commission's legislative proposal on the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EIEF) whose text we have already known since the last plenary session. It should be noted in relation to this draft regulation that a clear legislative proposal has not been presented, but a financial gibberish that obscures the very important political and social dimension of the Investment Plan for Europe achieved through the constant work of the Parliamentary Group of European Socialists and Democrats. It is for this Parliament to correct and improve this draft, giving it minimal intelligibility and internal coherence. It is also important to ensure that the European Investment Bank exercises its role as a lender rationally, assuming a certain level of risk and not multiplying the imposition of commissions on beneficiaries or the exaggeration of EIE FEIE administration costs. Finally, it is striking, if not worrying, that Mr Katainen has come to his arraignments both before the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs and the plenary session of the European Parliament empty-handed with regard to possible national contributions to the EIG.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. – The Aim of the European Fund for Strategic Investments is to increase liquidity in the markets, to finance investments that market participants consider too risky but to re pay off, thereby kick-starting the European economy. The draft regulation assures us that, despite the transfers of resources, the areas of infrastructure and R&D and innovation will not be disadvantaged. Moreover, overall, the amount spent on these policy areas will increase as a result of the multiplier effect. This issue is crucial for Parliament. Our support is conditional on genuinely increasing support for these projects and not diminishing them: the whole investment plan can be legitimate if the objectives of the TPM and horizon 2020 programmes, which have been jointly set by the Commission and Parliament, are not violated and implemented through the recovery plan. My colleagues have previously argued in favour of R&D, innovation, and I am now in favour of energy infrastructure. There is no more reimbursable investment than increasing security of supply, such as avoiding the high costs of crisis situations and ending price negotiations from vulnerable situations. Another area within the energy field is the financing of energy efficiency projects, which also benefits everyone: reducing Europe's energy dependency and reducing the consumer's energy bill. I call on the Commission to take these aspects into greater account.

name: Eduard-Raul Hellvig (PPE)
text: in writing. – With the highest unemployment rate in the EU (26% reaching 51% among young people, with almost a third of the population excluded from the public health system and below the poverty line, including following pension amputation by 40%, with a GDP per capita reduced by 30% from the 2008 level and a record public debt in the EU , equivalent to 175% of national GDP, Greece is exhausted by crisis, austerity and pouting. The outcome of the legislative elections is a wake-up call in this respect. I believe that compliance with Greece's commitments on budgetary responsibility and a realistic estimate of the country's possibilities to repay its debts can form a basis for recovery on an investment basis. Greece's increasingly hopeless situation warns of the economic future of a European Union that is failing to regain the pace needed for growth. That is why I believe that the Strategic Investment Fund must focus as a priority on directing liquidity to the countries and sectors most affected by the crisis.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The creation of the European Fund for Strategic Investments is a valuable initiative and I thank the Commission for presenting the legislative proposal in such a short period of time. This gives you the chance to complete the work as planned by the middle of the year and start your investment in a timely way. I hope that the selected projects will indeed be those of strategic importance and have high added value in the form of the creation of new, sustainable jobs. In particular, I hope that the EUR 75 billion foreseen for small and medium-sized enterprises will contribute to a real improvement in their innovation and competitiveness. Some doubts concerned whether the new fund would not be introduced at the expense of the Structural and Investment Funds. I am pleased that commissioner Crețu has been given assurances that the cohesion fund and policy will be complementary to each other and that the resources allocated to improving cohesion are safe. A good implementation of these funds means that we really have a chance to jump investment in the coming years.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. – The EU needs an ambitious investment plan to re-launch growth and create jobs. The proposal to mobilise additional public and private investment in the real economy, worth at least EUR 315 billion, should be complemented by a series of measures to remove barriers to investment and to create a genuine single market. I am glad that strategic infrastructure, research and educational projects will play a central role. However, there are many questions about this plan – largely in relation to the fact that it does not address internal economic divergences. The plan should be improved; it should complement regional development programmes; and we must not forget European values such as equity and solidarity.

name: Benedek Jávor (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. - A transparent and sustainable Europe! To start the engine of European development with strategic investments? Attractive idea – the Hungarian example shows you the possibilities and pitfalls. After the 2008 crisis, investment in Hungary increased for the first time in 2013. Even then, growth was only seen in industrial and infrastructure investments, predominantly through EU support. For example, a lowland motorway section will be built with European taxpayers' money for double German prices, and an existing railway will be renewed with the same amount of money for which a brand new high-speed railway will be built in Austria. Pakson is a nuclear power plant with Russian technology and financing – the cost is to accumulate a huge state tax. Is this the model for european economic recovery? Or audi's factory construction in Natura 2000 with a grant of $40 million per new job? It's not the future, it's the past. Strategic investments should build on the future rather than re-producing past mistakes: for example, the creation of an integrated European energy market, climate protection (one fifth of the expenditure on strategic investments should go directly to climate protection), the achievement of much more ambitious renewable, energy efficiency and emission reduction targets than at present. A sustainability analysis of all investments should be carried out in order to identify subsidies harmful to the environment. Investment decision-making should be made fully transparent, involving NGOs, and accountability should be established to curb corruption. This package can guarantee that the investment programme will not serve to steal and waste, but to put Europe on a sustainable path.

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Schwa In recent days, a plan to balance existing austerity policies has been observed. One pillar is President Juncker's so-called investment package, the most important part of which is the European Fund for Strategic Investments. The second was the eib's recent decision to buy euro area bonds, which means that huge amounts of money have been de facto pumped into the EU economy. Given the current economic situation in Europe, the current measures seem not only necessary, but even necessary. Therefore, despite numerous doubts – particularly regarding the reality of obtaining €315 billion – the creation of the Fund should be supported. Perhaps this is the last moment to improve existing policies and take action to stimulate the EU economy.  For my part, I would like to thank the Commission for trying to create mechanisms in its legislative proposal to ensure the rationality of projects financed by the Fund. The design of the Investment Committee makes it possible to hope that the initiatives chosen will actually serve the European economy and not just be the result of lobbying by individual governments. However, it is crucial to select the experts who sit there so that, on the one hand, they can look at the problems and needs of the EU economy in the long term and, on the other hand, they are independent and resistant to political pressure. However, I am concerned that the European Commission plans to finance the EU contribution to the Fund from the money allocated to Horizon 2020.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. – With the European Fund for Strategic Investments, or EFSI for short, the European Commission aims to mobilise €315 billion of investment for the European economy over the next three years. The fund relies on private investors, who, with a leverage of 5, multiply the EUR 21 billion provided by the European Union and the European Investment Bank, which will be increased from EUR 3 billion to EUR 63 billion in a first step, in a second step to the total volume announced by President Juncker. Some 2000 projects to be implemented have already been proposed by the Member States. In particular, risky projects will be supported. On the expert side, there are serious doubts as to whether a leverage effect of 1:15, as envisaged in the context of EFSI, is possible at all, i.e. there are serious doubts as to whether the Juncker package in its proposed form can work at all. It also criticises the raising of funds for the Guarantee Fund, the feeder fund for EFSI. The EUR 8 billion for the Guarantee Fund will come from 75 percent of EU research funding, i.e. Horizon 2020 and the Connecting Europe Facility. Funds that are then missing in the field of research, development and innovation throughout Europe.
