name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I would like to denounce that this proposal is not an investment plan: on the contrary, it attracts money from such important items as research and development. What the Commission proposes is to make the EI the bank of the great oligopolies and the privatisation of the public, an instrument for socialising private losses under the European seal. The EI has already demonstrated its inability to manage such projects: Beaver is in everyone's memory. But I point to the European crisis itself, the failure of the neoliberal model and its terrible commitment to put the State at the service of markets, as an example of the serious consequences of such policies. On the contrary, we need to put ourselves at the service of public investment: since only public management and control can transform our productive model at the service of workers. To this end, the Commission should be committed to the mutualisation and restructuring of public debt, the fight against fraud and the easing of deficit targets; putting the financial resources available to the state and not markets.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing – we have stabilised Europe in the fight against the crisis. However, we are in danger of stagnating for many years to come. We therefore need new impetus for economic growth and employment. Investment in the EU has fallen by more than 15% since 2008. At the same time, high-return investments are the best remedy for economic growth and employment. The situation in Europe requires a combination of measures: – Juncker's package investments must go hand in hand with the removal of obstacles to investment, thereby increasing Europe's attractiveness while multiplying the impact of the investment plan, – Draghi's plan to pump more than a thousand billion euros into euro area countries (so many are about annual tax evasion in the EU), – EURO funds for high-value investments, – economic reforms in EU countries – combating tax evasion and fraud in all corners of Europe.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. – The EU is looking to increase investment through the proposed European Fund for Strategic Investments. But in order to invest in a competitive globalised environment, the EU must abandon the policy of austerity, violent fiscal adjustment and the impoverishment of its citizens, while launching policies to increase demand and boost investment in education, innovation and research. This means changing the model based on social justice, the fair distribution of wealth generated, the Knowledge Economy and not the low-wage labour-intensive economy. In addition, energy security, low energy costs, low interest rates and investments in the real economy must be ensured with particular emphasis on supporting SMEs. So to the extent that these conditions are guaranteed and the EU's production model changes, we could really lead to an increase in investment. But the European Fund for Strategic Investments not only does not rely on the above production model but also does not even have sufficient funds to increase investment. The leverage of funds sought by the Juncker Plan is opaque and insufficient, while transferring the risks to the EU itself, its Member States and ultimately to european taxpayers themselves.

name: Giulia Moi (EFDD)
text: in writing. – The new investment plan launched at the end of 2014 by the President of the European Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker, foresees the mobilisation of €315 billion in new investments between 2015 and 2017. We should welcome the Commission's announced desire to support, in particular, strategic sectors, such as energy networks, broadband and climate policies.  Once again, however, Europe is in danger of staying away from the most immediate needs of most of its citizens. In fact, in the Juncker plan, very little space is given to the expansion and incentives to be allocated to the marked work. Little or nothing to social policies regarding welfare and immigration; even less importance is given to the small and medium-sized enterprises sector. All the attention of the European summits seems to focus more on future trade agreements with the United States and on investments that have only the strengthening of already established political agreements. The same people who are staring at Europe. The same ones that have been sacrificing the interests of citizens for too long in favour of those of the few.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. The new European Fund for Strategic Investments is certainly an important instrument, both to give new impetus to the construction of European infrastructures and to help small and medium-sized enterprises in the Union. However, it will be crucial that the structuring of its governance ensures maximum transparency in the evaluation of projects, especially those requiring more funding. There will also have to be clarity on a number of points, including the process by which the Commission expects to be able to apply a multiplier of 1 to 15 with the stimulus to private investment. Finally, it can only be disappointed that eight of the 16 billion will consist of existing resources to be reallocate and, specifically, almost 3 of these will be taken from the Horizon 2020 research programme. It is sad to note that, when decisions are taken on possible cuts, education and research are always the areas sacrificed first and should be the first of our priorities.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – I am one of those politicians who believe in public investment, but also understand that in today's world there is a need for the state to involve private investors in the actions it is taking.  However, even though I was initially a supporter of the European Investment Plan, I became increasingly sceptical following the latest information. My caution and question marks start from the transformation of this European economic recovery plan into a financial fund that mimics high-risk private ones and does not preserve the basic principles of the European Union, such as solidarity, equity and social values.  More specifically, it is apparent from the statements of the European Commissioners that there is no mechanism by which the distribution of funds would take into account the diversity of the Member States, their level of development, the capacity for co-financing or national rules on legislation, social protection or the environment. I must stress that the distribution of funds remains unclear. The allocation of only 20% of the funds to SMEs is also too small in relation to their possible contribution to job creation and economic development. I just hope that the way in which the selection process will be organised will be more transparent.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – The success of the investment initiative hinges on the ability to identify and select those risky projects that would have not been realised in the absence of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), and where the ‘leverage effect’ can achieve its full potential in terms of attracting private financing. One of the main challenges for the governance structures will be to ensure additionality and avoid the crowding-out of private investment. According to the provisions of the proposed regulation, an independent Investment Committee will be charged with the task of examining potential operations and approving support for them irrespective of the geographic location of the projects concerned. Although the text does not provide for any geographical pre-allocations of investment, it would be important to consider devising a mechanism to guarantee the balanced distribution of the projects, taking account of the differing economic conditions and investment environment across the Member States. It is important to emphasise that projects in poorer and peripheral regions could, ceteris paribus, provide higher social returns and European added value, thus helping to safeguard the proper functioning of the single market. I call on the Commission to assess carefully the governance structure of the fund so as to guarantee the independence of the Investment Committee.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D)
text: in writing. – One thing is common to those who push for all-out fiscal consolidation and those who insist that the total priority must be economic stimulus: both agree that investment in Europe is lagging too much. The EU Fund for Strategic Investments is being proposed by the Juncker Commission to compensate for this deficiency. It has been criticised as being too little too late. Also, the really new investment monies being mobilised by the initiative are, in relative and absolute terms, minimal. Most have been subtracted from monies voted by the EU for research, and that is highly regrettable. I sympathise with people who argue ‘better this than nothing’: however, the malaise of the eurozone results fundamentally from deep imbalances between its constituent parts. These have created a dynamic in which internal economic divergences continue to widen. Perhaps the only way to counter the imbalances is through a central investment fund that is massive in scope and is targeted to rebalance wealth and employment creation within the eurozone. The Juncker fund has no chance of achieving that target. Nor does it have that ambition. For that reason, I fear it will make hardly any dent in the economic stagnation in Europe.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: Writing. – There is considerable investment potential in Europe, the use of which would allow the creation of new jobs, stimulate the employment of young people and strengthen the competitiveness of the European economy. The Objective of the Fund for Strategic Investments is to remove obstacles to the full exploitation of untapped potential by supporting strategic investments, in particular in infrastructure, research and education. In order for this ambitious project to be successful, it is necessary to set clear rules at an early stage – to ensure the maximum level of transparency in the selection of specific projects, to prevent conflicts with financial instruments already approved, in the field of transport, for example, with the CEF, and to concentrate on making more efficient use of the European Structural and Investment Funds overall. I wish President Juncker that the investment plan would be a good new start for his Commission.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing – the European Fund for Strategic Investments is yet to be born, but it already has many critics and opponents. But critics do not offer other solutions. I support the Juncker proposal because, after years of stagnation in Europe's economy, it is necessary to give the possibility of mobilising additional investment, maximising the impact of public investment and freeing up private investment. The Investment Plan should enable the real economy to be financed through a transparent database containing viable projects at EU level. The new fund will support strategic investments in infrastructure. It will also support risk finance for SMEs and mid-caps. Today, there are almost 2000 projects on the list of potential investment projects. Slovakia has sent 150 projects worth a total of €29 billion and I believe that in the final selection we will have successful projects that will contribute to the growth and creation of new jobs in my country as well.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE)
text: in writing. – Considering the 23 million unemployed in the European Union, expectations are justifiably high regarding the Juncker Commission’s EUR 15 billion investment plan to put Europe back on a growth track and create new jobs. I believe that, in order to achieve good results with the investment plan, we must follow two rules from the outset. First, we should ensure that enough money is targeted towards countries where there is insufficient credit for SMEs, thereby creating more impact where this money is truly needed. Second, with regard to the project selection criteria, we should ensure that these are clear enough and that they allow for competitiveness between projects, but, at the same time, that they lead to the financing not of deadweight projects that would have been financed anyway but of projects with a high leverage effect conducive to the creation of jobs which would not have been created in the absence of the financing. We should also use this tool to support investment in novel and high-risk areas like green energy and the digital economy, where investment is truly needed and where we can have a strong impact in terms of the realisation of the EU 2020 strategy.

name: Jutta Steinruck (S&D)
text: Writing. – The creation of the European Fund for Strategic Investment is the next important step in Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker's investment plan. I very much welcome the fact that this fund has been launched within three months. Nevertheless, I urge caution: investment is not an end in itself and must not be made out of pure action for the sake of investment. We must not lose sight of our common objective of creating good jobs. Mr Juncker and Mr Katainen have also announced this with their 'Triple Social A'. We will judge them against that promise. Confidence in Europe has been shaken by the crisis and the resulting high unemployment rate of 9.7%. This is used to capitalise on anti-democratic movements throughout Europe and offer supposedly simple solutions in times of complex problems. We must show people that Europe is more than competitiveness at all costs. Jobs must not be created for the purpose of lower unemployment rates in the short term, but must be under the guiding principle of sustainability. We do not need more atypical employment, but at last we need jobs with fair pay and the guarantee of long-term employment.

name: Theodor Dumitru Stolojan (PPE)
text: in writing. – I welcome the European Commission's focus on the implementation, as soon as possible, of the investment programme through the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI). I appreciate the conceptual construction of this fund and the fact that Member States can participate in the capital formation of the fund, and this effort will be taken into account in the analysis of the budget deficit.  I believe that both potential private sector investors and investment beneficiaries want to know more about the financing cost-forming mechanism. It is important that the EFSI contributes to a reasonable balance between investors' desire for the highest possible profit and the desire of investment beneficiaries in need of the lowest cost of financing.

name: Henna Virkkunen (PPE)
text: Written. – Mr President! Boosting investment in Europe is essential for the future. The programme prepared by Vice-President Katainen is an important opening to encourage the private sector. I understand very well the concern that parliament has raised about using funding for the Horizon 2020 research programme for the investment programme. It should be noted, however, that this can also be an important opportunity to leverage research and product development funding even further. The most important thing now is to ensure that the funding that may be decouped from Horizon 2020 into the investment programme is directed specifically at research and product development projects and not at pipelines, networks and roads, although infrastructure is also needed. For example, there are a lot of promising R&D activities and new growth sprouts in the interface between university research and companies that should be funded.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (PPE)
text: Writing. – This mechanism can and should significantly strengthen the Member States, contributing to the creation of an investment-friendly environment, as long as it operates more flexibly and immediately mobilises more capital. The European Parliament will be able to assess and monitor the functioning of the mechanism, enhancing transparency in its management. Now is the time when, as a Union, we must act quickly and decisively to sustain investment, promote smart innovation and support reforms to reduce red tape. I welcome the Commissioner's statement, which gives priority to projects relating to the sectors and regions with the greatest problems such as my country. In Greece today, traders and professionals find it difficult to meet their insurance obligations. We must put an end to this and seek funds with immediate absorption. Investment should be aimed at the real economy, reaching the money directly to the citizen, boosting business, creating new jobs, contributing to the growth rates of both the Greek economy and the European South as a whole.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. – The launch of the European Fund for Strategic Investments is a quantum evolution in European crisis-fighting policy. It means the recognition of the failure of the impoverishment model as a path to the sustainability of public accounts. The new fund has weaknesses, but opens a new conceptual stage. On the one hand, strategic options are explicit and, on the other hand, the capitalisation of the fund will not be counted for the purposes of a public deficit. The next step will be to extend this exception to all strategic investment. This is the way to a future of sustainable growth for Europe.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This Investment Plan will only be positive if it is no longer a programme for granting public guarantees to private investments. By the nature of the investments in question – large infrastructure – it is easily concluded that we are talking about public-private partnerships, where profit is on the side of the private and the risk on the public side. Moreover, if investments are not based on the creation of safe, stable and rights work, the jobs that will be created will be ephemeral, underpaid and will not solve, in the medium and long term, any of the problems it says it wants to solve.

name: Der Präsident. -
text: The next item on the agenda is the statement by the Council and the Commission on the roadmap for a new climate agreement in Paris (2015/2521(RSP)).

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council. - Mr President, the Paris Climate Change Conference at the end of this year is expected to adopt a new global climate agreement for the post-2020 period. This new agreement should be universal and capable of keeping us on track to limit the average global temperature increase to below 2°C relative to pre-industrial levels. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change has indicated in its latest synthesis report that the target of 2°C and global emissions reduction of 40-70% compared to 2010 are needed by 2015, and that emission levels should be near zero or below in 2100. We have less than 10 months and we need to use this time efficiently. The results of the Lima Climate Change Conference, and a sense of urgency expressed by world leaders at the UN climate summit in September, provide a necessary impetus for the work this year. The Lima call for climate action, adopted in December, contains two main outcomes. The first is guidance for the communication of proposed emission-reduction targets, the so-called ‘intended nationally determined contributions’, and the second is the preparation of elements for the draft negotiating text for the Paris agreement. In the Paris agreement, all parties should have legally binding mitigation commitments, but levels of ambition and commitment types will differ. Intended nationally determined contributions should therefore allow each party to choose its contribution type and define its level of ambition, in accordance with its national circumstances and capabilities. In October last year, EU leaders endorsed a target to reduce the EU’s domestic emissions by at least 40% in 2030 compared to 1990, in line with its long-term objective of reducing emissions by 80-95% by 2050. The strategic framework is now to be translated into an EU intended contribution. The Presidency of the Council is determined to ensure that the EU intended contribution is submitted to the secretariat of the UN Framework Climate Change Conference within the first quarter of 2015. We expect other major economies to come forward promptly with their contributions as well. The Paris agreement should go well beyond mitigation targets capable of delivering on the below-2°C objective. It should also be dynamic, with inbuilt flexibility and capacity to respond to evolving circumstances, responsibilities and capabilities. It should provide a long-term vision of the need for transformation towards a lower-emission and climate-resilient economy and it should enable broad and effective participation. Let me underscore that, despite the significant progress, there are still important issues on which a shared global vision has yet to emerge, in particular on differentiation between countries’ obligations on the legal form and force of the Paris agreement.  Intensive negotiations will be needed in order to find common ground on these outstanding core issues. The Presidency of the Council will make all possible efforts to ensure effective European Union participation at the international negotiation sessions. Outreach activities planned to take place throughout 2015 will be a crucial element in this process. They will contribute to the ongoing discussions. We have to talk to our partners all around the world to try to find common ground. Moreover, in order to ensure an appropriate background for negotiations, we need to make sure that the EU’s efforts on emissions reduction and support for developing countries are adequately recognised. The Presidency of the Council will also stimulate EU-internal political debate on climate change with a view to the Paris conference. The Environmental Council in March will be the first opportunity to discuss the EU’s expectations and strategy.

name: Miguel Arias Cañete
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is my satisfaction to have this opportunity to exchange views on the European Union's climate action plans and activities on the conclusion of a comprehensive climate agreement which we want to reach in just over ten months at the United Nations Summit in Paris. First of all, I would like to share with you my assessment of the Lima Conference. I have already had the opportunity to do so with the representatives of this House during that Conference, in the context of the daily meetings we held during the last COP. That is why many of you know that I believe that the Lima COP was an important step in our efforts to reach a comprehensive agreement in Paris. It would highlight three conclusions of the Lima Conference. First, the decision to reiterate the need for all countries to submit their respective national emission reduction contributions at the end of March, known in English as intended nationally determined contributions. Secondly, agreement was reached on information requirements, which should clearly, transparently and understandably describe these contributions. Finally, the decision mandated the United Nations to prepare a synthesis report once all the respective contributions have been submitted. This report should allow us to assess the progress we are willing to make collectively to keep the increase in global warming below two degrees Celsius. Lima has also been a palpable demonstration of the unity of the European Union. There was great collaboration between ministers and with the European Parliament. We were able to react to changing circumstances satisfactorily and hope that this collaboration will continue throughout this year. However, much remains to be done this year. The draft of the final text elements of the agreement is too long and contains excessive options. Very important issues remain to be resolved, such as the legal form of the future agreement, climate finance and differentiation in national emission reduction contributions. In order to clearly articulate our vision of the objectives to be achieved by the Paris agreement, in the coming weeks I will present to the College of Commissioners a Communication entitled 'The Paris Protocol, a project to combat climate change beyond 2020'. This Communication has two main objectives: first, to describe how we intend the Paris Protocol to be dynamic, transparent and legally binding and, as such, capable of responding to economic and geopolitical realities; and, secondly, to translate the objectives of the European Union's climate and energy strategy by 2030 into our emission reduction contribution, in accordance with the information transparency requirements agreed in Lima. The Communication will reiterate that we must work hard to reach an agreement in Paris that applies to all. The United States and China are committed to action and, together with the European Union, would account for nearly half of the world's greenhouse gas emissions. But all countries that can submit their national emission reduction contributions this year, as we agreed in Warsaw. All G20 countries and other major economies are certainly in a position to do so. But, in parallel, and throughout 2015, we will need to mobilize our energies in the area of climate diplomacy, we will need to continue to dialogue with our partners and friends about our vision for the new agreement and encourage them to present their national emission reduction targets. Of course, the Commission is committed to working to maintain the European Union's leadership on climate action and, together with Commission Vice-President Federica Mogherini, we will work to raise awareness among all international actors this year. Next week I will be in Washington to meet with my counterparts from the State Department, the Department of Energy and the White House and on February 4th we will hold a meeting with Chinese Minister Xie Zhenhua and the Secretary-General of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change. Last week the Vice-President and High Representative and myself presented a climate diplomacy plan at the Foreign Affairs Council which was supported by the Foreign Ministers. Implementing this plan together will contribute very positively to raising awareness of large numbers of countries, both in bilateral meetings and within the framework of the G7 and G20. Finally, I would like to say a few words about the climate finance, an essential issue not only for the Paris agreement, but also for the credibility of the European Union as an international player. In 2013 the European Union and its Member States contributed EUR 9.5 billion in climate finance, but there is no doubt that the European Union and the Member States have to continue their efforts. Together with the Ministers of Finance and Development Cooperation, we must be able to engage with our partners on this fundamental issue, in order to complete an ambitious agreement in Paris. In addition to the climate negotiations we are also negotiating the post-2015 sustainable development goals. On this issue, Commissioners Vella and Mimica are leading the work within the Commission, and we will work together to ensure that our action is coherent. At the same time we will continue to work together with the private sector and other international institutions, such as the World Bank, to mobilize more resources. Ladies and gentlemen, success for the European Union is to be able to speak with one voice Parliament, the Commission and the Member States. I will therefore continue to work closely with this House and the Council to reach an ambitious, legally binding and applicable agreement in Paris for all countries.

name: Ivo Belet
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. I think we can say that the European Union still has the most ambitious climate policy in the world: a 40% reduction by 2030. I don't think anyone's doing any better. Meanwhile, while things are moving slowly in India and China, there is some cause for optimism towards Paris. In Canada and Australia, on the other hand, political leaders have yet to see the light. So be it. We hope that something will happen there. But first and foremost, we have to look at ourselves, finish our own homework. That means we want to follow a double track. On the one hand, as the Commissioner said, pursue an ambitious climate policy and, on the other hand, a strong economy. We are convinced that this can go hand in hand.  This does indeed require a balanced reform of our unique ETS system. With that market stability reserve system in the first place, we need to make that ETS a stable system in the short term. And also a system that is shock proof, that is, it is resistant to shocks and that we need to have a good solution for the back loaded allowances, which is balanced at the same time. By this I mean such an ETS reform with market stability reform that industrial companies that invest in sustainable technology also get all the opportunities and remain encouraged. To ensure that we do not find ing a situation where sustainable production is moving away from Europe to just across the border, outside the European Union, where there is no ETS system. It is therefore a matter of trying to achieve those 2030 targets with all sectors, ETS and non-ETS. [The speaker responds to a "blue card" question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)]

name: Marek Jurek (ECR)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – Mr President, you call our climate policy an ambitious policy, but do you realise that these ambitions are paid primarily by the poorer countries of the European Union, those countries that have the least money to develop new technologies. The decarbonisation programme is really a programme to eradicate the main industry in our homeland. Maybe it is time for us to really think about how to pass on these costs to other countries, but we also think about our own countries.

name: Ivo Belet (PPE)
text: "blue card" answer. I am very pleased that you are asking that question, because it is one of the essential elements of that reform of the ETS system. I believe that very important guarantees were given at the European Council on 24 October for Poland, Hungary and other Member States from the former 'eastern bloc', as they say. They must indeed be given these guarantees, transitional measures must be provided to ensure a balanced transition so that they also have carbon leakage measures, and we can guarantee energy-intensive energy.

name: Kathleen Van Brempt
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – It is January, so we can still make New Year's speeches. That means looking at 2014 and then making good intentions for 2015. I could be ominous and say: 2014 was the warmest year ever, and that should worry us. But 2014 - the Commissioner has spoken about it - was also the year that was concluded with an agreement on Lima. We might be pessimistic, but the good thing is: we have an agreement, let us build on that. It has already been said that it is very important that we look at ourselves in the coming months and lead by example. We have a responsibility in the world to do that. Climate diplomacy has already been discussed. Very well, Commissioner, we fully support this. We think it's incredibly important.  But looking at one's own responsibility also means looking at the funding. Mr Belet, who has a particular responsibility in that dossier, has already spoken about it. I think it will be symbolic for the next few weeks if Europe will effectively succeed in taking its responsibility. I make a gesture, which I do not often do, to the PPE Group: let us make a good agreement together, not as it did in Itteren. Let us be ambitious and realistic, and that also means: let us start a new system of market stability reserve as soon as possible. That is crucial. [The speaker responds to a "blue card" question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.]

name: Andrzej Duda (ECR)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – I also have a question for Mrs Van Brempt in the context of our previous discussion on the Strategic Investment Plan. We are talking about reducing emissions at the moment, we are talking about the fact that we, as the European Union, also want to get the rest of the world to do so. The problem is that our plan that we want to implement, which is to reduce emissions by 40%, is a plan that is basically not accepted by the rest of the world – let's call it by name – which will make the European economy much less competitive in this perspective. Is it not better today also to devote money from the Juncker Plan to a significant extent to investments in energy, to improving energy efficiency?

name: Kathleen Van Brempt (S&D)
text: "blue card" answer. – I totally agree with the latter. Energy efficiency should be the top priority of the Juncker Plan. Secondly, I believe and hope that you will also feel that it is very important to take our responsibility in the world with regard to pollution. At the same time, we are looking for solutions very innovatively. In our country, many companies, steel companies, chemical companies, are among the top in the world in terms of energy efficiency. I know that we still need to take steps in Eastern Europe, including in your country. And for that, Europe must show solidarity to ensure [the President deprives speaker of the floor].

name: Ian Duncan
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I am struck again, as we sit in this Chamber, by the fact that we entered the Lima discussions with such high hopes and I believe we left them with such low expectations. Success is not final and failure is not fatal. It is the courage to continue that counts. So we must leave behind some of those disappointments in Lima and cast our eyes towards what we can finally achieve in Paris. On hearing some of the questions from colleagues, even in my own group, I realise this is going to be a challenge – not just a global challenge but a challenge for Europe itself. We must make sure – and I believe the Commission must adhere to this – that in going forward, when we consider mitigation and adaptation, we provide adequate support for adaptation both within the EU and more broadly.

name: José Inácio Faria
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Science has spoken on climate change. The climate situation has not only been worsening, but this has been happening at a higher rate than expected. There is no doubt about what is going on, we now have solid data and a strong consensus on the part of the scientific community on global climate change.  It is now the turn of policy makers to take responsibility. What we've been doing isn't enough. The commitments we have reached with our global partners are insufficient. We cannot turn a blind eye to this reality and we must act now before it is too late for the planet. As Mr Cañete said here today, many difficult aspects remained unresolved at the Lima Conference. There are many parties involved and many interests concerned and experience shows that they can only be resolved at the highest level by the Heads of Government and State. An example of this is the requirements and financial contributions to the Green Climate Fund. Without the consolidation of this instrument, we will hardly be able to achieve the crucial goal of a global, ambitious and legally binding agreement to limit CO2 emissions. Time is short until the Paris Conference, which will take place later this year. I therefore believe that concerted action by the Member States and the European Commission is essential, and this should be a whole as a diplomatic offensive coordinated by the High Representative of the European Union, Federica Mogherini, with the main international partners, as Mr Cañete also said here in his initial speech. I also believe that the European Union must show commitment and that it must ensure coherence and determination in its own energy and climate policy objectives. I hope that this will be demonstrated in the awaited energy union communication, expected by the end of next month.  Only by being consistent and ambitious between us can we maintain the credibility necessary to successfully lead the negotiations on the global climate agreement.

name: Merja Kyllönen
text: On behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the message from the Lima Climate Conference was clear to us. A genuine solution must be found in Paris, a climate agreement must be reached. Peru, where the climate conference took place, suffers the fourth most from climate change in the world. The visit to Peru was eye-opening. Changes can be seen in everything, food production, the fastest of all. There will be a battle for clean drinking water and edible food. The poorest everywhere suffer the most, and women suffer the most from the poor. Cold, heat, drought, famine and land corrosion are increasing all the time. I brought a sense of injustice to all of us as a so-called 'so-fire' feeling that developing countries rightly feel. It should wake us up to action in Europe. Whose standard of living is one of the causes of climate change? Who, as the poorest, suffers the greatest consequences? The response to climate change is therefore also about solidarity and humanity. In Europe, we need to make our own ambitions more ambitious, to move towards fully renewable energy. Climate finance must be steadily increased, and the economic crisis cannot stand in the way of this. Sensible solutions are an opportunity rather than an obstacle.

name: Yannick Jadot
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we know that in Paris part of the future of humanity is at stake. Is Europe acting on climate? Yes, Europe is acting. Is Europe doing enough? No, Europe is not doing enough. She doesn't do enough for her first. Contrary to what a number of people say about the competitiveness of the European economy, we will still have to start looking at the reality of the European economy. The sectors that are doing well are those sectors that anticipate climate change, which are part of the energy transition, efficiency and renewable energy. It is also the sectors that are creating jobs today. I invite you to reread in particular the Commission's paper on job-generating growth: the first sector that will create jobs in Europe is the energy transition sector. But we also need to do it for climate negotiations. Europe, too, is not doing enough. If we purge part of the ETS system, Europe could have a target of 25% reduction in our greenhouse gas emissions by the end of spring by 2020. It is essential that, in the contributions that the European Union will make, we exclude everything about land use, change in land use, because otherwise we will lose all credibility. And because we know that today, the main block in international negotiations is financing, we need to be more serious about this. Just because Europe actually does it doesn't mean that Europe is doing enough. We must act for ourselves and for humanity.

name: Marco Affronte
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Paris agreement could be the largest agreement ever reached on the issues dealt with and on the number of countries committed to reducing emissions.  We really hope that this time there will be a decisive turning point for a global climate agreement. The text adopted in Lima shows the willingness of states to reach a final compromise, including through the proposal for a permanent mechanism for raising emission reduction targets. But we cannot fail to be critical of the absence of binding deadlines which could limit their effectiveness. We must point out that, despite the attempts at negotiations, the text is still weak in defining the legal nature of the next agreement and there is still a serious risk to its effectiveness. The European Union must ensure and insist that the Member States prepare their national contributions well in advance and that they are effective and coherent. We must obtain and demand a binding treaty that commits all countries to reducing emissions in accordance with the objective of limiting world temperature growth to 2 degrees.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI). -
text: The lima climate meeting is a success because a signed document has been signed. Why would this be a success in itself when the UN declares that its main goal of keeping global warming below 2 degrees has not been achieved. Once again, the European Union is taking on more ambitious targets and is at the forefront of reducing emissions. But why not take into account that we are responsible for 10% of global emissions. It would be more important to get the US and China, the two biggest polluters, to make a real commitment. Moreover, China and India signed the document because, as developing countries, they were guaranteed that the more affluent would support them in climate protection investments. I ask: will the EU and its member Hungary support China, which is the world's second largest economy, with huge financial reserves?  (The speaker agrees to answer a blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. – In fact, we are talking about international or global aspects of climate protection. But I ask you respectfully, and I would like to ask your representative's opinion on this, that it is not easier to deal with the energy that has been given here on the surface of the earth? Do we have to constantly mine energy from everywhere and carry energy for 10,000 kilometres?

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Blue card answer. – It is not clear whether the question was my speech. As far as 10,000 kilometres are to be carried, it is precisely the independence of the European energy system that many of us mention. And I will give you a good solution from the point of view of climate, not polluter, clean, no need to carry energy on long lines: namely nuclear power plants. I therefore propose that you stand up for climate protection.

name: Karl-Heinz Florenz (PPE). -
text: Mr. President! Commissioner! First of all, a heartfelt word of thanks to you. We had very good contact with the Commission in Lima and were quite close to the issues. I believe that the main success of Lima took place about eight or ten days before the conference, when the Americans and the Chinese – Mr President, you were unfortunately not there – said: yes, we are taking part. We do not like this UN concept, but we are already telling you today what precise percentages we want to achieve in which year. And, sir, we are already going from 14% to 51% of the reduction in the world's CO2 emissions, and that is a pleasing goal. We have a 2030 target, which is quite ambitious, I do not want to deny that, and – this is very important for my colleague from Poland – we must find a sensible way to get there. Basically, the moment of truth is here today. In two months' time, the Member States of the Union and all the countries of the world – 192 in number – will have to set their actual reduction targets. And then there is an international arrangement, and we will see if we reach the 2 percent or not.  We need to readjust if necessary. But I am glad that the Americans and the Chinese are finally there, that was our goal and a goal that I personally have been pursuing for a long time. They can't get out of there, and that's why I think we're in the end, despite all the anger, where we want to get there. And all those who criticise here, Mr President,...  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Matthias Groote (S&D). -
text: Madam President-in-Office of the Council, I would like to Commissioner! I must say that I am glad that the European External Action Service has now also woken up, that we are developing a kind of climate diplomacy on the way to Paris. Paris must be a success, that is clear, and we must do the preparatory work here as a Parliament, but also with the other two institutions. The new Commission has brought the idea of an Energy Union into play. I think it should be a climate and energy union, because that's the only way to make it.  We must also organise this internationally, and that is why we are very keen to get an agreement internationally and that we ensure that the 520 million Europeans are able to ensure that energy supply becomes sustainable, becomes secure, but also that the issue of jobs, namely green energy, is being pushed forward by us, because it is precisely in this area that we have to create jobs in the area. , and there is huge potential. That is why we should take advantage of this tailwind, but also do our homework at the end of the day. Because no one in Paris will take it away if we do not manage to make the emissions trading scheme flounder. That is why, in the direction of the Council, also towards the Commission, but also here in this House: MSR, the market stability reserve, that must come, and we must agree on that. This must not be the way in which everything is put on the wall, as in the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, but the colleagues in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Energy will have to ensure that, at the end of the day, we are launched a responsible compromise, so that we do not have to be ashamed of ourselves in Paris, but can show that we have done the preparatory work in this regard. That is what we should use the coming months to do this!

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR). -
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking If, in Paris, the world's major emitters do not take on what the European Union is proposing to them, namely emission reductions, Then I think we should revise our climate policy. What will come of the fact that we will impose restrictions on ourselves? They will not bring any significant emission reductions in a global context, as we will be responsible for 4% of global emissions by 2030. Moreover, they can cause enormous economic and social damage. On the one hand, it will weaken our competitiveness, particularly in energy-intensive sectors, and on the other hand it will affect our energy security, which is particularly dangerous for Polish and other new Member States in the face of Russia's aggression against Ukraine. The Union itself imposes restrictions that already discourage many sectors of the economy from investing in Europe. This weakens particularly weaker countries, such as my homeland Poland, which, due to intra-EU restrictions, is becoming less and less competitive with global competition.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, Commissioner, after a not very successful conference in Lima, the eyes of the public are once again fixed on the international community in the hope of reaching a landmark agreement. The aim of the conference will be to keep global warming below 2%. I believe that this is a commendable objective, but I would like to warn against losing sight of the reduction in numbers. The European Union's plans to prevent global warming are very ambitious. However, we must also focus on how to persuade the big economic players, and not only the US and China, but also, for example, Russia, India and other large countries, to join the objectives of the European Union in order not to gain an undue competitive advantage. Without a truly global agreement to reduce CO2 production, the European Union's plan will only transform into a move of industry outside the European Union with an impact on employment, but without an impact on the global climate. I think it is very important that greenhouse gas emissions are reduced, but we must not lose sight of employment, energy prices, especially in ourselves and in our home.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD). -
text: Mr President, successful political activity or campaigns should focus on that sound military adage ‘Never reinforce failure: follow up success.’ Two facts are clear. First, as we have said before, the climate is refusing to cooperate with forecasts: the figures show that since 1995 global warming has not been happening. This Parliament and national governments should concentrate on the practical measures which, in a period of austerity, are causing events like the Greek revolt. We should not and must not pursue policies and agreements which exacerbate Europe’s downturn and comparative decline. Applying my adage, that fact is clear. Fact two is that we do have one clear success to report: on ozone. There is international agreement that action here seems to be working. The UN tells us that we have the first signs of thickening, that over the next decade there should be a clear win, and that it can only happen if the whole world acts. Hence the need for world action ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Commissioner, we set ourselves important objectives in the run-up to Lima. We wanted to convince all the parties involved of the need to invest in an ambitious climate policy, in order to safeguard the environment and at the same time create work, encouraging the development of new technologies. The result achieved is a step forward, but only one start remains. More could certainly be done. And Paris can be the right opportunity if everyone shows the same commitment and tenacity.  Our overall objective today is to strengthen and commit the entire international community to sustainable development, because I strongly believe that there can be no real growth unless it is sustainable. It is necessary, however, to start working immediately, involving all the parties before Paris: our external and diplomatic service, as well as Parliament, the Commission and all those who, in the individual countries, deal with this issue, with a great sense of mutual cooperation between the institutions. Only in this way can we achieve our goal. I would also like to stress the importance of funding in this area: to recall the commitment made by the EU and its Member States to progressively increase the mobilisation of climate finance, which is essential for investing in research and sustainable development. I would like to end by thanking you, Commissioner, for the role you have given parliament's delegation at this conference in Lima and we hope to be able to continue to cooperate together.

name: Pervenche Berès (S&D). -
text: Mr President, Commissioner, Madam President, whatever the outcome of the Paris conference, in a way, this must serve as a spur both to set up the Energy Union, but also to guide this investment plan for our ecological transition. And there is one link that we still lack, the question of the carbon price, in order to be sure to direct investments in good market conditions, as many here wish, towards the long-term investment of ecological transition.  Beyond our business, we have a certain responsibility, not only because we are polluters, not only because this conference will take place on our continent, but also because we have to put our house in order. Many before me in this debate have mentioned this, but why can we not agree to anticipate this reserve of stability, which we all agree is a determining factor in the credibility of our European Union. So, Commissioner, roll up your sleeves and get this anticipation of the stability reserve.  There is also the issue of financing solidarity. Here, too, the European Union must be there. We have commitments to finance the Green Fund and I welcome the initiative that has just been taken in France by the Minister of Finance and the President of the Republic with his Austrian counterpart to revive a tax on financial transactions that would, in particular, feed this Green Fund, and I hope that all the Member States that are parties to this enhanced cooperation... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, at the next conference in Paris it is extremely urgent that we reach an agreement that achieves everything we have not achieved so far. The European Union must strive to set new targets for tackling climate change effectively. At our heart - we must not forget this, Commissioner - must be the needs of society and people on the planet and not the interests of multinationals and monopolies. To achieve this objective it is very important to promote new measures to limit greenhouse gas emissions. And in this direction we must press resolutely so that the agreement reached and the commitment of the states to the creation of the Green Fund for the financing of developing countries are finally implemented. This is the only way for developing countries to adapt to new climate change. Equally important is the European Union to take more initiatives to develop renewable energy sources and tackle energy ....... (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz (EFDD). -
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking Once again, we are dealing with an ideological topic, not a practical one, which exists only in the heads of politicians and lobbyists. It must be made clear Polish that a 40% reduction in CO2 emissions is an absurd, unreal and deadly condition.  Over the coming years, the price of energy in Poland will increase by at least 30%. Most lignite and coal power plants will have to be closed. We will be doomed to buy green energy from Germany, nuclear from France or gas from Russia. This is how Polish energy security will look in practice. So who will pay the costs of Polish unemployment, the cost of CO2 emissions, the cost of more expensive energy? Who will pay for losses in Polish transport, agriculture, construction...? You know Polish taxpayer, because who else? And that's all because there are a few lunatics who have insisted that climate change is dependent on man and a few who have decided to cash in on these superstitions. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Indrek Tarand (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Iwaszkiewicz, if you do not believe that climate change is caused by man, do you believe that it is caused by God?

name: Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz (EFDD)
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – Mr President, it goes without saying, as has been said here, that 2014 is the warmest year. I do not know on what basis this is told, as the name of the island of Greenland comes from the fact that it was green there, there were fields grown there, and not as there was ice at the moment. This is not a human thing, one explosion of some Vesuvius can introduce much more greenhouse gases.

name: Linda McAvan (S&D). -
text: Mr President, as the Commission and Council are aware, before we get to Paris in December the UN will be considering the SDG process at the Summit in September in New York. As they also know, Goal 13 of the Sustainable Development Goals is to tackle climate change.  So I have two questions for them: How are you linking these two processes, both within the Commission and the Council? For colleagues on the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, every country on the planet will have to adopt the Sustainable Development Goals, and implement them: it is not like the Millennium Development Goals. Yet we are not talking, even in this Parliament, in those terms. We are not linking the two things together. So I particularly want to hear from the Commission how they are working and how this will impact on the finance for development, because we can be certain that, even if we are not linking these issues, the G77 are linking them, and success in New York will determine success in Paris.

name: Massimo Paolucci (S&D). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is an illusion to think that if we are less ambitious, if we lower our environmental standards, we will be the most competitive in the world. If the game is played downwards, Europe has already lost. We must not be uncertain about the ETS. The reserve of market stability is urgently needed. It is necessary to anticipate its entry into force, to put back-loading in the reserve and to overcome the current distortions of the European internal market in support for energy-intensive industries.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D). -
text: Mr President, the negotiations in Lima have brought promise, but not a major breakthrough. I am not at all sure that world leaders have really understood that the failure of these negotiations also means security and social risks and climate migration with all the known consequences. We're running out of time because the feedback mechanisms on the planetary scale are already running out. Methane is melting on the Arctic shelf, and these mechanisms may vate any effort in the near future. We ourselves in the European Union have failed time and time again with the introduction of active measures. We're stopping air travel hours, we've botched the carbon leakage sheet, we're fixing the ETS system for a long time. Now it's Paris's turn. The Latvian Presidency has stressed several times that preparing for Paris is one of its key priorities, thank you for that. The Commission is pragmatic here, and I thank you for that. We still have a chance, but what we don't prepare for in the next six months is not going to be a good thing in Paris. And if we don't agree on measures in Paris, next time we're just going to talk about adapting to climate change.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D). -
text: The rise in global temperature already has, and will have, catastrophic consequences. The effort to be made cannot just be a European effort. It has to be a global effort and therefore we have to mobilize citizens. Change is not made only by normative means. To mobilize citizens, more than global warming, we have to talk about another model of society, with more proximity, with more participation, with more quality. A society with growth, with sustainable jobs, with efficient and clean industries and transport.  This model transition is a great economic and social opportunity motivated by an environmental urgency. Paris is a city that leads us to beauty, but also to revolution. What we have to achieve in Paris is not just a reduction in emissions, it is the revolution in the way we live in society in a sustainable way. The traditional industrial model of the second globalization died.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE). -
text: Mr. President, this conference in Paris is extremely important from the point of view of development policy. Namely, we have three major conferences this year in 2015. One will of course be about financing development policy, on global funding in Addis . Then there will be a conference in New York in September on new sustainable development goals and in December in Paris on climate change.  The international community's decision was big when it merged two different processes, one concerning climate change and the other for developing a new development framework. This synergy is extremely important, it is also extremely important that the European Union understands it and that the Commission is working on it, I would therefore also like to commend the work of the Commissioner who is constantly in contact with the Commissioner for Development and I want the European Union to speak in both cases with one voice.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D). -
text: Mr President, we are all aware of the fact that climate change is a reality. Around the world the impact of climate change is accelerating and the most vulnerable countries are already paying the higher price. Last September, the conclusions of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change were published and the debate about human influence on the climate is now over: we are responsible for warming the earth. Luckily, next November is rapidly approaching. We have never had a better opportunity than the upcoming summit to tackle the tremendous danger of climate change. This is the greatest challenge that we must face but we must face it with the greatest ambition and hope. Next November in Paris, not only European citizens but more than 7 billion people will ask us to be brave and for our choices to be bold. They will ask us to go beyond our differences and our doubts and to chart a new course together. Much has to be done in Paris but if we are able to make the climate agreement a reality our generation will not be remembered as the one that destroyed the world but as the one that finally came to respect it.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, the fight against climate change is also about radically changing how we feed ourselves. It doesn't make sense for our daily feed to travel thousands and thousands of miles. That is why small-scale peasant agriculture, local food consumption and the empowerment of short marketing circuits, while supporting millions of jobs around the world, will cause global temperatures to drop dramatically because they will drastically reduce greenhouse gas emissions. We need to be consistent and act on the discourse with which we wrap our concerns. If we are to put in place measures to tackle the serious climate crisis, we also have an obligation to commit ourselves in Paris to take a radical turn in our agricultural and food policies and to cancel the TTIP and CETA negotiations.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I note the Optimism expressed by the Commission about the possible agreement in Paris but, reading the experts of the Lima meeting, I believe that the points that have not been resolved and that they could constitute an obstacle to an ambitious agreement are still different and important. Unlike the Kyoto Protocol, it will then be the individual countries that will indicate their contribution to the overall reduction in emissions, while the scrutiny of the measures has been declassicated as a simple summary of the national measures, prepared by the Secretariat, and there is still no shared date by which the contracting parties undertake to achieve the reduction targets. Both the distribution of reduction efforts and technical and financial assistance have yet to be defined, obstacles which, if not removed before the next Paris Agreement, risk failing to negotiate on their own, as happened in Copenhagen in 2009. However, to conclude, in the final document, one of the options ... (The President withdrew the speaker)

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D). -
text: Climate change is the factor that most conditions the future of the planet and our civilization. The breaking point we have reached has now required fictionally muscled political decisions that entail a substantial reform of our way of life, including a significant reduction in the use of fossil fuels. The services of the ecosystems on which we depend are threatened and, with them, social values and our security. Worse, millions of people from islands and less developed nations suffer the effects of a situation to which they have not contributed.  Kyoto and Johannesburg failed because key countries failed. In Lima, some progress has been made but we have fallen short of needs. Paris remains. As the International Energy Agency warns, the target of two degrees Centigrade will be cancelled in 2017 in terms of objectives if, by then, the clear methodology is not agreed. I therefore look forward to seeing the continued future of what has been said so far - that in Paris more ambitious targets will be set.

text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the latest scientific research has shown that if we really want to achieve the objective of limiting global warming to 2°C, one third of oil reserves, half of current gas reserves and more than 80% of coal reserves should remain underground until 2050. However, as we discuss these objectives, we in the ACP delegation adopt a resolution in which agreements are made for the exploitation of gas, oil and coal in Africa. At the same time, therefore, we decide to reduce the extractions here in Europe that we then implement in Africa. We just have to be less hypocritical.

name: Miguel Arias Cañete
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, I would like to thank all the Members who have spoken in this debate. Many of them concentrated on the need for climate finance. Climate finance will be a key part of our work in 2015 because public finance will determine in part our credibility in the negotiations. The European Union already has a good story to tell because in 2013 alone, as I said, the Union and its Member States provided EUR 9.5 million in climate finance, including grants and loans from development banks and financial institutions in the Member States. The EU Member States also made almost half of the pledges for the Green Climate Fund. We need more credit for the efforts already being made in what is a difficult economic situation. However, we also need to maintain our efforts to scale up further, in order to provide the reassurances that are needed. We have to use public funding in a smart way. Public grant finance should be used to support the poorest and most vulnerable countries but it must also be used to leverage private investment in low-emission and climate-resilient technologies. Here too the European Union has an impressive story to tell. Some Members asked how we are going to coordinate with the sustainable development goals process. Financing for development and climate finance must go hand in hand. We can be successful only if we integrate climate objectives into national development and into our development and cooperation portfolios. We work closely with our colleagues in development cooperation and with developing countries to ensure that the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and the climate processes recognise and make use of the synergies between development and climate action. Inside the European Union we have been doing our homework. The Union has made a commitment that at least 20% of its entire budget for 2014-2020 should be spent on climate-relevant projects, and this provision applies not only to the Union’s internal spending but also to our development cooperation budget. I would also repeat that it will be very important to involve the finance ministers in the run-up to Paris. It is planned that the finance ministers will discuss climate finance in the Ecofin Council, and we expect Ecofin Council conclusions on climate finance in the second half of 2015. There was a specific question on how we were going to handle land use with regard to the intended nationally determined contributions (INDC). I can tell Members that land use will be part of the European Union INDC because the INDC will be a translation of the October European Council conclusions on the 2030 climate and energy framework, and they are clear that LULUCF (Land use, Land Use Change and Forestry) LULUCF is covered in the EU target of domestic in-house emissions reduction of at least 40%. The question is not ‘if’ but ‘how’ to do it, because we have to design good accounting rules, building on and streamlining existing approaches, and they have to ensure environmental integrity and foster ambitious climate action in the land sector. We are working intensively on this but the issue will not be resolved by the time the EU INDC is presented. Many Polish Members have expressed concern about whether our climate ambitions could hamper the development of industry. I have to tell them that the agreement reached at the October Council was unanimous and, specifically in relation to that point, when we were discussing the conditions of the Emissions Trading Scheme (ETS) the policy situation was taken into account. There are very specific measures that we will have to take account of when we draw up our ETS proposal: we will have to take into account the different situations. There are still many things that we have to tackle ahead of Paris. There are the problems of differentiation between countries’ obligations depending on their responsibilities and capabilities. There are also the questions of climate finance and the legal form and force of the future agreement. Still to be determined, too, are the extent to which, and how, the 2015 agreement will address controversial issues such as adaptation to the impacts of climate change, and dealing with loss and damage when those impacts occur, promoting or regulating international carbon markets and establishing how we are going to save them. That is why it is important that this Parliament is able to deliver soon on the carbon market and the stability reserve, so that we will arrive in Paris with a credible proposal on the basis that we have put into action an efficient carbon market and have given clear signals to industry to move in the direction of a low-carbon economy.

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council. - Mr President, honourable Members, I would like to thank you for this debate which confirms the importance and urgency of the international negotiations in 2015 towards reaching an agreement on the post-2020 climate regime in Paris. We recognise that the Lima negotiations have been difficult. However, we should not give up when confronted by difficult situations and the work on finding agreement should continue, as there is no alternative to the Paris conference. When it comes to announcements by the United States and China, I would like to stress that the US-China announcement was very important in that it is the first time that the two biggest emitters, representing 43% of global emissions, jointly announced future mitigation commitments, and in that they did so more than a year before the Paris conference. Of course we will need to have more information in order to analyse the pledge and wait for the others to come forward in order to assess how big a gap separates us from the below-2°C objective. Therefore, we need to see how these announcements will be translated into intended nationally determined contributions. You also mentioned the Climate and Energy Policy Framework 2013. The long-awaited agreement on the 2013 climate and energy framework shows the EU’s determination to respond to climate change with ambitious targets and effective measures. The conclusions of the October 2014 European Council provide essential guidance and building blocks for further work. The ETS market stability reserve proposal, which was issued together with the 2030 framework package a year ago, is a priority file for the Latvian Presidency. We are keen to make very rapid progress on it and hope that informal discussions with the European Parliament can start soon. The roadmap towards Paris will show our obligations and intentions in the international context, and the forthcoming proposals on the Energy Union will be more focused on internal EU processes. Still, I would like to use this opportunity to share with you a few points on the Energy Union. The establishment of the Energy Union is one of the priorities of the Latvian Presidency, as was also made clear by our Prime Minister at the European Parliament’s plenary session two weeks ago. We need an energy policy that is based on solidarity, trust and security, a better-integrated energy infrastructure, more efficient governance and sustainability. As you know, the European Council in December called on the Commission to present a comprehensive energy union proposal before the March European Council, and the Presidency will lead the discussions in the Council to prepare the endorsement of a strategy by the European Council in March. 2015 is a crucial year in the international climate domain and is important for international negotiations on sustainable development. The global agreement on combating climate change has to be achieved in Paris. Successful international negotiations on climate change will be one of the priorities of the Latvian Presidency. We will do everything possible to ensure effective European Union representation at international negotiating sessions, and we understand that on the way to an agreement we must be prepared for very intensive work. This will also be an important year for setting the international sustainable development agenda. On the way a to post-2015 framework development the European Union must convey a strong and united position. This is also highlighted in the resolution of the European Parliament. In order to be fully prepared, the Latvian Presidency intends to organise a discussion at the March Environmental Council on better integration of the environmental dimension in the post-2015 process. I would also like to thank Ms McAvan for bringing the development dimension to today’s discussion, and I would like to recall that 2015 has been marked as European Union Year of Development. We will have the third Financing for Development Conference in Addis Ababa, the UN post-2015 Summit in New York, and the Paris Conference as a culminating event. Therefore this year will be important, not only to the climate process. We will also have to work hard to agree on the new post-2015 development agenda. The Latvian Presidency stands ready to assist in steering discussions towards a common EU position. The run-up to Paris will see very intensive negotiations and meetings at different levels and in various formats. As on previous occasions, your support in outreach efforts to our partners worldwide is very much appreciated. I look forward to continuing this exchange and working closely together for the best possible outcome in Paris, and I would like to thank you for today’s very fruitful debate.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. – It is essential to establish well the Roadmap that the EU has to face in these months in order for the Paris Conference to be a success. The work is a lot, especially since we are in danger of falling back into old vices of texts that are too long and farcy or in an eternal search for a legal framework, which is accepted by all, and that allows the new Agreement to be binding. The Spanish Socialists welcome the announcement of the presentation of a Communication on this subject and place particular emphasis on the role that the Commission has to play in monitoring the evaluations and national plans in March. Computations have to be clear and honest. Countries need to submit plans that also take into account the total of what has ceased to be issued due to the drop in industrial activity due to the crisis or what has been over-issued through the purchase of allowances from third parties. If it is not done this way, many will be able to show off figures and have complied with Kyoto - in fact, they are already doing so - without it being entirely true.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. The Lima Conference last December was intended to prepare the ground for concluding a new international climate agreement to be implemented by 2020. Unfortunately, many of the issues to be resolved eventually prevent the negotiations from continuing in a more concrete direction and undermine the chances that the new Treaty will contain truly binding commitments on those more industrialised nations.  Therefore, in order to give concrete form to international intentions, we want a strong commitment on the part of each Member State and we will ensure that the Commission respects its policy priorities, especially in that it states that it wants to make the Union 'the world number one in the field of renewable energy and the fight against global warming'.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. – Climate change is a global challenge, and greenhouse gas emissions are a global problem requiring a global coordinated response. What happens – or does not happen – in one country will have an impact on the rest. I am strongly in favour of having a roadmap which will eventually lead us to a new, strong international climate agreement in Paris. We need to reach an ambitious, fair and legally binding agreement. What I see today is promising. After the economic crisis in the EU, which somehow put the environment on the back burner, it is once again high on the agenda. I honestly hope that Europe can be an inspiration to others and retain its global leadership on environmental and climate issues. I will not say that the Paris conference is the world’s last chance to avoid catastrophic climate change but I do believe that we have a good opportunity before of us, which we should not miss. So, as leaders, we should act now, not least for the sake of our children and future generations.

text: in writing. – In the UK, nearly 70% of people say we are not doing enough to tackle climate change. Yet British politicians on the right choose to ignore this, claiming – in blatant disregard of the scientific consensus that exists among 97% of the world’s leading climate scientists – that the link between rising carbon dioxide levels and human activity is ‘open to question’. The EU is in a unique position to take effective measures that respond to the aspirations of our citizens. Firstly, moving forward the European energy union will be crucial. An important test will be the roadmap on energy union which we expect to see next month and which should put us firmly on the path towards a sustainable, decarbonised economy based on renewables. I find it extremely disappointing that proposals put forward by my party to address this issue in an effective way were brushed off the table last week. However, we succeeded in blocking an attempt from the right to further water down reform of the ETS, and our battle continues.

text: in writing. – It is essential to establish a forward-going, ambitious and sufficiently fine-rated Roadmap for the Paris Conference. The planet needs it to be a success.
