name: Anja Hazekamp (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. – Today we are debating the 'Roadmap for a new international climate agreement in Paris'. And in the word "roadmap" there is the problem; it is exemplary of the ostrich policy of the new European Commission in everything that has to do with climate change. The Commission does not take this problem seriously and follows its own roadmap: 1. It is removing the post of Commissioner for Climate Change. 2. It ignores intensive livestock farming as an important factor in climate change. 3. It subsidizes overproduction of meat and milk, which is responsible for 14% of greenhouse gas emissions. 4. She sticks her head in the sand and denies that the long-standing agricultural policy focused on bulk production is at odds with a responsible climate policy. If we really want to tackle climate change in Paris this year, we also need to look at our own food consumption and switch to a more sustainable and plant-based consumption pattern. We must stop robbing agricultural land and food from people in developing countries in order to satisfy the hunger of Europe's intensive livestock farming. It is better to grow local, poison- and gene-free plant food. Better for the climate, better for the environment, and better for animals and people worldwide.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. The climate change conference, to be held under the auspices of the United Nations this December, aims to reach an international agreement replacing the Kyoto Agreement. The new agreement must be ambitious, legally binding and applicable to all. The fight against climate change is a common cause of nations, it is the responsibility of all of us, and we all bear the consequences. Under the Lima deal reached at the end of last year, both developed and developing countries will have to announce specific national commitments to keep global temperature rises below 2 degrees Celsius. In the opinion of scientists, the harmful effects of climate change can still be addressed below this limit, which is becoming more evident to everyone as extreme weather events become more frequent and water resources and agricultural resources decrease. Hungary has always been committed to combating climate change. It has largely outperformed its previous emission reduction targets. As a member of the European Union, hungary is still part of the most ambitious emission reduction commitment in the international community. It is well known that the EU climate and energy framework adopted last October has set a target of 40% emission reductions by 2030. However, in addition to encouraging national commitments, European diplomacy should aim to facilitate coordination between developed and developing countries before Paris. Indeed, the most demanding issues, including adapting to and financing the effects of climate change in developing countries, are yet to be resolved.

name: Jo Leinen (S&D)
text: Writing. – The outcome of the last climate summit in Lima was only a minimal consensus and the road to a global climate treaty in Paris is going to be rocky. Too many conflicts between developed and developing countries must be resolved by the end of the year in order to adopt a treaty text that, for the first time, contains legally binding objectives and measures for all countries. As hosts, the European Union has a great responsibility to break the frozen fronts between developing countries and developed countries and to act as a bridge-builder between the different expectations of the two camps. This will be a test of the European Union's place in the world and the capabilities of EU climate diplomacy. More trust between the camps must be created, for example by presenting a roadmap for financing international climate action beyond 2020. For the developing countries, the financial commitments are crucial for their willingness to compromise. After the fiasco of the Copenhagen climate summit, Europe cannot afford a second embarrassment. Otherwise, humanity risks losing the race over time to limit global warming to two degrees.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. – Global warming is caused to the greatest extent by human activity and not by natural climate fluctuations. At the moment, our prospects are not good for avoiding dramatic consequences, as the struggle for water, resources, hunger and extreme weather form a constructive process. The biosphere is able to absorb an ever-increasing proportion of co2 emissions. While it is true that air temperatures have not risen in recent years, the heat content of the system is constantly increasing as a result of greenhouse gases. Globally, it is also not a solution for large companies to move to countries that are more permissive than EU standards and continue their polluting activities in the same way. The European Union has always been at the forefront of the example against climate change. In my opinion, this is an issue that we cannot get around, and it is therefore important to coordinate our action with economic life as soon as possible. We need to develop an environmental action plan that, on the one hand, significantly reduces CO2 emissions and, on the other hand, increases our competitiveness, creates new jobs and generates economic benefits for Europe.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. - I welcome the further improvement of the attitudes of global climate policies and the Commitment to reaching an ambitious agreement in Paris this year. Europe has done its part on the global stage in this stage, but it is important that it remains a credible leader in international efforts to combat climate change.  I recall the views of this Parliament that the EU's credibility in the context of climate negotiations depends on the ambition of action within the EU and judging by the European Commission's announcement, the EU is on track to meet its 2020 targets. I also recall the Commissioner's statement made in Parliament that progress must be made to strengthen our climate change mitigation ambitions before 2020 to stay on track to reach the "below 2°C" target.  One of the first indicators of whether we are moving in the right direction will be the debate on the European Energy Security Strategy. It must adequately evaluate energy efficiency and renewable energy production measures, as this is the key to achieving European energy security and independence. If, as an EU, we advocate and propose an agreement of three binding objectives - reducing emissions, increasing energy efficiency and increasing the share of renewables - then these targets must be considered consistently and convincingly in European strategic documents.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. - Energy policy needs to move towards an elastic EU that would be competitive, secure and sustainable with far-reaching climate change plans. As policymakers, we can apply the results of scientific research and IPCC reports that have shown that global warming is caused by anthropogenic activity.  It is time for an ambitious energy and climate policy plan by 2030 and the key is: reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 40% below 1990 levels, increasing the SHARE of RES by at least 27% of European energy consumption and increasing energy efficiency by at least 27%. Investing in "green technologies" will reduce greenhouse gas emissions, boost the economy, create new high-tech jobs and strengthen the EU's competitiveness.  Analyses suggest that 2014 was the hottest year in the history of measurements in Europe, outshooting the record in 2007 by 0.3 C. Likewise, nine of the ten hottest years in the world were recorded after 2000. In order to keep global warming below 2 ºC per century, the development of technologies to capture and save carbon dioxide is crucial.  The MFF will allocate at least 20% to climate change projects, strengthening security of energy supply and reducing dependence on fossil fuel imports. Therefore, I support a new agreement that will be a major step towards creating a transformed, energy-efficient Europe as a leader in the fight against climate change.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. – Whilst the Commission tries to reform the Emissions Trading Scheme – which is probably the world’s most ambitious climate legislation – with its proposal for a Market Stability Reserve after 2020, there have been some encouraging signs from international partners who have made further commitments to capping carbon emissions. But reducing the output of CO2 is only part of the solution in limiting global warming. We also need an agreement to ensure the protection of forests and other natural carbon sinks, as this will be essential for both adaptation and mitigation. I call on the EU negotiating team to prioritise this, and to ensure that international financing will be used to protect natural carbon sinks, which also provide essential eco-services such as water purification, air filtration, and flood defence.

Therefore, on the way to the 2015 Paris climate conference, it is worth taking all reasonable steps to make formal commitments from both these countries and all developing countries gaining economic strength. Encouraging signals from China and the Us bring hope of success to the conference. This requires at least the same attention to be paid in the paris-2015 roadmap developed, both to achieving success in making realistic and comparable commitments from major global polluters and to protecting the EU's interests from excessive burdens on industry, small and medium-sized businesses and citizens. name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE). -
text: Mr President, in 2011 the Commission undertook to introduce a European accessibility law. It consisted of recommending to the Member States a minimum so that all persons with disabilities could access all services in general: we talk about transport, we talk about education, we talk about work, we talk about new technologies... all sectors of society. A study was commissioned on the socio-economic impact that the new measures would bring to improve this accessibility of goods and services for people with disabilities. In short, a study to calibrate the benefits of adopting these measures. This study had to be delivered in 2013, was awarded in 2012 and we do not yet know the conclusions of this study. name: Bernd Lucke (ECR). -
text: Mr. President! Greece voted, and the people spoke. Having built up a system of economic governance over many years, which has been laid down in various legislative acts and treaties, the people are now simply saying: no! It does not accept the conditions that come from the European level. It has its own will. This is a problem for the European Union.  How do we deal with this, given that the democratic will of the people is being expressed here? How can we insist on compliance with regulations and recommendations at the European level when the people say in democratic elections that we do not want it? The whole problem shows how bad the conflict is between the European Union's claim to govern into states and the will of the people to go their own way. We must return to the non-assistance clause, to the principle of responsibility for our own economic policy. This is the only way to re-emerge the responsibility of the States.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE). -
text: Mr. President, unlike the Slovenian Minister of Agriculture, Mr. Židan, who is practically already announcing a lawsuit against the European Union over the dispute that exists regarding the recognition and use of the Teran wine variety, I would like to invite all interested parties to reasonably, in a spirit of good-naturedness and friendship, and above all professional resolution of the dispute.  Teran is undoubtedly a special type of wine variety that has been cultivated for centuries in the whole geographical Istria and on Kras. For centuries, Istrian and Krakoly producers have grown vines and produce teran wine, which they enjoy because of its exceptional quality. I invite experts and producers of Terans from Croatia, Slovenia and Italy to jointly identify all professional relevant facts in order to resolve this situation.  Of course, as Istrian, I must say that Teran is part of our Istrian identity and that we Istrians simply cannot give up our teran wine.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, in the Spanish State we have been experiencing an increase in repression in recent times, with the aim of criminalizing social protest. Bipartisanship sinks, the regime collapses, and that is why the government and economic powers are stirring and acting in an absolutely authoritarian way. The result is that Alfon is asked for four years in prison, eight Airbus trade unionists are asked for sixty-four years in prison in total, Tamara and Ana, three years for claiming a collective agreement, Isma and Dani are asked for eight years in prison; and these are just a few of the examples, because right now there are three hundred social and trade union activists awaiting trial, when, moreover, the European Commission recognises that the Spanish State is not guaranteeing the right to a fair trial. Amnesty International has denounced excessive use of police force, increased fines for protesters and ill-treatment of detainees. Does this police state fit into this Europe of the freedoms that you talk so much about?

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE). -
text: Mr. President, I speak for the citizens of Croatia who are concerned about the way the Government of the Republic of Croatia conducts and initiates the oil exploration process in the Adriatic Sea.  We are aware of the importance of the energy security of the European Union, but not at the cost of endangering the environment, and not at the cost of endangering thousands of jobs in the economic sector, which among other things produces healthy food for croatian citizens, but also for citizens of the European Union.   The Ministry of economy and the Hydrocarbons Agency avoid complying with european union directives. They avoid quality public consultation with citizens of the Republic of Croatia and avoid consultations with other countries in the Adriatic subregion, thereby jeopardizing the public interest of Croatian citizens, but also preventing governments of other countries from working in the public interest of their citizens.  That is why I call on the Government of the Republic of Croatia to respect its own laws and implement them in the public interest.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to talk about how we persist in regarding the mafia phenomenon as something that is not a priority in the European Union. The mafia phenomenon that we deal with from time to time in committee or on certain issues is in fact a top priority, because it leads to corruption, fuels terrorism, through illegal proceeds, and generates emergencies and situations of misery, which it then exploits in order to obtain popular consent.  We should learn to make a really serious and coordinated fight between states, through an anti-Mafia prosecutor, through monitoring by a standing committee against organised crime. We should use a wonderful instrument, which could be the income of citizenship, which is an instrument that, in addition to guaranteeing dignity, ensuring fairness, could defeat at its base what is the main source of food for organised crime, namely poverty and poverty.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI). -
text: Mr President, the measures of the so-called quantitative easing Draghi and the Juncker investment package offer state money to monopolies and condemn peoples to poverty. The same line is supported by the new LINE SYRIZA-Independent Greeks in Greece, assuring that it will respect the unpopular commitments of the European Union and NATO and promote the interests of the business groups that support this Government, cynically calling the poverty of the people "simple life". That is why government change in Greece is not a change for the people. The Communist Party - and with its support in the elections - will offer all its powers so that the people do not show tolerance to the Government, stand up to recover their losses with a strong labour-based popular opposition, compete with their real opponent: the European Union, their monopolies and their power.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE). -
text: Mr President, for many people, Norway is a country where everyone would like to live. Except for me. For me, Norway is a country where hundreds, if not thousands, of children are taken annually by local social services without any obvious reason. I ask, how long are we going to ignore these practices? How long are we going to criticize any country here and not look at the land that adjoins us? I have personally convinced myself that legal remedies are not helping to remedy this situation. So we cannot be surprised that mothers from Lithuania and Poland have taken their children back to their countries. Another example is Eva Michaláková from the Czech Republic, who is fighting for her children. She has not been shown any guilt, and yet the children cannot return to their mother. My mother can't hug them and she can't speak Czech to them. I am therefore asking how long we will ignore the fact that the citizens of the Czech Republic and the European Union have no right to be... (He removed the speaker's word.)

name: Siôn Simon (S&D). -
text: Mr President, my constituency of the West Midlands is currently missing out on GBP 718 million of EU funding, entirely due to the incompetence and arrogance of the Conservative Government of the UK. Every other Member State has been able to agree its operational programmes with the Commission. The Tory Government of the UK cannot because they insist that they want to give the money to local enterprise partnerships which, unelected and unaccountable as they are, the Commission is unsurprisingly not happy with as channels for public funds. In the West Midlands we are talking about GBP 140 million for the Black Country, GBP 107 million for Coventry and Warwickshire, GBP 201 million for greater Birmingham and Solihull, GBP 127 million for Stoke-on-Trent and Staffordshire, GBP 90 million for The Marches and GBP 54 million for Worcestershire. We are not getting it because of the Tory Government.

name: Jan Zahradil (ECR). -
text: Mr President, my contribution concerns Germany, so perhaps it will be of interest to you as well. In Germany, from 1 January this year, the Minimum Wage Act applies, which must also be subject to carriers, often from eastern European countries. The law requires paying a minimum wage of €8.5 per hour. This, by the way, is four times the Czech minimum wage! I believe that, in this situation, we can boldly say that the minimum wage is aimed at distorting the single market, that it is distorting the wage systems of individual Member States, and that it is essentially creating an indirect obstacle to the freedom to provide services. I think it is a violation of one of the fundamental principles of the European Union, that we cannot accept this and that the Commission must do something about it. Moreover, it is not at all clear whether there is a legal right for this law to apply to services provided by carriers.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE). -
text: Mr President, I cannot speak today without mentioning the situation in Ukraine, because the conflict in Ukraine needs an immediate international intervention. The most logical way to go about this would be to reach a new ceasefire and also allow a UN peacekeeping force into the country. This step would end the violence and Ukraine’s further loss of any territory. But I also want to stress that, in recent months, there have been several situations which have been very close to crashes between passenger planes and military planes flying without transponders in Europe. The activity of Russian military planes has increased considerably in European airspace, especially in the Baltic Sea region. Flying with transponders and communication systems switched off represents a grave threat to passenger planes. This means that the aviation rules need to be changed in such a way that military planes could not fly without working transponders.

name: Indrek Tarand (Verts/ALE). -
text: Mr President, it is never easy to talk about war or its grave consequences. War is a costly business, especially if Russians are involved. Take it from me because I was unfortunate enough to have been forced to serve in the Russian army in the 1980s. Ukraine, as Mr Paet said, is in deep crisis. GDP shrank by nearly a tenth, the currency fell by more than 50 %, inflation is up to 25 % and foreign currency reserves fell by half within one year. Hence our question is: have we taken the necessary commitments for all kinds of aid to Ukraine, because we could not foresee the events during our discussions about the Multiannual Financial Framework? I am fully aware that there are also other crises going on around the European Union, for instance the Palestinian authorities receiving EUR 500 million each year. Now it has been proposed by the German Chancellor that we donate the same amount of money to Ukraine. Well, the size of the economy is different. I will stop here.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE). -
text: Mr President, Turkey has been a member of the European Union for forty years, it is essentially a European territory, creating tragic consequences, such as the 200,000 Greek Cypriot refugees, who are the only European citizen refugees. But there are even more tragic aspects of this tragedy, such as missing persons. Unfortunately, Turkey, and on this extremely humanitarian issue, instead of being sensitive, is showing its own inhumane face. He stubbornly refuses to open the archives of the Turkish army so that the fate of these missing persons can be investigated. At the same time, some areas have been described as so-called 'military areas' to prevent the missing from being found. At the same time, they executed in cold blood, in 1974, 70 civilians from the community of Assia, whom they transported somewhere else and do not today protest where they are. We call on the European Union to take measures towards this acceding country for a Member State of the European Union such as Cyprus. At last, Europe must respond to this ...... (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the creation of the Strategic Investment Fund is linked to a strengthening of the process of European integration, as Mr Juncker has often said in presenting it. That is why we need to involve the citizens directly, and we therefore need ways of expressing this potential in the best possible way. So why not allow citizens to feel more part of the project? New forms of Fund funding could be found that involve them directly, through a kind of 'microdonation' or crowd funding to finance the European project par excellence, the one that has actually affected the lives of millions of European citizens more than others: Erasmus.  I have circulated this proposal and received a great many enthusiastic responses, especially from young people. This means that there is a great desire for Europe but that it does not find the appropriate answers, especially the channels through which this desire can be put into practice. It is our responsibility to have the courage and audacity to experiment with new paths and give these answers.

name: Julie Girling (ECR). -
text: Mr President, I would like to use this opportunity to bring to your attention a gross infringement of the rights of my constituents, the citizens of Gibraltar, who are also fellow citizens of the EU. I refer to the issue of the Single European Sky recast proposal. The Commission had originally included explicit language referencing the Cordoba Agreement and the fact that the proposal would apply in full to Gibraltar. In March 2014, this plenary voted in favour of an amendment to exclude Gibraltar and its citizens. That vote was discriminatory and unacceptable. Imagine the outcry if we had excluded EU citizens on the basis of gender or ethnicity! Yet we did so on the basis of nationality. This is now blocked in Council – and rightly so – by the UK Government, but as a result no citizen in Europe can now benefit from the new Single European Sky regulations. So I call on fellow Members to stand up for EU citizens and ensure that this Parliament reverses the discriminatory position.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE). -
text: There is a war raging in a very sensitive and strategically important part of Europe.  For those of us who, more than 20 years ago, looked to the evening television reports from the Balkan battlefields with fear, the images of terror, destruction and suffering of innocent people are being returned. A new area where people are fleeing and seeking protection elsewhere, not at home. On both sides of the frontline in Ukraine, fighters on both sides are dying, with civilians bearing the brunt. We're going to have a new generation of traumatized kids. Is this not the time to prevent a war that we have not been able to prevent, but which we have also often supported and helped to create ourselves, to join with peace-building programmes and means, patient negotiations to stop hostilities, effective measures to protect the civilian population. It's time to see the war as it is by its nature. It doesn't distinguish between victims and dead who are ours and different.

name: Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE). -
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking On 19th January the French Ministry of Agriculture announced the conclusion of a bilateral agreement with Russia on the resumption of exports of pigs and pig products. This is a clear breach of EU rules, even worse, the European Commission has been informed of the ongoing negotiations and has not yet taken action to curb this. The European Union's relations with Russia are of the utmost political importance, and the Russian Federation has repeatedly tried to upset the Member States and destabilise our single market. In the face of such a crisis situation arising from both the agricultural embargo and the armed conflict in Ukraine (i think no one is under any illusions that these are two different issues), divisions within the Community will lead to a weakening of our markets, not to mention a loss of political credibility on the international stage. I call on the Member States to show full solidarity and for the European Commission to carry out its duties fairly.

name: Jude Kirton-Darling (S&D). -
text: Mr President, in 1984, 37 Cammell Laird shipworkers were jailed for 30 days and lost their right to a proper redundancy and pension because of striking against politically motivated job cuts. Last year in the Committee on Petitions Eddie Marnell explained that, in spite of the fact that no law was broken, the strikers were never told why. Investigations into historical miscarriages of justice, like the battle of Orgreave, have shown that, despite denials from the then government, secret closure plans existed and Conservative ministers at the time sought to influence police tactics and put pressure on them to escalate industrial disputes. Access to official documents is key to ensuring justice for those on the receiving end. These workers’ fundamental rights were violated and the Commission should press the UK Government to release the information needed to ensure that Cammell Laird workers and our coalfields get the long-awaited justice they deserve.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE). -
text: Mr President, although I am tempted to speak of Gibraltar Spanish, I will not talk about it. I will talk about science and research, as it is one of the pillars that the European Union has set itself in the coming years. In Spain, specifically in the Canary Islands, we have the best astronomical sky in the world and one of the most important centers of astrophysical research: the Institute of Astrophysics of the Canary Islands, which for thirty years has been cooperating to serve science, mainly European science. Currently, the IAC works in coordination with institutions and other research centres to ensure that the Canary Islands is headquartered in the northern hemisphere of the Cherenkov Telescope project, which will create the largest network of gamma-ray telescopes on the planet, a global project supported by the Government of Spain and that will allow the institution to expand and serve the development of science in Europe in the coming decades. The installation of the Cherenkov telescope network in the Canary Islands would be a qualitative leap in knowledge of the universe and a new impetus for a leading center such as the Institute of Astrophysics of the Canary Islands. From here I ask you for determined support for this project.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D). -
text: Mr President, in 2006 the European Investment Bank granted EUR 800 million in loans to the Generalitat Valenciana to finance the Crea Escola programme for the renovation and improvement of schools. Nine years later, the program is delayed. Nearly a hundred centres have not received a single euro and, worse, thousands of pupils study in centres in unfortunate conditions. It is time for the EI to take steps to ensure that the Generalitat Valenciana does its part and executes the school renovation works. And I want to draw particular attention to a school: the Ciutat school in Cremona, in Alaqus, whose students have been studying in barracks for eight years, in unfortunate conditions. They have created a platform to claim an educational center because the Valencian Government does not give them answers, it breaches its promises and, worse, has been eting places for two years to make the center disappear. We cannot allow public schools to be abolished because there are governments that are unable to keep their promises.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE). -
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking At a meeting of the EU Council of Agriculture Ministers on Monday, the European Commission said it had not agreed to bilateral agreements with Russia to relax the pork embargo by European Union countries. Nevertheless, I believe that the signal of opposition to such a potential situation should also come out of the European Parliament. Russia has consistently tried to create divisions within the European Union, so we cannot tolerate any discriminatory practices against any Member State. In the case of contacts and negotiations with Russia, but also in crisis situations and especially in the face of the tense situation in Ukraine, we must be coherent, united and in solidarity.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D). -
text: Because of the huge number of conflicts around the world, there are more than 50 million people forcibly displaced and 7 million have left their homelands in the last year. In the last 2 years in my country Bulgaria has sought asylum 18 thousand refugees, and separately under the Dublin Regulation there is an inquiry for the return of another 8 thousand. This puts Bulgaria at a disadvantage to other European countries because refugees remain in those countries where they first crossed the borders of the European Union.  In addition to revising European migration legislation, I set out clearly the most important issues that are of paramount importance to our country – our adoption in Schengen and the issue of refugees. Both are unconditionally linked to our external border and must be reflected in the European Commission's work programme for this year. The implementation of the Schengen Agreement in Bulgaria must be a priority not only for Bulgaria, but also for the whole of Europe.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to draw your attention to a fact in the relations between the European Union and Russia, which I find alarming. The Russian Ministry of Education has issued an official document calling on representatives of universities to proactively inform about the Activities of the European Union on the territory of Russia, which it calls European propaganda. We who have experienced totalitarianism know that the Russian state thus wants to gain more control over schools and academia. The Russian Ministry wants information about the Erasmus programme, it wants to inform students in advance of the official Russian opinion before discussions with experts from the European Union. These actions are considered by Russian officials to be a nest of destructive ideas, which are very dangerous for students.  I would like to draw the Attention of the European Parliament to this situation and to support the Representation of the European Union in Moscow, which has expressed its concern. The unilateral move by the Russian Ministry is a dangerous signal of restrictions on freedom. Students have always been at the beginning of pro-democracy changes in society, and the Russian regime seems to be worried about this.

name: Paul Brannen (S&D). -
text: Mr President, last Friday I visited dairy farmers in my constituency in Northumberland in the north-east of England and I met with farmers Chris McDonald and Richard and Dennis Gibb. Richard and Dennis have 300 cows on their farm and as a result of the fall in the price of milk over the last eight months they are now receiving a dip in income of a quarter of a million pounds. They are clearly struggling, as are dairy farmers across the UK.  What is to be done? One thing that customers can do is ask their supermarket managers if they are ensuring that they are paying a fair price for all of the milk that they have on sale in the supermarket. Customer power can be used to deliver a fair price for our farmers. It is right that dairy farmers milk cows, but it is wrong if supermarkets and customers milk dairy farmers.

name: Der Präsident. -
text: This concludes this item of the meeting.

text: I declare the session of the European Parliament adjourned. (The sitting was closed at 8.25 p.m.)
